urn:contentItem:5WN1-HKS1-DYRK-9494-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 14:55 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 14:55 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 14:55 ET

Dow: -108.23...

Nasdaq: +45.13... S&P: +8.58...

NYSE Vol: 378.5 mln.. Adv: 2021.. Dec: 853

Nasdaq Vol: 1.3 bln.. Adv: 2072.. Dec: 929

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite push to all-time highs; cyclical sectors outperformRelative strength in UPS (UPS) and the semiconductor stocks following upbeat earnings resultsCaterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA) disappoint on earnings, guidanceDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities, Consumer Staples

14:55 ET

Dow -108.23 at 27240.96, Nasdaq +45.13 at 8296.54, S&P +8.58 at 3014.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.3%, nearing its all-time high, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.2%. The Nasdaq Composite (+0.5%) is currently trading at its all-time intraday high.

Today's advance has been concentrated among the cyclical sectors -- financials (+0.7%), industrials (+0.5%), information technology (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer discretionary (+0.3%). The communication services sector (+0.7%) has been another leader as investors buy the dip in Netflix (NFLX 319.42, +12.12, +4.0%).

Looking ahead, notable companies that will report earnings after today's close include Facebook (FB 203.19, +0.83, +0.4%), Ford Motor (F 10.32, +0.15, +1.4%), PayPal (PYPL 120.77, +0.55, +0.5%), and Tesla (TSLA 262.65, +2.48, +1.0%).

14:30 ET

Dow -118.60 at 27230.59, Nasdaq +37.92 at 8289.33, S&P +6.95 at 3012.42

[BRIEFING.COM] Both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite notched session highs in the last half hour, up 0.23% and 0.46%, respectively.

Positive action in the S&P 500 is led by earnings movers like Discover Financial Services (DFS 92.13, +7.65, +9.06%), Edwards Lifesciences (EW 211.97, +16.51, +8.45%), and Grainger (GWW 301.54, +22.76, +8.16%).

Conversely, Rollins (ROL 34.35, -3.80, -9.96%) sits at the bottom of the index in light of this morning's in-line Q2 results.

14:00 ET

Dow -124.98 at 27224.21, Nasdaq +31.96 at 8283.37, S&P +4.50 at 3009.97

[BRIEFING.COM] Again, the major averages have held their lines in the last half hour with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite still within shouting distance of session highs.

Gold futures gave up most of their morning advance though still settled 0.1% higher to $1,423.60/oz on Wednesday in view of this morning's less than stellar Manufacturing PMI reading.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index has traded mostly sideways today, down less than 0.1% at the moment to 97.66.

13:30 ET

Dow -116.45 at 27232.74, Nasdaq +32.39 at 8283.8, S&P +4.58 at 3010.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages sit little changed in the last half hour with the Dow Jones Industrial Average still in a hole, down about 116 points now.

Aside from the widely-covered losses from Dow Jones Industrial Average components Boeing (BA 362.35, -10.72, -2.87%) & Caterpillar (CAT 131.93, -6.127, -4.47%) shares of UnitedHealth (UNH 252.51, -2.50, -0.98%), Procter & Gamble (PG 112.73, -1.12, -0.98%), and Pfizer (PFE 42.68, -0.41, -0.95%) sit modestly lower.

Conversely, semiconductor giant Intel (INTC 52.72, +0.97, +1.87%) sits atop the index due in part to broader strength in tech and chips.

The DJIA gives back almost all of yesterday's decently higher session, now 0.29% higher on the week.

Elsewhere, at the top of the hour, the Treasury's $41 bln 5-year note auction drew a high yield of 1.824% on a bid-to-cover of 2.26.

12:55 ET

Dow -116.01 at 27233.18, Nasdaq +31.88 at 8283.29, S&P +3.92 at 3009.39

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market trades mixed today. Strong gains in the semiconductor stocks have contributed to the positive disposition in the S&P 500 (+0.1%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.4%), but noticeable losses in shares of Boeing (BA 363.44, -9.60, -2.6%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.34, -5.77, -4.2%) have pressured the Dow Jones Industrial Average (-0.4%).

Outside of Caterpillar, which missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance, earnings results have continued to come in mostly better than expected. Boeing beat estimates, but its struggles remain company-specific.

UPS (UPS 113.27, +8.00, +7.6%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 338.16, +14.17, +4.4%), ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 785.79, +46.19, +6.3%), and Texas Instruments (TXN 129.13, +9.06, +7.4%) are some of today's biggest earnings gainers. Visa (V 180.68, -0.22, -0.1%) beat estimates and raised guidance, but reaction has been muted.

Texas Instruments' report has spurred big gains in the semiconductor stocks, many of which are contributing to the leadership of the S&P 500 information technology sector (+0.5%) and Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.9%). Still, losses in five of the 11 S&P 500 sectors, including consumer staples (-0.7%), have kept the broader market in check.

The market is also missing the influential leadership from some of its largest tech companies, which are currently holding modest losses after the Department of Justice announced an antitrust review into the "market-leading online platforms."

Big-tech scrutiny is nothing new, but it does show legitimate efforts to oversee the influence of market leaders like Facebook (FB 201.40, -0.94, -0.5%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.50, -2.99, -0.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1133.77, -12.44, -1.1%), and Apple (AAPL 208.13, -0.70, -0.3%). On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1949/905. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1963/986.

12:25 ET

Dow -124.36 at 27224.83, Nasdaq +22.75 at 8274.16, S&P +1.41 at 3006.88

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades just above its flat line, holding steady above the 3000 level. The Nasdaq outperforms with a gain of 0.3%, while the Dow trades lower by 0.4%.

Looking at the FAANG stocks shows Netflix (NFLX 314.65, +7.39, +2.4%) finally receiving some reprieve after disappointing investors last week. Conversely, Facebook (FB 201.71, -0.65, -0.4%), Apple (AAPL 207.95, -0.89, -0.4%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.43, -3.06, -0.2%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1135.29, -10.92, -1.0%) remain in the red amid the regulatory overhang from the DoJ.

Overseas, the major European indices closed mixed. Germany's DAX increased 0.3%, UK's FTSE lost 0.7%, and France's CAC lost 0.2%. The Europe Stoxx 600 increased 0.1%.

12:00 ET

Dow -139.91 at 27209.28, Nasdaq +14.27 at 8265.68, S&P +0.26 at 3005.73

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market remains mixed, but strikingly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.8%) has advanced to its best levels of the session. That move has been instrumental in lending support to the broader market.

One can sense, however, that selling activity in the broader market might pick up some steam if the semiconductor shares start to roll over, so this will be a closely-watched area as the day progresses.

Overall, there aren't any standout moves from a sector standpoint. Six sectors are up, and five sectors are down, with the performance range spanning -0.5% (health care) to +0.3% (energy).

Separately, Treasuries continue to hold modest gains, with yields down one to three basis points in maturities ranging from the 2-yr note to the 30-yr bond.

11:25 ET

Dow -129.99 at 27219.2, Nasdaq +7.03 at 8258.44, S&P -1.62 at 3003.85

[BRIEFING.COM] It's currently a mixed market with six S&P 500 sectors trading lower and five sectors trading higher. The benchmark index currently trades just below its flat line.

The flattish disposition isn't too bad considering the negative tone in the market prior to the open. Some of that negativity stemmed from weakening manufacturing flash PMI readings out of Europe, the DoJ antitrust probe into the largest online companies, and disappointing guidance from Caterpillar (CAT 132.69, -5.37, -3.9%).

These are legitimate points for investors to be concerned about, but the fact that earnings have come in mostly better than expected has been a positive consideration. The outperformance of the S&P 500 energy sector (+0.8%) amid higher oil prices ($57.08, -$0.30, -0.5%) has also been an area of support for the broader market.

10:55 ET

Dow -135.83 at 27213.36, Nasdaq -11.98 at 8239.43, S&P +1.62 at 3007.09

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher 0.1% after beginning the day on a lower note. The outperformance in several industrial companies and the semiconductor stocks has contributed to the positive disposition.

Like the broader market, the industrials sector (+0.3%) began the day lower amid weakness in shares of Boeing (BA 367.34, -5.69, -1.5%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.38, -5.67, -4.1%) after disappointing investors with results and/or guidance. UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.73, +8.3%) and Northrop Grumman (NOC 337.20, +13.22, +4.1%), however, have provided strong support for the sector after pleasing investors with their results.

Similarly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.5%, rising on the back of solid results from Texas Instruments (TXN 127.99, +7.92, +6.6%). The PHLX is now up a staggering 40% this year.

10:40 ET

Dow -64.20 at 27284.99, Nasdaq +23.24 at 8274.65, S&P +5.19 at 3010.66

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are higher (+0.5% at 79.92 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is lower (-0.1% at 97.6160)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.75 (+1.3%) at $57.52/barrelEIA petroleum data for the week ended July 19- huge draw in oilCrude oil inventories had a draw of 10.8 mln from the prior weekPrior week showed a draw of 3.1 mlnGasoline Inventories had a draw of 0.2 mln barrelPrior week had a build of 3.6 mln barrelDistillate Inventories had a build of 0.6 mlnPrior week had a build of 5.7 mlnEIA reported U.S. oil production fell 700K barrels per day (bpd) to 11.3 mln bpd, a massive reduction. Recent storm Barry plays some part in the reported data, but this really does seem to be a huge reduction..In other energy, Aug natural gas is -$0.06 (-2.5%) at $2.24/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$2.85 (+0.2%) at $1424.55/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.13 (+0.8%) at $16.61/ozSept copper is now +$0.02 (+0.6%) at $2.72/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1800/911. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1719/1095.

10:00 ET

Dow -80.60 at 27268.59, Nasdaq +3.12 at 8254.53, S&P +0.18 at 3005.65

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has marched back to its flat line, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.1%.

Just in, New Home Sales in June hit an annualized rate of 646,000, coming in below the Briefing.com consensus of 660,000. The May reading was revised to 604,000 (from 626,000).

09:45 ET

Dow -139.01 at 27210.18, Nasdaq -6.58 at 8244.83, S&P -2.97 at 3002.5

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market begins the day modestly lower amid weakness in Caterpillar (CAT 129.24, -8.89, -6.4%), Boeing (BA 367.44, -5.80, -1.6%), and mega-cap tech stocks. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%, and the Nasdaq composite is down 0.1%.

An early look at the S&P 500 sectors shows industrials (-0.1%) recovering some its opening losses as UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.71, +8.0%) helps offset losses from Caterpillar and Boeing following their earnings reports. Health care (-0.9%) is an early laggard, while energy (+0.4%) outperforms.

Separately, Facebook (FB 199.30, -3.09, -1.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1131.90, -14.31, -1.3%), and Amazon (AMZN 1974.59, -19.90, -1.0%) are each down at least 1.0% after the DoJ launched an antitrust probe into the leading online platforms.

U.S. Treasuries are slightly higher, pushing yields lower. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.63. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $56.91/bbl.

09:15 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -24.50.

Wall Street is headed for a lower start in a busy morning in news that has reined in some of yesterday's enthusiasm. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

Alphabet (GOOG 1134.35, -11.86, -1.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1970.00, -24.49, -1.2%), and Facebook (FB 198.50, -3.86, -1.9%) are under pressure this morning after the DoJ announced that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms. On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

Elsewhere, shares of Caterpillar (CAT 131.20, -6.60, -4.8%) are getting hit in pre-market after the Dow component missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance. Fellow Dow components Visa (V 180.21, -0.69, -0.4%) and Boeing (BA 370.89, -2.18, -0.6%) are also down following their results.

Overseas, the slowdown in the eurozone region has persisted, evidenced by the weaker-than-expected flash Manufacturing PMI readings for July. The eurozone reading declined to 46.4 from 47.6. A level below 50.0 denotes a contraction.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -20.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade seven points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own. Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

In economic data: Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3). Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6). New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.2% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.8% India's Sensex: -0.4% South Korea's Kospi: -0.9% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.7%

Major European indices are mixed. The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

In economic data: Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%). Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8). France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102). Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.1%Germany's DAX: +0.3% U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.8% France's CAC 40: -0.4% Italy's FTSE MIB: +0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: +0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.

The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices.

In other earnings news, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights.

08:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.

U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action.

In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.

Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance. Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance. Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei +0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng +0.2%, China's Shanghai Composite +0.8%, India's Sensex -0.4%, South Korea's Kospi -0.9%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries +0.7%.In economic data:Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3).Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6).New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).In news: People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own.Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.Major European indices are mixed. June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%).Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8).France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102).Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)In news:The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

07:27 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.60.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -11.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -42.40.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...21709.57...+88.70...+0.40%. Hang Seng...28524.04...+57.60...+0.20%.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7484.95...-71.90...-1.00%. DAX...12504.5...+13.80...+0.10%.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HMD1-JC8H-K18S-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 14:55 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 14:55 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 14:55 ET

Dow: -108.23...

Nasdaq: +45.13... S&P: +8.58...

NYSE Vol: 378.5 mln.. Adv: 2021.. Dec: 853

Nasdaq Vol: 1.3 bln.. Adv: 2072.. Dec: 929

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite push to all-time highs; cyclical sectors outperformRelative strength in UPS (UPS) and the semiconductor stocks following upbeat earnings resultsCaterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA) disappoint on earnings, guidanceDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities, Consumer Staples

14:55 ET

Dow -108.23 at 27240.96, Nasdaq +45.13 at 8296.54, S&P +8.58 at 3014.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.3%, nearing its all-time high, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.2%. The Nasdaq Composite (+0.5%) is currently trading at its all-time intraday high.

Today's advance has been concentrated among the cyclical sectors -- financials (+0.7%), industrials (+0.5%), information technology (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer discretionary (+0.3%). The communication services sector (+0.7%) has been another leader as investors buy the dip in Netflix (NFLX 319.42, +12.12, +4.0%).

Looking ahead, notable companies that will report earnings after today's close include Facebook (FB 203.19, +0.83, +0.4%), Ford Motor (F 10.32, +0.15, +1.4%), PayPal (PYPL 120.77, +0.55, +0.5%), and Tesla (TSLA 262.65, +2.48, +1.0%).

14:30 ET

Dow -118.60 at 27230.59, Nasdaq +37.92 at 8289.33, S&P +6.95 at 3012.42

[BRIEFING.COM] Both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite notched session highs in the last half hour, up 0.23% and 0.46%, respectively.

Positive action in the S&P 500 is led by earnings movers like Discover Financial Services (DFS 92.13, +7.65, +9.06%), Edwards Lifesciences (EW 211.97, +16.51, +8.45%), and Grainger (GWW 301.54, +22.76, +8.16%).

Conversely, Rollins (ROL 34.35, -3.80, -9.96%) sits at the bottom of the index in light of this morning's in-line Q2 results.

14:00 ET

Dow -124.98 at 27224.21, Nasdaq +31.96 at 8283.37, S&P +4.50 at 3009.97

[BRIEFING.COM] Again, the major averages have held their lines in the last half hour with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite still within shouting distance of session highs.

Gold futures gave up most of their morning advance though still settled 0.1% higher to $1,423.60/oz on Wednesday in view of this morning's less than stellar Manufacturing PMI reading.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index has traded mostly sideways today, down less than 0.1% at the moment to 97.66.

13:30 ET

Dow -116.45 at 27232.74, Nasdaq +32.39 at 8283.8, S&P +4.58 at 3010.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages sit little changed in the last half hour with the Dow Jones Industrial Average still in a hole, down about 116 points now.

Aside from the widely-covered losses from Dow Jones Industrial Average components Boeing (BA 362.35, -10.72, -2.87%) & Caterpillar (CAT 131.93, -6.127, -4.47%) shares of UnitedHealth (UNH 252.51, -2.50, -0.98%), Procter & Gamble (PG 112.73, -1.12, -0.98%), and Pfizer (PFE 42.68, -0.41, -0.95%) sit modestly lower.

Conversely, semiconductor giant Intel (INTC 52.72, +0.97, +1.87%) sits atop the index due in part to broader strength in tech and chips.

The DJIA gives back almost all of yesterday's decently higher session, now 0.29% higher on the week.

Elsewhere, at the top of the hour, the Treasury's $41 bln 5-year note auction drew a high yield of 1.824% on a bid-to-cover of 2.26.

12:55 ET

Dow -116.01 at 27233.18, Nasdaq +31.88 at 8283.29, S&P +3.92 at 3009.39

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market trades mixed today. Strong gains in the semiconductor stocks have contributed to the positive disposition in the S&P 500 (+0.1%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.4%), but noticeable losses in shares of Boeing (BA 363.44, -9.60, -2.6%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.34, -5.77, -4.2%) have pressured the Dow Jones Industrial Average (-0.4%).

Outside of Caterpillar, which missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance, earnings results have continued to come in mostly better than expected. Boeing beat estimates, but its struggles remain company-specific.

UPS (UPS 113.27, +8.00, +7.6%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 338.16, +14.17, +4.4%), ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 785.79, +46.19, +6.3%), and Texas Instruments (TXN 129.13, +9.06, +7.4%) are some of today's biggest earnings gainers. Visa (V 180.68, -0.22, -0.1%) beat estimates and raised guidance, but reaction has been muted.

Texas Instruments' report has spurred big gains in the semiconductor stocks, many of which are contributing to the leadership of the S&P 500 information technology sector (+0.5%) and Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.9%). Still, losses in five of the 11 S&P 500 sectors, including consumer staples (-0.7%), have kept the broader market in check.

The market is also missing the influential leadership from some of its largest tech companies, which are currently holding modest losses after the Department of Justice announced an antitrust review into the "market-leading online platforms."

Big-tech scrutiny is nothing new, but it does show legitimate efforts to oversee the influence of market leaders like Facebook (FB 201.40, -0.94, -0.5%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.50, -2.99, -0.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1133.77, -12.44, -1.1%), and Apple (AAPL 208.13, -0.70, -0.3%). On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1949/905. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1963/986.

12:25 ET

Dow -124.36 at 27224.83, Nasdaq +22.75 at 8274.16, S&P +1.41 at 3006.88

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades just above its flat line, holding steady above the 3000 level. The Nasdaq outperforms with a gain of 0.3%, while the Dow trades lower by 0.4%.

Looking at the FAANG stocks shows Netflix (NFLX 314.65, +7.39, +2.4%) finally receiving some reprieve after disappointing investors last week. Conversely, Facebook (FB 201.71, -0.65, -0.4%), Apple (AAPL 207.95, -0.89, -0.4%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.43, -3.06, -0.2%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1135.29, -10.92, -1.0%) remain in the red amid the regulatory overhang from the DoJ.

Overseas, the major European indices closed mixed. Germany's DAX increased 0.3%, UK's FTSE lost 0.7%, and France's CAC lost 0.2%. The Europe Stoxx 600 increased 0.1%.

12:00 ET

Dow -139.91 at 27209.28, Nasdaq +14.27 at 8265.68, S&P +0.26 at 3005.73

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market remains mixed, but strikingly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.8%) has advanced to its best levels of the session. That move has been instrumental in lending support to the broader market.

One can sense, however, that selling activity in the broader market might pick up some steam if the semiconductor shares start to roll over, so this will be a closely-watched area as the day progresses.

Overall, there aren't any standout moves from a sector standpoint. Six sectors are up, and five sectors are down, with the performance range spanning -0.5% (health care) to +0.3% (energy).

Separately, Treasuries continue to hold modest gains, with yields down one to three basis points in maturities ranging from the 2-yr note to the 30-yr bond.

11:25 ET

Dow -129.99 at 27219.2, Nasdaq +7.03 at 8258.44, S&P -1.62 at 3003.85

[BRIEFING.COM] It's currently a mixed market with six S&P 500 sectors trading lower and five sectors trading higher. The benchmark index currently trades just below its flat line.

The flattish disposition isn't too bad considering the negative tone in the market prior to the open. Some of that negativity stemmed from weakening manufacturing flash PMI readings out of Europe, the DoJ antitrust probe into the largest online companies, and disappointing guidance from Caterpillar (CAT 132.69, -5.37, -3.9%).

These are legitimate points for investors to be concerned about, but the fact that earnings have come in mostly better than expected has been a positive consideration. The outperformance of the S&P 500 energy sector (+0.8%) amid higher oil prices ($57.08, -$0.30, -0.5%) has also been an area of support for the broader market.

10:55 ET

Dow -135.83 at 27213.36, Nasdaq -11.98 at 8239.43, S&P +1.62 at 3007.09

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher 0.1% after beginning the day on a lower note. The outperformance in several industrial companies and the semiconductor stocks has contributed to the positive disposition.

Like the broader market, the industrials sector (+0.3%) began the day lower amid weakness in shares of Boeing (BA 367.34, -5.69, -1.5%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.38, -5.67, -4.1%) after disappointing investors with results and/or guidance. UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.73, +8.3%) and Northrop Grumman (NOC 337.20, +13.22, +4.1%), however, have provided strong support for the sector after pleasing investors with their results.

Similarly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.5%, rising on the back of solid results from Texas Instruments (TXN 127.99, +7.92, +6.6%). The PHLX is now up a staggering 40% this year.

10:40 ET

Dow -64.20 at 27284.99, Nasdaq +23.24 at 8274.65, S&P +5.19 at 3010.66

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are higher (+0.5% at 79.92 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is lower (-0.1% at 97.6160)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.75 (+1.3%) at $57.52/barrelEIA petroleum data for the week ended July 19- huge draw in oilCrude oil inventories had a draw of 10.8 mln from the prior weekPrior week showed a draw of 3.1 mlnGasoline Inventories had a draw of 0.2 mln barrelPrior week had a build of 3.6 mln barrelDistillate Inventories had a build of 0.6 mlnPrior week had a build of 5.7 mlnEIA reported U.S. oil production fell 700K barrels per day (bpd) to 11.3 mln bpd, a massive reduction. Recent storm Barry plays some part in the reported data, but this really does seem to be a huge reduction..In other energy, Aug natural gas is -$0.06 (-2.5%) at $2.24/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$2.85 (+0.2%) at $1424.55/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.13 (+0.8%) at $16.61/ozSept copper is now +$0.02 (+0.6%) at $2.72/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1800/911. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1719/1095.

10:00 ET

Dow -80.60 at 27268.59, Nasdaq +3.12 at 8254.53, S&P +0.18 at 3005.65

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has marched back to its flat line, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.1%.

Just in, New Home Sales in June hit an annualized rate of 646,000, coming in below the Briefing.com consensus of 660,000. The May reading was revised to 604,000 (from 626,000).

09:45 ET

Dow -139.01 at 27210.18, Nasdaq -6.58 at 8244.83, S&P -2.97 at 3002.5

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market begins the day modestly lower amid weakness in Caterpillar (CAT 129.24, -8.89, -6.4%), Boeing (BA 367.44, -5.80, -1.6%), and mega-cap tech stocks. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%, and the Nasdaq composite is down 0.1%.

An early look at the S&P 500 sectors shows industrials (-0.1%) recovering some its opening losses as UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.71, +8.0%) helps offset losses from Caterpillar and Boeing following their earnings reports. Health care (-0.9%) is an early laggard, while energy (+0.4%) outperforms.

Separately, Facebook (FB 199.30, -3.09, -1.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1131.90, -14.31, -1.3%), and Amazon (AMZN 1974.59, -19.90, -1.0%) are each down at least 1.0% after the DoJ launched an antitrust probe into the leading online platforms.

U.S. Treasuries are slightly higher, pushing yields lower. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.63. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $56.91/bbl.

09:15 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -24.50.

Wall Street is headed for a lower start in a busy morning in news that has reined in some of yesterday's enthusiasm. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

Alphabet (GOOG 1134.35, -11.86, -1.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1970.00, -24.49, -1.2%), and Facebook (FB 198.50, -3.86, -1.9%) are under pressure this morning after the DoJ announced that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms. On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

Elsewhere, shares of Caterpillar (CAT 131.20, -6.60, -4.8%) are getting hit in pre-market after the Dow component missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance. Fellow Dow components Visa (V 180.21, -0.69, -0.4%) and Boeing (BA 370.89, -2.18, -0.6%) are also down following their results.

Overseas, the slowdown in the eurozone region has persisted, evidenced by the weaker-than-expected flash Manufacturing PMI readings for July. The eurozone reading declined to 46.4 from 47.6. A level below 50.0 denotes a contraction.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -20.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade seven points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own. Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

In economic data: Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3). Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6). New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.2% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.8% India's Sensex: -0.4% South Korea's Kospi: -0.9% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.7%

Major European indices are mixed. The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

In economic data: Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%). Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8). France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102). Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.1%Germany's DAX: +0.3% U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.8% France's CAC 40: -0.4% Italy's FTSE MIB: +0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: +0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.

The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices.

In other earnings news, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights.

08:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.

U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action.

In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.

Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance. Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance. Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei +0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng +0.2%, China's Shanghai Composite +0.8%, India's Sensex -0.4%, South Korea's Kospi -0.9%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries +0.7%.In economic data:Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3).Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6).New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).In news: People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own.Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.Major European indices are mixed. STOXX Europe 600 UNCH, Germany's DAX +0.4%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -1.0%, France's CAC 40 -0.3%, Italy's FTSE MIB +0.4%, Spain's IBEX 35 +0.3%.In economic data:Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%).Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8).France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102).Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)In news:The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

07:27 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.60.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -11.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -42.40.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...21709.57...+88.70...+0.40%. Hang Seng...28524.04...+57.60...+0.20%.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7484.95...-71.90...-1.00%. DAX...12504.5...+13.80...+0.10%.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5W8C-0J11-JC8H-K1NY-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 14:55 ET2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 14:55 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 04-Jun-19

The market at 14:55 ET

Dow: +436.07...

Nasdaq: +163.33... S&P: +48.30...

NYSE Vol: 430.5 mln.. Adv: 2263.. Dec: 636

Nasdaq Vol: 1.6 bln.. Adv: 2198.. Dec: 828

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Stock market rallies from short-term oversold conditions and yesterday's rout in big-techFed Chair Powell said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansionDemand for U.S. Treasuries cools off, sending yields higher, in a counter-trade from short-term overbought conditions The S&P 500 breaks above its 200-day moving average (2775)

Strong: Financials, Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Industrials

Weak: Utilities, Real Estate

14:55 ET

Dow +436.07 at 25255.85, Nasdaq +163.33 at 7496.32, S&P +48.30 at 2792.75

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 1.7%, and the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.8%.

The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX 17.52, -1.34, -7.2%) has declined noticeably today as buying conviction for equities holds firm. Strikingly, despite the recent losses in the stock market, the VIX never made a convincing move to its recent May 5 high of 23.38.

Looking ahead, Salesforce (CRM 148.90, +3.80, +2.6%) will report its earnings report after today's close.

14:25 ET

Dow +430.82 at 25250.6, Nasdaq +159.91 at 7492.9, S&P +47.95 at 2792.4

[BRIEFING.COM] There has been little to sway the market's decision to rally today. The S&P 500 continues to trade near session highs with a gain of 1.7%.

A look inside the S&P 500 shows Mattel Inc (MAT 10.71, +1.06, +10.9%), Wynn Resorts (WYNN 111.38, +7.81, +7.5%), and MGM Resorts International (MGM 25.35, +1.48, +6.2%) among today's biggest gainers. Mattel announced an international licensing agreement with Sanrio, Inc. WYNN and MGM are benefiting from the prevailing view that stocks were primed for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions.

On the other hand, Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR 32.72, -1.34, -3.9%) has been left out of today's rally, as investors take some profits from yesterday's 8.8% surge.

14:00 ET

Dow +451.73 at 25271.51, Nasdaq +163.67 at 7496.66, S&P +48.88 at 2793.33

[BRIEFING.COM] In the last half hour the Nasdaq Composite and the S&P 500 both made session highs with the Nasdaq's lead growing, now up 2.23% on the day.

Gold futures settled higher for a fifth straight session on Tuesday, but only just so, up less than 0.1% to $1,328.70/oz.

The U.S. Dollar Index sits little changed at 97.13, but spent a good portion of the morning in negative territory.

13:30 ET

Dow +438.51 at 25258.29, Nasdaq +157.30 at 7490.29, S&P +47.80 at 2792.25

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have held their ground in the last half hour, little changed with the Nasdaq Composite still in the lead, up 2.15%.

Inside the Dow Jones Industrial Average action has held its broadly higher bias with NIKE (NKE 80.66, +2.70, +3.46%), Dow (DOW 49.56, +1.60, +3.34%) & Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 51.52, +1.61, +3.23%) leading the move.

Conversely, Coca-Cola (KO 49.88, -0.10, -0.20%) is the lone decliner in the Dow 30.

The DJIA sits near a six-day high at this moment, now up 1.79% on the month.

13:00 ET

Dow +454.12 at 25273.9, Nasdaq +156.06 at 7489.05, S&P +47.84 at 2792.29

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has made a nice run so far today, bolstered by broad-based buying interest and an opportunistic trade rooted in the idea that it was primed to rebound from a short-term oversold condition. The major indices, led by a 2.3% gain in the Russell 2000, are all up at least 1.8% and trading at session highs.

Today's move began in earnest at the sound of the opening bell, as market participants reacted favorably to headlines that seemingly cooled down the temperature surrounding the trade dispute with China, and provided some cover to think the tariff on imported goods from Mexico could be averted, either due to a deal with the U.S. ahead of the June 10 deadline or a possible vote in Congress to forestall the action, according to the Washington Post.

In reality, the mood of the market had been lifted on Monday when the S&P 500 exhibited some relative strength in the face of large losses suffered by Alphabet (GOOG 1051.22, +14.99, +1.5%), Facebook (FB 166.54, +2.39, +1.5%), Amazon.com (AMZN 1723.80, +31.11, +1.8%), and Apple (AAPL 178.68, +5.37, +3.1%), which fell prone to some regulatory angst on the part of investors.

Those mega-cap stocks have managed to bounce back some today on the belief that any investigation into their business practices is likely to be a drawn out one; moreover, there is some underlying hope that none of the companies would eventually be broken up by the government.

Their gains today have helped bolster the broader market, yet the buying interest has been widespread. The information technology (+2.6%), financials (+2.3%), industrials (+2.1%), and consumer discretionary (+2.1%) sectors are all up at least 2.0%. The only sectors not participating today are the defensive-oriented real estate (-1.1%) and utilities (-1.0%) sectors.

Some of the fallout for the latter two sectors hearkens back to the Treasury market, where yields have risen noticeably across the curve on a counter-trade rooted in the idea that Treasuries were primed for a pullback from a short-term overbought condition.

The 2-yr note yield has spiked seven basis points to 1.90% while the 10-yr note yield has jumped five basis points to 2.14%.

The losses in the Treasury market have unfolded despite some softening CPI data out of the eurozone and a 0.8% decline in U.S. factory orders for April.

The non-response in the Treasury market to otherwise disappointing economic data and some seemingly supportive remarks from Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, underscores how the Treasury market is succumbing to the overbought perspective.

Neither Mr. Powell nor Mr. Evans promised a rate cut soon while speaking at a conference in Chicago, yet both paid heed to the risks of undershooting the 2.0% inflation target and the risks of the trade uncertainty, which has been construed by some today as a dovish policy leaning.

Separately, there was no mistaking the leaning in the analyst community with respect to Uber (UBER 42.17, +0.92, +2.2%). No fewer than 20 firms initiated coverage of the stock after its IPO, 16 of which had the equivalent of a Buy recommendation.

12:25 ET

Dow +403.11 at 25222.89, Nasdaq +141.44 at 7474.43, S&P +42.97 at 2787.42

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages hover near their recently established session highs. The Nasdaq (+1.9%) remains in the lead while the S&P 500 (+1.6%) follows a bit behind. The Nasdaq's outperformance comes after the tech-heavy index displayed relative weakness on Monday.

Accordingly, the Nasdaq's outperformance has been supported by a 2.3% gain in the technology sector. The top-weighted group is today's best performer with chipmakers doing their part. The PHLX Semiconductor Index is up 3.0% with all 30 components trading in the green. NVIDIA (NVDA 140.84, +7.06, +5.3%) is up 5.3%, pacing the group's advance after recording eight consecutive losses.

Treasuries sit a bit above their morning lows with the 10-yr yield up five basis points at 2.14%.

11:55 ET

Dow +422.01 at 25241.79, Nasdaq +150.99 at 7483.98, S&P +44.89 at 2789.34

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages continue to push higher with the S&P 500 up 1.7%, the Nasdaq up 2.1%, and the Dow up 1.7%. Contributing to today's bullish bias are supportive comments from Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters.

Mr. Powell said that the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion. Mr. Evans said the "fundamentals" of the economy remain in good footing and is open to a change in policy if necessary. There was no promise of a rate cut, but both did acknowledge concerns about low inflation.

Separately, shares of Box (BOX 16.61, -1.33) have dropped 7.4% after the company guided Q2 revenue below consensus and lowered its FY20 revenue below consensus. On a related note, the stock was downgraded to Hold from Buy at Canaccord Genuity with a price target of $16.

11:25 ET

Dow +419.65 at 25239.43, Nasdaq +137.40 at 7470.39, S&P +41.50 at 2785.95

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades near session highs with a gain of 1.5%. Most of the FAANG stocks that were indicated in potential antitrust probes yesterday have turned it around today.

Shares of Apple (AAPL 1748.91, +5.60) have bounced 3.2% after declining 1.0% yesterday. Amazon (AMZN 1715.83, +23.15, +1.4%) and Alphabet (GOOG 1046.54, +10.31, +1.0%) have recouped some of their losses, while Facebook (FB 163.74, -0.50, -0.3%) has succumbed to follow-through selling interest.

Separately, shares of Uber (UBER 41.84, +0.58) are up 1.6% after the stock was initiated with a Buy rating, or its equivalent thereof, by a host of firms.

10:55 ET

Dow +325.92 at 25145.7, Nasdaq +94.54 at 7427.53, S&P +29.79 at 2774.24

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 1.1% and is flirting with its 200-day moving average (2775).

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.3%) has been one of today's best-performing groups. Nearly all of its components are up and some have provided solid support for the S&P 500 information technology sector (+1.9%).

Retail stocks, too, have shown some strength, evident by 2.3% gain in the SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT 41.25, +0.95). Shares of Tiffany & Co (TIF 92.93, +2.76, +3.2%) have given the group a boost after the stock initially traded lower by more than 4% in pre-market action. Investors have since cozied up to its earnings beat.

10:30 ET

Dow +345.45 at 25165.23, Nasdaq +104.87 at 7437.86, S&P +34.33 at 2778.78

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities higher (-0.01% at 77.45 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is higher (+0.04% at 97.1800)Looking at energy:Jul WTI crude oil futures are now -$0.33 (-0.6%) at $52.92/barrelIn other energy, Jul natural gas is +$0.01 at $2.41/MMBtuMoving on to metals:June gold is currently +$1.75 at $1329.65/oz, while May silver is +$0.03 at $14.77/ozMay copper is now unch at $2.65/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2164/609. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2068/775.

10:00 ET

Dow +242.14 at 25061.92, Nasdaq +69.21 at 7402.2, S&P +23.72 at 2768.17

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.8%, and the Russell 2000 is up 1.3%. Fed Chair Powell recently said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, giving the market assurance that the Fed is on its side.

Just in, the Factory Orders report for April showed a decline of 0.8% (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%), and the March reading was revised to +1.3% (from +1.9%).

09:40 ET

Dow +232.30 at 25052.08, Nasdaq +63.13 at 7396.12, S&P +22.40 at 2766.85

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages begin the day in a rebound led by the cyclical sectors. The S&P 500 is up 0.8%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite is up 0.9%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows financials (+1.4%), information technology (+1.0%), and consumer discretionary (+1.0%) leading the rebound effort. The real estate (-0.3%) and utilities (-0.1%) sectors are the lone sectors in the red amid a rise in U.S. Treasury yields.

Demand for Treasuries has eased amid the positive disposition in equities. The 2-yr yield is up seven basis points to 1.90%, and the 10-yr yield is up four basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.1% to 97.27. WTI crude is down 0.3% to $53.08/bbl.

09:14 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +29.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +80.90.

Wall Street is set for a nice rebound at the open, as the S&P 500 futures trade 27 points, or 1.0%, above fair value.

There has been little-to-no progress in U.S.-China trade talks, but the market appears content for now that there is still a willingness for further talks. There is also a prevailing belief that the market was due for a rebound from short-term oversold conditions, especially considering that the broader market withstood the heavy tech sell-off yesterday.

U.S. Treasury yields have increased noticeably across the curve, as demand for Treasuries cools off. The 2-yr yield is up nine basis points to 1.92%, and the 10-yr yield is up five basis points to 2.13%. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.2% to 97.29.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +24.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +72.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 24 points, or 0.9%, above fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly lower note. Japan's Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi said that working-level trade talks will be held with officials from the U.S. between June 10 and June 11. The Reserve Bank of Australia lowered its cash rate by 25 bps to 1.25%. The move was anticipated by the market and there are expectations that at least one more cut will be made before the end of 2019. Australia's Treasurer Josh Frydenberg called on the country's big four banks to fully pass the rate cut onto consumers to stimulate the economy.

In economic data: Japan's Q1 Capital Spending +6.1% yr/yr (expected 2.6%; last 5.7%) South Korea's Q1 GDP -0.4% qtr/qtr (expected -0.3%; last 1.0%); +1.7% yr/yr (expected 1.8%; last 1.8%). May CPI +0.2% m/m (expected 0.3%; last 0.4%); +0.7% yr/yr (expected 0.8%; last 0.6%) Australia's Q1 Current Account deficit AUD2.90 bln (expected deficit of AUD2.50 bln; last deficit of AUD6.30 bln). April Retail Sales -0.1% m/m (expected 0.2%; last 0.3%) New Zealand's Q1 Export Prices -2.6% qtr/qtr (expected -1.5%; last -1.7%) and Q1 Import Prices -3.5% qtr/qtr (expected -2.5%; last 1.4%)

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: UNCH Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.5% China's Shanghai Composite: -1.0% India's Sensex: -0.5% South Korea's Kospi: UNCH Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.1%

Major European indices trade in the green. Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said he will offer his resignation if coalition parties stop cooperating. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini reportedly said that his party wants to press ahead with the current government. The unemployment rate in the eurozone declined to a decade low of 7.6%.

In economic data: Eurozone April Unemployment Rate 7.6% (expected 7.7%; last 7.7%). May CPI +1.2% yr/yr (expected 1.3%; last 1.7%) and May Core CPI +0.8% yr/yr (expected 1.0%; last 1.3%) U.K.'s May Construction PMI 48.6 (expected 50.5; last 50.5) France's April government budget balance -EUR67.20 bln (expected -EUR62.20 bln; last -EUR40.70 bln) Italy's April Unemployment Rate 10.2% (expected 10.3%; last 10.2%) Spain's May Unemployment Change -84,100 (expected -67,000; last -91,500)

08:28 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +23.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +66.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 24 points, or 0.9%, above fair value.

In U.S.-China trade news, China's Ministry of Commerce said on Tuesday it hopes the U.S. can meet half-way and stop the "wrong-doings." No further trade talks have been planned, but China has reiterated its willingness for further talks to resolve the dispute.

In an interview with CNBC, Chicago Fed President Charles Evans (FOMC Voter) said he was "content" with the current Fed policy but is worried about the persistently low inflation levels.

07:54 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +21.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +61.60.

The S&P 500 futures trade 22 points, or 0.8%, above fair value in a rebound from short-term oversold conditions. Likewise, the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 futures trade 0.9% above fair value after antitrust concerns sent big tech stocks reeling yesterday.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell will deliver opening remarks at the Monetary Policy Strategy, Tools, and Communication Practices Conference in Chicago at 9:55 a.m. ET. Several other Fed members are also expected to speak at the two-day conference, which the market hopes will give further insight about the possibility for a rate cut to address slowing growth and muted inflation.

On the data front, investors will receive Factory Orders for April (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%) at 10:00 a.m. ET.

U.S. Treasuries have cooled off amid the positive disposition in the futures trade, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield is up four basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield is up two basis points to 2.10%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.09. WTI crude is down 1.3% to $52.56/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Tiffany & Co (TIF 86.50, -3.67): -4.1% after missing revenue estimates, although it did beat earnings estimates. Uber (UBER 41.65, +0.40): +1.0% after getting initiated with positive coverage by many analysts on Wall Street. Box (BOX 14.99, -2.94): -16.4% after guiding Q2 revenue below consensus and lowering its FY20 revenue below consensus. Box, however, did beat earnings estimates and raised its FY20 EPS above consensus.Ventas (VTR 62.20, -1.55): -2.4% after the REIT company commenced a public offering of 11 million shares of common stock.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly lower note. 16:15 ET

Dow +4.74 at 24819.78, Nasdaq -120.13 at 7332.99, S&P -7.61 at 2744.45

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows.

The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.

Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.

These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.

Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.

On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation.

Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.

In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).

Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

urn:contentItem:60FP-SBJ1-JC8H-K0Y4-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 15:25 ET2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 15:25 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 27-Jul-20

The market at 15:25 ET

Dow: +93.49...

Nasdaq: +174.34... S&P: +23.33...

NYSE Vol: 457.3 mln.. Adv: 1748.. Dec: 1192

Nasdaq Vol: 3.5 bln.. Adv: 1872.. Dec: 1418

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

-- Stock market trades higher in front of busy news week-- U.S. dollar continues to weaken, gold futures keep rallying -- Strength in semiconductor space-- Investors await coronavirus relief bill later today

Strong: Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Communication Services, Materials

Weak: Financials, Energy, Utilities

15:25 ET

Dow +93.49 at 26563.38, Nasdaq +174.34 at 10537.6, S&P +23.33 at 3238.96

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is trading at session highs with a 0.7% gain.

One last look at the S&P 500 sectors shows information technology (+1.6%), materials (+1.2%), and consumer discretionary (+1.0%) sectors leading the market in gains, while the financials (-1.1%) and utilities (-1.7%) sectors head in the opposite direction.

WTI crude futures settled higher by $0.38 (+0.9%) to $41.68/bbl.

Dow -182.44 at 26469.89, Nasdaq -98.24 at 10363.26, S&P -20.03 at 3215.63

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market ended the week in negative territory in a mostly broad-based decline. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 underperformed with a 1.5% decline.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed lower, but the health care (-1.1%) and information technology (-1.2%) sectors were the only sectors to decline more than 1.0%. Note, the tech sector was down as much as 2.7% intraday, while the consumer discretionary sector gained 0.3% as shares of Amazon (AMZN 3008.91, +22.36, +0.8%) recovered an early 3.3% decline.

Intel (INTC 50.59, -9.81, -16.2%) did very little recovering, with shares falling 16% after the company announced a six-month delay in its next-generation 7nm chip technology. While disappointing for Intel investors, the news was welcomed by investors of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD 69.40, +9.83, +16.5%).

Other negative factors today included China ordering the U.S. to close its consulate in Chengdu in response to the U.S. ordering China to close its consulate in Houston and a delay in the Republican coronavirus relief bill until next week.

On a more positive note, new home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January.

In other corporate news, Goldman Sachs (GS 201.47, -1.66, -0.8%) settled its 1MDB case for $3.9 billion, Verizon (VZ 56.85, +1.00, +1.8%) beat top and bottom-line estimates, American Express (AXP 95.33, -1.34, -1.4%) reported mixed quarterly results, and Walt Disney (DIS 117.61, -0.51, -0.4%) reportedly delayed several blockbuster movies by a year.

U.S. Treasuries finished little changed. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield was flat at 0.58%. Gold futures rose 0.4% to $1897.50/ozt -- its highest settlement price ever amid continued weakness in the U.S. Dollar Index (94.39, -0.30, -0.3%). WTI crude futures settled little changed at $41.08/bbl.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

New home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January. On a yr/yr basis, new home sales were up 13.7%.The key takeaway from the report is that sales activity in the new home market is quite healthy given the tight supply of existing homes for sale, low mortgage rates, pent-up demand, and an emerging, coronavirus-driven shift by city dwellers to suburban settings.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June on Monday.
