16:20 ET

Dow -182.44 at 26469.89, Nasdaq -98.24 at 10363.26, S&P -20.03 at 3215.63

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market ended the week in negative territory in a mostly broad-based decline. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 underperformed with a 1.5% decline.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed lower, but the health care (-1.1%) and information technology (-1.2%) sectors were the only sectors to decline more than 1.0%. Note, the tech sector was down as much as 2.7% intraday, while the consumer discretionary sector gained 0.3% as shares of Amazon (AMZN 3008.91, +22.36, +0.8%) recovered an early 3.3% decline.

Intel (INTC 50.59, -9.81, -16.2%) did very little recovering, with shares falling 16% after the company announced a six-month delay in its next-generation 7nm chip technology. While disappointing for Intel investors, the news was welcomed by investors of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD 69.40, +9.83, +16.5%).

Other negative factors today included China ordering the U.S. to close its consulate in Chengdu in response to the U.S. ordering China to close its consulate in Houston and a delay in the Republican coronavirus relief bill until next week.

On a more positive note, new home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January.

In other corporate news, Goldman Sachs (GS 201.47, -1.66, -0.8%) settled its 1MDB case for $3.9 billion, Verizon (VZ 56.85, +1.00, +1.8%) beat top and bottom-line estimates, American Express (AXP 95.33, -1.34, -1.4%) reported mixed quarterly results, and Walt Disney (DIS 117.61, -0.51, -0.4%) reportedly delayed several blockbuster movies by a year.

U.S. Treasuries finished little changed. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield was flat at 0.58%. Gold futures rose 0.4% to $1897.50/ozt -- its highest settlement price ever amid continued weakness in the U.S. Dollar Index (94.39, -0.30, -0.3%). WTI crude futures settled little changed at $41.08/bbl.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

New home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January. On a yr/yr basis, new home sales were up 13.7%.The key takeaway from the report is that sales activity in the new home market is quite healthy given the tight supply of existing homes for sale, low mortgage rates, pent-up demand, and an emerging, coronavirus-driven shift by city dwellers to suburban settings.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June on Monday.

urn:contentItem:60FP-SBJ1-JC8H-K0Y6-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 27-Jul-20

The market at 16:15 ET

Dow: +114.88...

Nasdaq: +173.09... S&P: +23.78...

NYSE Vol: 790.0 mln.. Adv: 1769.. Dec: 1196

Nasdaq Vol: 4.1 bln.. Adv: 1932.. Dec: 1354

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

-- Stocks close near highs, mega-caps find renewed strength-- U.S. dollar continued to weaken, contributing to continued breakout in gold prices-- Positive start in front of busy news week

Strong: Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate

Weak: Financials, Utilities

16:15 ET

Dow +114.88 at 26584.77, Nasdaq +173.09 at 10536.35, S&P +23.78 at 3239.41

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 advanced 0.7% on Monday in a session that included renewed strength in the mega-cap stocks and continued weakness in the U.S. dollar. The Nasdaq Composite (+1.7%) and Russell 2000 (+1.2%) rose more than 1.0%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased just 0.4%.

Nine of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed higher, including the information technology (+1.6%), materials (+1.4%), and real estate (+1.1%) sectors at the top of the standings. The utilities (-1.3%) and financials (-0.8%) sectors were the lone holdouts.

Material stocks benefited from higher metal prices, including the continued breakout of gold ($1931.70/ozt, $34.20 +1.8%) amid a weakening U.S. Dollar Index (93.71, -0.72, -0.8%). The tech sector was lifted by mega-cap leadership and strong gains in the semiconductor space. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose 3.2%.

Amazon (AMZN 3055.21, +46.30, +1.5%), Apple (AAPL 379.24, +8.78, +2.4%), Alphabet (GOOG 1530.20, +18.33, +1.2%), and Facebook (FB 233.50, +2.79, +1.2%) outperformed in front of high-profile events this week. Specifically, the CEOs of these companies will testify before lawmakers on Wednesday regarding regulatory concerns, and the companies will report earnings on Thursday.

Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM 83.25, +9.35, +12.7%) stood out with a 12.7% gain amid speculation that Intel (INTC 49.57, -1.02, -2.0%) might order chips from the company to get around its internal production issues.

In other corporate news, Moderna (MRNA 79.91, +6.70, +9.2%) received an additional $472 million from the government to advance its COVID-19 vaccine candidate, Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 39.94, -0.67, -1.7%) announced its CEO will step down, and Hasbro (HAS 71.84, -5.75, -7.4%) missed top and bottom-line estimates.

Elsewhere, U.S. Treasuries finished little changed while investors continued to await the details of $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill from Republican Senators. The 2-yr yield was flat at 0.15%, and the 10-yr yield increased one basis point to 0.60%. WTI crude futures increased 0.9%, or $0.38, to $41.68/bbl.

Reviewing Monday's economic data:

Total durable goods orders increased 7.3% m/m in June (Briefing.com consensus 6.4%) following a downwardly revised 15.1% increase (from 15.8%) for May. Excluding transportation, orders jumped 3.3%, as expected, after a downwardly revised 3.6% increase (from 4.0%) for May. The key takeaway from the report is that business spending picked up in June, evidenced by a 3.3% increase in new orders for nondefense capital goods excluding aircraft. That came on top of a 1.6% increase in May.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for July and the S&P Case-Shiller Home Price Index for May on Tuesday.

Nasdaq Composite +17.4% YTDS&P 500 +0.3% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average -6.9% YTDRussell 2000 -11.0% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1769/1196. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1932/1354.

15:25 ET

Dow +93.49 at 26563.38, Nasdaq +174.34 at 10537.6, S&P +23.33 at 3238.96

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is trading at session highs with a 0.7% gain.

One last look at the S&P 500 sectors shows information technology (+1.6%), materials (+1.2%), and consumer discretionary (+1.0%) leading the market in gains, while the financials (-1.1%) and utilities (-1.7%) sectors head in the opposite direction.

WTI crude futures settled higher by $0.38 (+0.9%) to $41.68/bbl.

14:55 ET

Dow +31.45 at 26501.34, Nasdaq +135.58 at 10498.84, S&P +15.95 at 3231.58

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.5%, and the Russell 2000 is up 0.6%.

Within the financials sector (-1.0%), shares of JPMorgan Chase (JPM 96.50, -1.78, -1.8%), Bank of America (BAC 23.99, -0.37, -1.5%), and Wells Fargo (WFC 25.34, -0.93, -3.5%) are down noticeably, dragging the group lower. There's no confirmed catalyst causing the negative bias in the space.

Looking ahead, notable companies that will report earnings tomorrow morning include 3M (MMM 162.10, +2.26, +1.4%), Pfizer (PFE 37.60, -0.06, -0.2%), Raytheon Technologies (RTX 60.99, -1.09, -1.8%), and McDonald's (MCD 200.46, +1.74, +0.9%)

14:30 ET

Dow +65.79 at 26535.68, Nasdaq +149.01 at 10512.27, S&P +19.01 at 3234.64

[BRIEFING.COM] The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (+1.44%) pushed to new session highs in the last half hour with the S&P 500 (+0.59%) still firmly in second place.

S&P 500 constituents Alexion Pharma (ALXN 107.80, +6.31, +6.22%), KLA Corporation (KLAC 197.75, +9.54, +5.07%), and Weyerhaeuser (WY 27.35, +1.24, +4.75%) are outperforming. All three names are slated to report quarterly results in the next calendar week, while WY enjoys gains in tandem with paper/forest peers Int'l Paper (IP 36.61, +0.29, +0.80%), Rayonier (RYN 28.59, +0.89, +3.21%), and Louisiana-Pacific (LPX 31.97, +1.33, +4.34%).

Conversely, cruise line company Carnival (CCL 13.81, -0.99, -6.69%) sits near the bottom of the index as the industry is seeing continued weakness owing in part to continued COVID-19 case, death count increases across the globe.

14:00 ET

Dow +78.17 at 26548.06, Nasdaq +119.38 at 10482.64, S&P +17.43 at 3233.06

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have gently shifted off their levels from half an hour ago with the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (+1.15%) still in front.

Gold futures finished $33.50 higher (+1.8%) to $1,931.00/oz, its highest settlement price ever, helped in part by weakness in the dollar. To be sure, continued U.S./Sino geopolitical tensions and rising economic uncertainty have also helped fuel the yellow metal's rally to record highs.

The U.S. Dollar Index loses about 0.8% to 93.66.

13:30 ET

Dow +80.13 at 26550.02, Nasdaq +125.70 at 10488.96, S&P +18.40 at 3234.03

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages held their modestly higher bias in the last half hour with the DJIA (+0.30%) still holding the rear.

A look inside the Dow Jones Industrial Average shows that Dow (DOW 43.96, +1.35, +3.17%), Apple (AAPL 377.47, +7.01, +1.89%), and Merck (MRK 78.48, +1.38, +1.79%) are outperforming. Apple reports earnings this Thursday and Merck reports on Friday.

Conversely, jetliner manufacturer Boeing (BA 169.81, -3.95, -2.27%) sits at the bottom of the index after earlier reports that completed jets may be piling up at BA and competitor Airbus (EADSY 18.21, -0.39, -2.10%).

The DJIA now holds gains of 2.86% on the month.

13:00 ET

Dow +99.58 at 26569.47, Nasdaq +103.49 at 10466.75, S&P +15.68 at 3231.31

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market is trading higher in front of a busy week in news. The Nasdaq Composite has the advantage today with a 1.0% gain, followed by modest gains in the S&P 500 (+0.5%), Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.4%), and Russell 2000 (+0.3%).

Currently, eight of the 11 S&P 500 sectors are trading higher, led by the materials (+1.1%) and information technology (+1.1%) sectors with 1.0% gains. Conversely, the utilities (-1.4%), financials (-0.7%), and energy (-0.5%) sectors trade lower.

Material stocks are outperforming amid higher metal prices, as the U.S. dollar (93.68, -0.76, -0.8%) continues to weaken against commodities and foreign currencies. Gold futures ($1929.60/ozt, +32.10, +1.7%) are trading at fresh all-time highs.

In the semiconductor space, shares of Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM 82.03, +8.13, +11.0%) have rallied 11% on speculation that Intel (INTC 50.19, -0.39, -0.8%) might order chips from the company to get around its internal production issues. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.7%.

As for upcoming news, investors are waiting for Senate Republicans to unveil a reported $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill some time today.

Later this week, the FOMC will begin a two-day policy meeting on Tuesday, the CEOs of Amazon (AMZN 3042.62, +32.72, +1.1%), Apple (AAPL 375.51, +32.38, +1.1%), Alphabet (GOOG 1525.00, +13.13, +0.9%), and Facebook (FB 231.86, +1.19, +0.5%) will address regulatory concerns with lawmakers on Wednesday, and each of these companies will report earnings on Thursday.

Separately, notable laggards within the S&P 500 include Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 39.93, -0.58, -1.4%), which said its CEO is stepping down, and Hasbro (HAS 72.47, -5.19, -6.7%), which missed top and bottom-line estimates.

Today's lone economic report was Durable Goods Orders for June:

Total durable goods orders increased 7.3% m/m in June (Briefing.com consensus 6.4%) following a downwardly revised 15.1% increase (from 15.8%) for May. Excluding transportation, orders jumped 3.3%, as expected, after a downwardly revised 3.6% increase (from 4.0%) for May.The key takeaway from the report is that business spending picked up in June, evidenced by a 3.3% increase in new orders for nondefense capital goods excluding aircraft. That came on top of a 1.6% increase in May. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1633/1266. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1776/1503.

12:25 ET

Dow +73.85 at 26543.74, Nasdaq +86.76 at 10450.02, S&P +12.19 at 3227.82

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.4%, and the Nasdaq is up 0.9%.

Looking at the FAANG stocks shows green across the board. Apple (AAPL 375.81, +5.35, +1.5%), Amazon (AMZN 3046.04, +37.13, +1.2%), and Netflix (NFLX 487.57, +7.12, +1.5%) are up more than 1.0%, followed by Alphabet (GOOG 1522.29, +10.42, +0.7%) and Facebook (FB 232.25, +1.39, +0.6%).

Overseas, the major European indices closed mostly lower. Germany's DAX was flat, UK's FTSE declined 0.3%, and France's CAC declined 0.3%. The Europe Stoxx 600 fell 0.3%.

11:55 ET

Dow +79.05 at 26548.94, Nasdaq +80.31 at 10443.57, S&P +11.80 at 3227.43

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is trading off session highs with a 0.3% gain. The Dow is up 0.3%, and the Nasdaq is up 0.8%.

Shares of DraftKings (DKNG 34.03, -3.52, -9.4%) have dropped 9% after the two MLB games scheduled for today were postponed due to coronavirus cases. DKNG shares were up 27% in the last nine trading sessions.

Updating coronavirus relief talks, the Washington Post is reporting that Senate Republicans are advocating for cutting the weekly emergency unemployment benefits to $200/week from $600/week, until a more complicated system is able to replace lost wages by 70%.

11:25 ET

Dow +78.16 at 26548.05, Nasdaq +80.53 at 10443.79, S&P +12.23 at 3227.86

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.5% amid gains in eight of the 11 S&P 500 sectors. Semiconductor stocks have been an area of strength today.

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.4%, predominately due to the 11% gain in shares of Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM 81.83, +7.92, +10.7%) on speculation that Intel (INTC 50.07, -0.52, -1.0%) might be ordering chips from TSM to get around its internal production issues.

Elsewhere, material stocks are having a great day, too, amid higher metal prices. Shares of Newmont Goldcorp (NEM 69.72, +2.97, +4.5%) are up 4.5%, as gold prices ($1935.00, +37.60, +2.0%) trade at fresh all-time highs at the expense of a weak dollar (93.51, -0.92, -1.0%).

10:55 ET

Dow +134.52 at 26604.41, Nasdaq +122.97 at 10486.23, S&P +20.07 at 3235.7

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade near session highs with a 0.6% gain. Today's advance comes in front of a jam-packed week of news.

Later today, Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill, so stay tuned for that. On Wednesday, the FOMC will release its latest policy directive and CEOs from some of the largest tech companies will testify before Congress regarding antitrust concerns.

Apple (AAPL 377.36, +6.87, +1.8%), Amazon (AMZN 3065.75, +56.84, +1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1529.04, +17.17, +1.1%) will then report earnings after Thursday's close.

10:25 ET

Dow +136.82 at 26606.71, Nasdaq +118.71 at 10481.97, S&P +18.93 at 3234.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade higher by 0.6%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.

In corporate news, Moderna (MRNA 77.40, +4.19, +5.7%) announced it will receive an additional $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate. MRNA shares are up 5%.

Separately, shares of Hasbro (HAS 72.55, -5.04, -6.5%) are down 6.5% after the company missed top and bottom-line estimates.

10:00 ET

Dow +106.38 at 26576.27, Nasdaq +135.54 at 10498.8, S&P +18.20 at 3233.83

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is now up 0.6%, as the materials (+1.2%) and health care (+0.5%) sectors join the the mega-cap rally.

Apple (AAPL 377.94, +7.49, +2.0%) and Amazon (AMZN 3081.12, +73.98, +2.4%) are up 2.0% after the stocks spent the last two weeks in consolidation mode. On a related note, AAPL had its price target raised to $425 from $365 at JP Morgan, and AMZN had its price target raised to $3600 from $2800 at Telsey Advisory Group.

Separately, shares of Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 39.63, -0.88, -2.1%) are down 2% amid news that CEO Stefano Pessina will step down from the helm.

09:40 ET

Dow -30.93 at 26438.96, Nasdaq +93.21 at 10456.47, S&P +3.31 at 3218.94

[BRIEFING.COM] The major indices start the day mixed, with the Nasdaq Composite outperforming with a 0.9% gain. The S&P 500 is up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.1%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows mixed results. The information technology (+0.7%), consumer discretionary (+0.6%), and communication services (+0.4%) sectors are among the early leaders amid relative strength in the mega-caps, while the financials (-1.2%) and energy (-1.1%) sectors are down more than 1.0%.

U.S. Treasuries trade near their flat lines. The 2-yr yield is flat at 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. Gold futures ($1928.30, +30.80, +1.7%) are trading above $1900/ozt, benefiting from a weak dollar (93.77, -0.67, -0.7%). WTI crude is down 0.9% to $40.93/bbl.

09:12 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +10.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +83.00.

The stock market is headed for a slightly higher start, as the S&P 500 futures trade 11 points, or 0.3%, above fair value ahead of an eventful week.

Apple (AAPL 374.94, +4.48, +1.2%), Amazon (AMZN 3063.98, +55.07, +1.8%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1524.00, +12.13, +0.8%) outperform in pre-market action ahead of their earnings reports on Thursday. There will be plenty of action before Thursday, though.

Senate Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill today, the FOMC will begin a two-day policy meeting on Tuesday, and the CEOs to some of the largest tech companies will head to Capitol Hill on Wednesday to address regulatory concerns.

08:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +67.50.

The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, above fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. U.S. officials entered the Chinese consulate in Houston shortly after the passage of Friday's deadline that was given to the Chinese diplomatic mission. China responded by seizing the U.S. consulate in Chengdu this morning. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor, Christopher Kent, said that the RBA is not considering new policy measures at this time.

In economic data: China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%) Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%) Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). June Imports -7.1% m/m (last -12.3%) and Exports -1.3% m/m (last -7.4%)

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: -0.2% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3% India's Sensex: -0.5% South Korea's Kospi: +0.8% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%

Major European indices trade in negative territory. Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

In economic data: Eurozone's June loans to non-financial corporations 7.1% yr/yr (last 7.3%) and M3 Money Supply 9.2% yr/yr (expected 9.3%; last 8.9%) Germany's July ifo Business Climate Index 90.5 (expected 89.3; last 86.3). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6) France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.4% Germany's DAX: -0.2%U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.4% France's CAC 40: -0.5% Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.7% Spain's IBEX 35: -1.8%

08:32 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +12.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +81.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.4%, above fair value.

Durable goods orders increased 7.3% in June (Briefing.com consensus +6.4%), and the prior month's increase was revised to 15.1% (from 15.8%). Excluding transportation, durable orders increased 3.3% (Briefing.com consensus +3.3%) to follow the prior month's revised 3.6% increase (from 4.0%).

07:56 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +14.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +99.60.

The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, above fair value to start the week, as investors await the coronavirus relief bill negotiated by the White House and Senate Republicans.

Reports indicate the bill will cost about $1 trillion, significantly less than what Democrats want, while Politico reported that GOP lawmakers intend on releasing the bill around 4:30 p.m. ET today, which would be after today's close. Related headlines could be announced throughout the day.

Separately, the mega-cap technology stocks are providing solid support for the futures trade after two straight weeks of mega-cap consolidation. On a related note, several of these big tech CEOs will testify before Congress on Wednesday regarding antitrust concerns.

On the data front, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June (Briefing.com consensus 6.4%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.

U.S. Treasuries trade little changed, while precious metals have extended their recent rally amid continued weakness in the dollar (93.78, -0.66, -0.7%). Gold futures are up 2.1% to $1937.40/ozt. The 2-yr yield is up one basis point to 0.15%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $41.43/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Moderna (MRNA 79.37, +6.16): +8.4% after being awarded up to $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate.Amazon (AMZN 3059.00, +50.09): +1.7% amid today's mega-cap gains. On a related note, Telsey Advisory Group raised its AMZN price target to $3600 from $2800.Hasbro (HAS 74.00, -3.59): -4.6% after missing top and bottom-line estimates.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei: -0.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4%, China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3%, India's Sensex: -0.5%, South Korea's Kospi: +0.8%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%.In economic data:China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%)Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%)Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). 07:00 ET

16:20 ET

Dow -182.44 at 26469.89, Nasdaq -98.24 at 10363.26, S&P -20.03 at 3215.63

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market ended the week in negative territory in a mostly broad-based decline. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 underperformed with a 1.5% decline.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed lower, but the health care (-1.1%) and information technology (-1.2%) sectors were the only sectors to decline more than 1.0%. Note, the tech sector was down as much as 2.7% intraday, while the consumer discretionary sector gained 0.3% as shares of Amazon (AMZN 3008.91, +22.36, +0.8%) recovered an early 3.3% decline.

Intel (INTC 50.59, -9.81, -16.2%) did very little recovering, with shares falling 16% after the company announced a six-month delay in its next-generation 7nm chip technology. While disappointing for Intel investors, the news was welcomed by investors of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD 69.40, +9.83, +16.5%).

Other negative factors today included China ordering the U.S. to close its consulate in Chengdu in response to the U.S. ordering China to close its consulate in Houston and a delay in the Republican coronavirus relief bill until next week.

On a more positive note, new home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January.

In other corporate news, Goldman Sachs (GS 201.47, -1.66, -0.8%) settled its 1MDB case for $3.9 billion, Verizon (VZ 56.85, +1.00, +1.8%) beat top and bottom-line estimates, American Express (AXP 95.33, -1.34, -1.4%) reported mixed quarterly results, and Walt Disney (DIS 117.61, -0.51, -0.4%) reportedly delayed several blockbuster movies by a year.

U.S. Treasuries finished little changed. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield was flat at 0.58%. Gold futures rose 0.4% to $1897.50/ozt -- its highest settlement price ever amid continued weakness in the U.S. Dollar Index (94.39, -0.30, -0.3%). WTI crude futures settled little changed at $41.08/bbl.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

New home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January. On a yr/yr basis, new home sales were up 13.7%.The key takeaway from the report is that sales activity in the new home market is quite healthy given the tight supply of existing homes for sale, low mortgage rates, pent-up demand, and an emerging, coronavirus-driven shift by city dwellers to suburban settings.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5W85-17M1-DYRK-920G-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 03-Jun-19

The market at 16:15 ET

Dow: +4.74...

Nasdaq: -120.13... S&P: -7.61...

NYSE Vol: 982.7 mln.. Adv: 1860.. Dec: 990

Nasdaq Vol: 2.5 bln.. Adv: 1654.. Dec: 1418

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Shares of Alphabet (GOOG), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), and Apple (AAPL) drop on antitrust and regulatory concerns ISM Manufacturing Index for May disappointsLingering trade and growth concerns

Strong: Energy, Materials, Health Care, Industrials

Weak: Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Utilities

16:15 ET

Dow +4.74 at 24819.78, Nasdaq -120.13 at 7332.99, S&P -7.61 at 2744.45

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows.

The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.

Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.

These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.

Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.

On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation.

Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.

In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).

Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

Nasdaq Composite +10.5% YTDS&P 500 +9.5% YTDRussell 2000 +8.9% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +6.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1860/990. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1654/1418.

15:45 ET

Dow -102.77 at 24712.27, Nasdaq -153.73 at 7299.39, S&P -20.61 at 2731.45

[BRIEFING.COM] Crude Oil futures closed at a four-month low as concerns over demand and global growth stem from trade disruptions. The Saudis said they will continue to work to avoid oversupply. July crude oil settled $0.25 lower (0.5%) to $53.25/barrel.

July Natural Gas settled $0.05 lower (-2.3%) at $2.403/MMBtu.

Precious metals rose as they tend to do in a flight to safety. June gold futures broke out to a four-month high, settling the session $16.90 higher (+1.3%) at $1322.70/oz. July silver settled $0.173 higher (+1.2%) at $14.74/oz.

Dow -354.84 at 24815.04, Nasdaq -114.57 at 7453.12, S&P -36.80 at 2752.06

[BRIEFING.COM] U.S. stocks, Treasury yields, and oil prices all dropped on Friday after President Trump surprised the market by threatening to impose a 5% tariff rate on all goods imported from Mexico. Friday's 1.3% decline in the S&P 500 sent it below its 200-day moving average (2776) and extended its weekly decline to 2.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (-1.4%), the Nasdaq Composite (-1.5%), and the Russell 2000 (-1.4%) extended their weekly losses to 3.0%, 2.4%, and 3.2%.

The 5% tariff rate will go into effect on June 10 and will increase incrementally during the summer to reach 25% on Oct. 1. The White House could remove these tariffs altogether if Mexico makes a concerted effort to curb the flow of undocumented migrants entering the U.S.

The news catalyzed de-risking efforts, leading to eight of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finishing with losses over 1.0%. The utilities (+0.5%) and real estate (+0.8%) sectors finished higher amid a steep drop in U.S. Treasury yields.

Another trade dispute on top of a U.S.-China trade war with no clear end in sight fueled ongoing concerns that trade tensions will lower economic, and earnings, growth prospects.

China added to these fears after it announced that it is drafting a list of unreliable foreign entities that harm the interests of its firms, increasing speculation about Chinese retaliation against the U.S. On a related note, China's manufacturing sector slipped into contraction in May.

Global growth concerns were transparent by the 5.2% drop in WTI crude ($53.48/bbl, -$2.92) and by investors seeking safety in a crowded U.S. Treasury market. The 2-yr yield dropped 12 basis points to 1.94%, and the 10-yr yield dropped nine basis points to 2.14%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.4% to 97.76.

In corporate news, shares of General Motors (GM 33.34, -1.48, -4.3%) underperformed on the Mexico tariff threat. Dell Technologies (DELL 59.55, -6.86, -10.3%), Gap (GPS 18.68, -1.92, -9.3%), and VMware (VMW 176.98, -14.11, -7.4%) disappointed investors with their earnings results, while Uber (UBER 40.41, +0.61, +1.5%) pleased investors with its results.

Reviewing Friday's economic data, which included Personal Income and Spending data for April, the PCE Price Index for April, the final University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment for May, and the Chicago PMI for April:

Personal income increased 0.5% in April (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) on top of a 0.1% increase in March. Personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%) on top of an upwardly revised 1.1% increase (from 0.9%) in March. The PCE Price Index was up 0.3% m/m, as expected, while the core PCE Price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, as expected.The key takeaway from the report is that real PCE was unchanged in April. That will be another data point that leads to forecasts calling for much slower real GDP growth in the second quarter than the 3.1% real GDP growth seen in the first quarter.The final May reading for the University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment checked in at 100.0 (Briefing.com consensus 101.5) versus the preliminary reading of 97.2.The key takeaway from the report was the acknowledgment that "confidence significantly eroded in the last two weeks of May" on account of concerns about the tariff actions.The Chicago PMI for May increased to 54.2 from 52.6 in April.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5W85-17K1-JC8H-K55H-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 03-Jun-19

The market at 16:15 ET

Dow: +4.74...

Nasdaq: -120.13... S&P: -7.61...

NYSE Vol: 982.7 mln.. Adv: 1860.. Dec: 990

Nasdaq Vol: 2.5 bln.. Adv: 1654.. Dec: 1418

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Shares of Alphabet (GOOG), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), and Apple (AAPL) drop on antitrust and regulatory concerns ISM Manufacturing Index for May disappointsLingering trade and growth concerns

Strong: Energy, Materials, Health Care, Industrials

Weak: Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Utilities

16:15 ET

Dow +4.74 at 24819.78, Nasdaq -120.13 at 7332.99, S&P -7.61 at 2744.45

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows.

The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.

Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.

These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.

Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.

On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation.

Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.

In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).

Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

Nasdaq Composite +10.5% YTDS&P 500 +9.5% YTDRussell 2000 +8.9% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +6.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1860/990. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1654/1418.

15:45 ET

Dow -102.77 at 24712.27, Nasdaq -153.73 at 7299.39, S&P -20.61 at 2731.45

[BRIEFING.COM] Crude Oil futures closed at a four-month low as concerns over demand and global growth stem from trade disruptions. The Saudis said they will continue to work to avoid oversupply. July crude oil settled $0.25 lower (0.5%) to $53.25/barrel.

July Natural Gas settled $0.05 lower (-2.3%) at $2.403/MMBtu.

Precious metals rose as they tend to do in a flight to safety. June gold futures broke out to a four-month high, settling the session $16.90 higher (+1.3%) at $1322.70/oz. July silver settled $0.173 higher (+1.2%) at $14.74/oz.

14:55 ET

Dow -54.18 at 24760.86, Nasdaq -121.43 at 7331.69, S&P -12.96 at 2739.1

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.5%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.

Apple (AAPL 172.45, -2.61, -1.5%) has been a new drag on the market after it joined the list of companies comprising of Facebook (FB 164.30, -13.30, -7.4%), Alphabet (GOOG 1030.25, -73.85, -6.7%), and Amazon (AMZN 1685.29, -89.66, -5.1%) today that have been singled out in antitrust investigation reports.

Reuters reported that Apple could be subject to a probe by the Department of Justice as part of a broader review of the tech giants' practices. Apple's weakness has sent contributed to the 1.8% decline in the information technology sector.

14:30 ET

Dow +25.06 at 24840.1, Nasdaq -98.27 at 7354.85, S&P -4.88 at 2747.18

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have drifted somewhat higher in the last 30 minutes with the Dow Jones Industrial Average returning to positive territory, while the Nasdaq Composite still sports losses north of 1.3%, and the S&P 500 nearing breakeven at -0.2%.

Action within the S&P 500 is mostly higher with about 75% of the components in the index showing gains, led by names like Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR 34.76, +3.44, +10.98%) which gains on an ASCO update, Capri Holdings (CPRI 34.45, +1.97, +6.07%) which recoups the majority of losses from the last few days following an insider purchase by the CEO & PVH (PVH 89.21, +4.02, +4.72%) which moves higher after announcing a Calvin Klein deal with G-III (GIII 25.95, +0.22, +0.86%) in the U.S. and Canada.

Conversely, declines from blue chip names like Centene (CNC 53.00, -4.75, -8.23%), Facebook (FB 165.41, -12.06, -6.80%) & Alphabet (GOOG 1,032.27, -71.36, -6.47%) rein in what should otherwise be a higher affair.

14:00 ET

Dow -1.74 at 24813.3, Nasdaq -110.51 at 7342.61, S&P -12.27 at 2739.79

[BRIEFING.COM] After an initial pop higher following comments from St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC voter) the broader market returned to its modestly lower move with the Dow Jones Industrial Average now back in negative territory.

Gold futures settled 1.3% higher on Monday at $1,327.90/oz, their best levels since February, as ongoing global trade tensions pushed investors toward bonds and precious metals.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index slips -0.5% at 97.30, near session lows at this point.

13:30 ET

Dow +52.04 at 24867.08, Nasdaq -79.17 at 7373.95, S&P -2.45 at 2749.61

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages were holding a negative move as of the last few minutes, but comments from the Saint Louis Fed President James Bullard that a rate cut may be warranted soon in order to lift inflation provided a modest lift.

The modestly lower move, ahead of the commentary from the last half hour, in the Dow Jones Industrial Average is helped by weakness in names like Microsoft (MSFT 120.61, -3.07, -2.48%), UnitedHealth (UNH 237.83, -3.97, -1.64%) & Visa (V 158.69, -2.64, -1.64%) being offset by equally decent gains at the top of the index.

Verizon (VZ 55.66, +1.31, +2.41%) takes top marks in the DJIA today with Chevron (CVX 115.41, +1.56, +1.37%) and NIKE (NKE 78.10, +0.96, +1.24%) close behind.

The DJIA scoots into positive territory in the last half hour after being down as much as 0.45% this morning.

13:00 ET

Dow -27.77 at 24787.27, Nasdaq -96.21 at 7356.91, S&P -14.44 at 2737.62

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is down 0.4%, as familiar trade and growth concerns suppress investor sentiment while heightened regulatory concerns send shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1030.72, -72.91, -6.6%), Facebook (FB 164.37, -13.10, -7.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1030.45, -77.87, -4.4%) noticeably lower. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Russell 2000 is down 0.3%.

The steep losses in these widely-held shares have contributed to the underperformance in the Nasdaq Composite (-1.3%), and the S&P 500 communication services (-3.2%) and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. Reports indicate that Alphabet, Facebook, and Amazon are facing new antitrust and regulatory threats from the Department of Justice and/or the Federal Trade Commission.

The broader market, meanwhile, has been digesting disappointing manufacturing PMI data from around the world and China blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks. The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), which was its lowest since October 2016.

In turn, the confluence of trade, growth, and regulatory concerns has outweighed early calls that the market was due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. The S&P 500 materials (+1.7%), energy (+0.7%), and consumer staples (+0.6%) sectors, however, have provided some offsetting support.

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+0.8%) has also been a notable standout, helped by the 24.8% gain in shares of Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.21, +4.38). Germany's Infineon said it will acquire the company for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85/share, in cash. The offer represents a 34% premium from CY's Friday closing price.

Nevertheless, investors remain steadfast in buying U.S. Treasuries amid the negativity and uncertainty in the market. Increased demand has pushed the 2-yr yield down six basis points to 1.88% and the 10-yr yield down three basis points to 2.11%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.3% to 97.46.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1669/1147. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1441/1537.

12:25 ET

Dow -52.21 at 24762.83, Nasdaq -98.60 at 7354.52, S&P -12.68 at 2739.38

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has descended to near session lows with a loss of 0.5%, as the widely-held FAANG stocks underperform.

Outside from Apple (AAPL 175.53, +0.43, +0.3%), Facebook (FB 164.97, -12.47, -7.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1699.05, -76.34, -4.3%), Alphabet (GOOG 1035.94, -67.67, -6.2%), and Netflix (NFLX 336.10, -7.18, -2.1%) have taken a hit. Facebook, Alphabet, and Amazon have all been singled out by separate reports that they are facing new antitrust threats.

Separately, shares of Tesla (TSLA 180.44, -4.47) have dropped another 2.6%, as the stock continues to be pressured by demand and manufacturing concerns. The Drive reported that Tesla failed to secure air quality permits for new production lines as it ramped up its Model 3 production.

11:55 ET

Dow +13.97 at 24829.01, Nasdaq -51.85 at 7401.27, S&P -1.54 at 2750.52

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.1%. Investors weren't too convinced by the bounce back into positive territory earlier, considering the persistent flight for safety in the U.S. Treasury market.

The 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.89%, and the 10-yr yield is down two basis points to 2.12%. At its low, the 2-yr yield touched 1.84%, which was also reflective of growing expectations for the Fed to cut rates to combat a slower growth environment.

Manufacturing PMI data around the world, including the U.S., showed slowing or flat growth for the month of May.

Overseas, the major European indices closed on a higher note. Germany's DAX gained 0.6%, UK's FTSE gained 0.4%, and France's CAC gained 0.7%. The Europe Stoxx 600 advanced 0.2%.

11:25 ET

Dow +54.28 at 24869.32, Nasdaq -29.43 at 7423.69, S&P +4.30 at 2756.36

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have experienced some volatility as the market tries to balance growth concerns with calls that the market is due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. The S&P 500 is up 0.1%, the Dow is up 0.2%, and the Nasdaq is down 0.4%.

Apple (AAPL 176.92, +1.85, +1.1%) has shown relative strength today ahead of its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, which will kick off at 1:00 p.m. ET. The company is expected to update its software products.

In other corporate news, shares of Centene (CNC 52.38, -5.38) have dropped 9.3% after Humana (HUM 252.06, +7.20, +2.9%) said it will not make a competing bid for the company. Boeing (BA 336.40, -5.14, -1.5%) notified the FAA of improperly manufactured parts on the 737 Max and 737 NG.

10:55 ET

Dow +75.38 at 24890.42, Nasdaq -35.81 at 7417.31, S&P +6.41 at 2758.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has climbed back into positive territory with a gain of 0.3% despite the lingering trade and growth concerns.

Shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1034.03, -69.60, -6.3%), though, have been a huge drag on the broader market after The Wall Street Journal cited sources stating that the Department of Justice is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google. Shares of Facebook (FB 170.49, -6.98, -3.9%) and Amazon (AMZN 1718.48, -56.59, -3.2%) have also undereperformed on antitrust worries.

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.0%) has shown some strength today, bolstered by the 24.6% gain in shares of Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.19, +4.38). Germany's Infineon Technologies (IFNNY) said it will acquire the company for $23.85/share, or $10.1 billion, in cash.

10:00 ET

Dow -76.80 at 24738.24, Nasdaq -71.45 at 7381.67, S&P -10.44 at 2741.62

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has reversed course and now trades lower by 0.4%.

Just in, the ISM Manufacturing Index for May decreased to 52.1 (Briefing.com consensus 56.2) from an unrevised reading of 52.8 in April.

Separately, construction spending came in flat for April (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%). March's reading was revised to +0.1% from -0.9%.

09:40 ET

Dow +72.03 at 24887.07, Nasdaq +0.40 at 7453.52, S&P +6.67 at 2758.73

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages begin the day on a mixed note after trading lower in pre-market action. The S&P 500 is up 0.3%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite is down 0.1%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows health care (+0.8%), energy (+0.8%), and information technology (+0.6%) leading the broader market higher. The communication services sector (-1.4%) has been dragged lower by shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1052.74, -50.96, -4.6%), as the Department of Justice reportedly prepares an antitrust investigation on Google.

Demand for U.S. Treasuries remains strong, driving yields even lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.89%, and the 10-yr yield is down three basis points to 2.11%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.2% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 1.5% to $54.30/bbl.

09:14 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -4.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -23.50.

Wall Street is on pace for a slightly lower start to begin the week, as the S&P 500 futures trade four points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Disappointing manufacturing PMI data out of Europe and Asia, coupled with China blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, has contributed to today's negative disposition. The trade and growth narrative remains the same, but given the lack of good news, investors have adopted a cautious tone in front of the first trading day of June.

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May (Briefing.com consensus 52.6), which will be released at 10:00 a.m. ET, will give investors a better feel for the economic environment in the U.S.

Investors continue to seek safety in U.S. Treasuries, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield is down five basis points to 1.89%, and the 10-yr yield is down two basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.2% to 97.60. WTI crude is up 2.1% to $54.59/bbl.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -4.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -25.50.

The S&P 500 futures trade five points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region started the week on a mixed, and cautious, note with trade worries hanging like a wet blanket on investors. Lots of attention this morning on a White Paper out of China that places blame on U.S. for the negotiations unraveling. Nothing particularly new there, although the paper reasserts China isn't going to compromise on its key principles, which adds to sense this trade dispute could persist for some time. The increased tariff rate on the $200 billion tranche of Chinese exports to the U.S. and the $60 billion tranche of U.S. exports to China went into effect June 1. Separately, the U.S. has ended India's designation as a beneficiary developing nation, which means it is likely to lose ability to exports products to U.S. without tariffs. Manufacturing PMI data out of the region, including China's Caixin Manufacturing PMI, reflected softer growth environment in May.

In economic data: China's May Caixin Manufacturing PMI 50.2 (expected 50.0; last 50.2) Japan's May Manufacturing PMI 49.8 (expected 49.6; last 49.6); Capital Spending 6.1% yr/yr (expected 2.6%; last 5.7%)Australia's May Manufacturing PMI 51.0 (expected 51.1; last 50.9)South Korea's May Nikkei Manufacturing PMI 48.4 (expected 49.5; last 50.2)

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: -0.9% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.03% China's Shanghai Composite: -0.3% India's Sensex: +1.4% South Korea's Kospi: +1.3% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: -1.3%

Major European indices are starting the week on a cautious note, pinned down by growth concerns that stem from trade worries and a batch of manufacturing PMI data for May that was roundly disappointing and reflective of relatively weak manufacturing activity. Political matters are garnering some increased attention today with President Trump making an official state visit to the UK, German SPD Leader Nahles announcing her resignation, and Italy standing its ground with EU over budget matters and specter of disciplinary action. Separately, Germany's Infineon announced ~$10 billion cash deal to acquire U.S.-based Cypress Semiconductor (CY).

In economic data: Eurozone's revised May Manufacturing PMI 47.7 (expected 47.7; last 47.7)Germany's revised May Manufacturing PMI 44.3 (expected 44.3; last 44.3)France's revised May Manufacturing PMI 50.6 (expected 50.6; last 50.6)Italy's May Manufacturing PMI 49.7 (expected 49.7 (expected 48.6; last 49.1)Spain's May Manufacturing PMI 50.1 (expected 51.3; last 51.8)UK's May Manufacturing PMI 49.4 (expected 52.0; last 53.1)Switzerland's May CPI 0.3% m/m (expected 0.3%; last 0.2%); May CPI 0.6% yr/yr (expected 0.6%; last 0.7%)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.3% Germany's DAX: -0.1% U.K.'s FTSE 100: unchFrance's CAC 40: unchItaly's FTSE MIB: -0.1% Spain's IBEX 35: -0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -8.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -36.50.

The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value. The benchmark index holds a yearly gain of 9.8% as it enters the first trading session of the month.

Reviewing the S&P 500 sector standings for the year shows real estate (+17.0%), information technology (+15.7%), and communication services (+13.5%) as the best-performing groups in 2019. Conversely, the health care (+0.6%), energy (+1.9%), and materials (+4.0%) sectors underperform.

Despite the negative disposition in the futures trade amid the familiar slowing growth narrative, investors haven't shown too much interest in hedging against further downside. The CBOE Volatility Index (18.74, +0.03, +0.2%) is up fractionally.

07:58 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -8.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -36.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value as investors follow through on last month's efforts to de-risk from trade and growth concerns.

Regarding the U.S.-China trade front, China published a white paper on Sunday blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks. Although it was not entirely surprising, the news continues to support the market's view that the trade dispute will not be over soon.

Separately, manufacturing PMI data out of Europe and Asia indicated slower or flat growth last month, adding to the concerns that slower economic growth will lead to lower earnings prospects.

In U.S. data, investors will receive the ISM Manufacturing Index for May (Briefing.com consensus 52.6) and Construction Spending for April (Briefing.com consensus 0.4%) at 10:00 a.m. ET. Auto and truck sales will be released throughout the day.

Persisting trade and growth concerns have also heightened the flight for safety in U.S. Treasuries, driving yields even lower across the curve.

The 2-yr yield is down seven basis points to 1.87%, and the 10-yr yield is down three basis points to 2.11%. The noticeable drop in the 2-yr yield is also reflective of the market's view that the Fed may cut rates to address slower growth. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64. WTI crude is up 1.5% to $54.32/bbl after falling nearly 9% last week on concerns that slower growth will weaken demand.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Alphabet (GOOG 1072.00, -31.63): -2.9% after The Wall Street Journal indicated sources that said the Department of Justice is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google.Boeing (BA 336.94, -4.67): -1.4% after the company notified the FAA of improperly manufactured parts on the 737 MAX and 737 NG. Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.30, +4.48): +25.1% after Germany's Infineon Technologies (IFNNY) said it will acquire the company for $23.85/share, or $10.1 billion, in cash.Apple (AAPL 174.62, -0.45): -0.3% ahead of its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC).

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region started the week on a mixed, and cautious, note with trade worries hanging like a wet blanket on investors. Japan's Nikkei -0.9%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng -0.03%, China's Shanghai Composite -0.3%, India's Sensex +1.4%, South Korea's Kospi +1.3%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries -1.3%.In economic data:China's May Caixin Manufacturing PMI 50.2 (expected 50.0; last 50.2)Japan's May Manufacturing PMI 49.8 (expected 49.6; last 49.6); Capital Spending 6.1% yr/yr (expected 2.6%; last 5.7%)Australia's May Manufacturing PMI 51.0 (expected 51.1; last 50.9)South Korea's May Nikkei Manufacturing PMI 48.4 (expected 49.5; last 50.2)In news:Lots of attention this morning on a White Paper out of China that places blame on U.S. for the negotiations unraveling. Nothing particularly new there, although the paper reasserts China isn't going to compromise on its key principles, which adds to sense this trade dispute could persist for some time.The increased tariff rate on the $200 billion tranche of Chinese exports to the U.S. and the $60 billion tranche of U.S. exports to China went into effect June 1. Separately, the U.S. has ended India's designation as a beneficiary developing nation, which means it is likely to lose ability to exports products to U.S. without tariffs.Manufacturing PMI data out of the region, including China's Caixin Manufacturing PMI, reflected softer growth environment in May.Major European indices are starting the week on a cautious note. STOXX Europe 600 -0.3%, Germany's DAX -0.2%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -0.3%, France's CAC 40 -0.2%, Italy's FTSE MIB -0.3%, Spain's IBEX 35 -0.5%.In economic data:Eurozone's revised May Manufacturing PMI 47.7 (expected 47.7; last 47.7)Germany's revised May Manufacturing PMI 44.3 (expected 44.3; last 44.3)France's revised May Manufacturing PMI 50.6 (expected 50.6; last 50.6)Italy's May Manufacturing PMI 49.7 (expected 49.7 (expected 48.6; last 49.1)Spain's May Manufacturing PMI 50.1 (expected 51.3; last 51.8)UK's May Manufacturing PMI 49.4 (expected 52.0; last 53.1)In news:Growth concerns have stemmed from trade worries and a batch of manufacturing PMI data for May that was roundly disappointing and reflective of relatively weak manufacturing activity.Political matters are garnering some increased attention today with President Trump making an official state visit to the UK, German SPD Leader Nahles announcing her resignation, and Italy standing its ground with EU over budget matters and specter of disciplinary action. Germany's Infineon announced ~$10 billion cash deal to acquire U.S.-based Cypress Semiconductor (CY).

16:15 ET

Dow -354.84 at 24815.04, Nasdaq -114.57 at 7453.12, S&P -36.80 at 2752.06

[BRIEFING.COM] U.S. stocks, Treasury yields, and oil prices all dropped on Friday after President Trump surprised the market by threatening to impose a 5% tariff rate on all goods imported from Mexico. Friday's 1.3% decline in the S&P 500 sent it below its 200-day moving average (2776) and extended its weekly decline to 2.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (-1.4%), the Nasdaq Composite (-1.5%), and the Russell 2000 (-1.4%) extended their weekly losses to 3.0%, 2.4%, and 3.2%.

The 5% tariff rate will go into effect on June 10 and will increase incrementally during the summer to reach 25% on Oct. 1. The White House could remove these tariffs altogether if Mexico makes a concerted effort to curb the flow of undocumented migrants entering the U.S.

The news catalyzed de-risking efforts, leading to eight of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finishing with losses over 1.0%. The utilities (+0.5%) and real estate (+0.8%) sectors finished higher amid a steep drop in U.S. Treasury yields.

Another trade dispute on top of a U.S.-China trade war with no clear end in sight fueled ongoing concerns that trade tensions will lower economic, and earnings, growth prospects.

China added to these fears after it announced that it is drafting a list of unreliable foreign entities that harm the interests of its firms, increasing speculation about Chinese retaliation against the U.S. On a related note, China's manufacturing sector slipped into contraction in May.

Global growth concerns were transparent by the 5.2% drop in WTI crude ($53.48/bbl, -$2.92) and by investors seeking safety in a crowded U.S. Treasury market. The 2-yr yield dropped 12 basis points to 1.94%, and the 10-yr yield dropped nine basis points to 2.14%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.4% to 97.76.

In corporate news, shares of General Motors (GM 33.34, -1.48, -4.3%) underperformed on the Mexico tariff threat. Dell Technologies (DELL 59.55, -6.86, -10.3%), Gap (GPS 18.68, -1.92, -9.3%), and VMware (VMW 176.98, -14.11, -7.4%) disappointed investors with their earnings results, while Uber (UBER 40.41, +0.61, +1.5%) pleased investors with its results.

Reviewing Friday's economic data, which included Personal Income and Spending data for April, the PCE Price Index for April, the final University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment for May, and the Chicago PMI for April:

Personal income increased 0.5% in April (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) on top of a 0.1% increase in March. Personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%) on top of an upwardly revised 1.1% increase (from 0.9%) in March. The PCE Price Index was up 0.3% m/m, as expected, while the core PCE Price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, as expected.The key takeaway from the report is that real PCE was unchanged in April. That will be another data point that leads to forecasts calling for much slower real GDP growth in the second quarter than the 3.1% real GDP growth seen in the first quarter.The final May reading for the University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment checked in at 100.0 (Briefing.com consensus 101.5) versus the preliminary reading of 97.2.The key takeaway from the report was the acknowledgment that "confidence significantly eroded in the last two weeks of May" on account of concerns about the tariff actions.The Chicago PMI for May increased to 54.2 from 52.6 in April.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5W85-17M1-DYRK-920H-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:15 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 03-Jun-19

The market at 16:15 ET

Dow: +4.74...

Nasdaq: -120.13... S&P: -7.61...

NYSE Vol: 982.7 mln.. Adv: 1860.. Dec: 990

Nasdaq Vol: 2.5 bln.. Adv: 1654.. Dec: 1418

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Shares of Alphabet (GOOG), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), and Apple (AAPL) drop on antitrust and regulatory concerns ISM Manufacturing Index for May disappoints; global PMI data also showed slower or flat growthLingering trade and growth concerns underpin strength in TreasuriesGrowing expectations for the Fed to cut rates to address slower growth and muted inflation; 2-yr yield drops 12 basis points to 1.83%

Strong: Energy, Materials, Health Care, Industrials

Weak: Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Utilities

16:15 ET

Dow +4.74 at 24819.78, Nasdaq -120.13 at 7332.99, S&P -7.61 at 2744.45

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows.

The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.

Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.

These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.

Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.

On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation.

Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.

In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).

Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

Nasdaq Composite +10.5% YTDS&P 500 +9.5% YTDRussell 2000 +9.0% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +6.4% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1860/990. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1654/1418.

15:45 ET

Dow -102.77 at 24712.27, Nasdaq -153.73 at 7299.39, S&P -20.61 at 2731.45

[BRIEFING.COM] Crude Oil futures closed at a four-month low as concerns over demand and global growth stem from trade disruptions. The Saudis said they will continue to work to avoid oversupply. July crude oil settled $0.25 lower (0.5%) to $53.25/barrel.

July Natural Gas settled $0.05 lower (-2.3%) at $2.403/MMBtu.

Precious metals rose as they tend to do in a flight to safety. June gold futures broke out to a four-month high, settling the session $16.90 higher (+1.3%) at $1322.70/oz. July silver settled $0.173 higher (+1.2%) at $14.74/oz.

14:55 ET

Dow -54.18 at 24760.86, Nasdaq -121.43 at 7331.69, S&P -12.96 at 2739.1

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades lower by 0.5%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.

Apple (AAPL 172.45, -2.61, -1.5%) has been a new drag on the market after it joined the list of companies comprising of Facebook (FB 164.30, -13.30, -7.4%), Alphabet (GOOG 1030.25, -73.85, -6.7%), and Amazon (AMZN 1685.29, -89.66, -5.1%) today that have been singled out in antitrust investigation reports.

Reuters reported that Apple could be subject to a probe by the Department of Justice as part of a broader review of the tech giants' practices. Apple's weakness has sent contributed to the 1.8% decline in the information technology sector.

14:30 ET

Dow +25.06 at 24840.1, Nasdaq -98.27 at 7354.85, S&P -4.88 at 2747.18

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have drifted somewhat higher in the last 30 minutes with the Dow Jones Industrial Average returning to positive territory, while the Nasdaq Composite still sports losses north of 1.3%, and the S&P 500 nearing breakeven at -0.2%.

13:00 ET

Dow -27.77 at 24787.27, Nasdaq -96.21 at 7356.91, S&P -14.44 at 2737.62

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is down 0.4%, as familiar trade and growth concerns suppress investor sentiment while heightened regulatory concerns send shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1030.72, -72.91, -6.6%), Facebook (FB 164.37, -13.10, -7.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1030.45, -77.87, -4.4%) noticeably lower. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.2%, and the Russell 2000 is down 0.3%.

The steep losses in these widely-held shares have contributed to the underperformance in the Nasdaq Composite (-1.3%), and the S&P 500 communication services (-3.2%) and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. Reports indicate that Alphabet, Facebook, and Amazon are facing new antitrust and regulatory threats from the Department of Justice and/or the Federal Trade Commission.

The broader market, meanwhile, has been digesting disappointing manufacturing PMI data from around the world and China blaming the U.S. for the setback in trade talks. The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), which was its lowest since October 2016.

In turn, the confluence of trade, growth, and regulatory concerns has outweighed early calls that the market was due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. The S&P 500 materials (+1.7%), energy (+0.7%), and consumer staples (+0.6%) sectors, however, have provided some offsetting support.

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+0.8%) has also been a notable standout, helped by the 24.8% gain in shares of Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.21, +4.38). Germany's Infineon said it will acquire the company for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85/share, in cash. The offer represents a 34% premium from CY's Friday closing price.

Nevertheless, investors remain steadfast in buying U.S. Treasuries amid the negativity and uncertainty in the market. Increased demand has pushed the 2-yr yield down six basis points to 1.88% and the 10-yr yield down three basis points to 2.11%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.3% to 97.46.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1669/1147. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1441/1537.

16:15 ET

Dow -354.84 at 24815.04, Nasdaq -114.57 at 7453.12, S&P -36.80 at 2752.06

[BRIEFING.COM] U.S. stocks, Treasury yields, and oil prices all dropped on Friday after President Trump surprised the market by threatening to impose a 5% tariff rate on all goods imported from Mexico. Friday's 1.3% decline in the S&P 500 sent it below its 200-day moving average (2776) and extended its weekly decline to 2.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (-1.4%), the Nasdaq Composite (-1.5%), and the Russell 2000 (-1.4%) extended their weekly losses to 3.0%, 2.4%, and 3.2%.

The 5% tariff rate will go into effect on June 10 and will increase incrementally during the summer to reach 25% on Oct. 1. The White House could remove these tariffs altogether if Mexico makes a concerted effort to curb the flow of undocumented migrants entering the U.S.

The news catalyzed de-risking efforts, leading to eight of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finishing with losses over 1.0%. The utilities (+0.5%) and real estate (+0.8%) sectors finished higher amid a steep drop in U.S. Treasury yields.

Another trade dispute on top of a U.S.-China trade war with no clear end in sight fueled ongoing concerns that trade tensions will lower economic, and earnings, growth prospects.

China added to these fears after it announced that it is drafting a list of unreliable foreign entities that harm the interests of its firms, increasing speculation about Chinese retaliation against the U.S. On a related note, China's manufacturing sector slipped into contraction in May.

Global growth concerns were transparent by the 5.2% drop in WTI crude ($53.48/bbl, -$2.92) and by investors seeking safety in a crowded U.S. Treasury market. The 2-yr yield dropped 12 basis points to 1.94%, and the 10-yr yield dropped nine basis points to 2.14%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.4% to 97.76.

In corporate news, shares of General Motors (GM 33.34, -1.48, -4.3%) underperformed on the Mexico tariff threat. Dell Technologies (DELL 59.55, -6.86, -10.3%), Gap (GPS 18.68, -1.92, -9.3%), and VMware (VMW 176.98, -14.11, -7.4%) disappointed investors with their earnings results, while Uber (UBER 40.41, +0.61, +1.5%) pleased investors with its results.

Reviewing Friday's economic data, which included Personal Income and Spending data for April, the PCE Price Index for April, the final University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment for May, and the Chicago PMI for April:

Personal income increased 0.5% in April (Briefing.com consensus 0.3%) on top of a 0.1% increase in March. Personal spending rose 0.3% (Briefing.com consensus 0.2%) on top of an upwardly revised 1.1% increase (from 0.9%) in March. The PCE Price Index was up 0.3% m/m, as expected, while the core PCE Price Index, which excludes food and energy, jumped 0.2%, as expected.The key takeaway from the report is that real PCE was unchanged in April. That will be another data point that leads to forecasts calling for much slower real GDP growth in the second quarter than the 3.1% real GDP growth seen in the first quarter.The final May reading for the University of Michigan Index of Consumer Sentiment checked in at 100.0 (Briefing.com consensus 101.5) versus the preliminary reading of 97.2.The key takeaway from the report was the acknowledgment that "confidence significantly eroded in the last two weeks of May" on account of concerns about the tariff actions.The Chicago PMI for May increased to 54.2 from 52.6 in April.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April on Monday.
