urn:contentItem:5WN1-HKS1-DYRK-9497-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 16:25 ET

Dow: -79.22...

Nasdaq: +70.10... S&P: +14.09...

NYSE Vol: 777.5 mln.. Adv: 2119.. Dec: 784

Nasdaq Vol: 1.9 bln.. Adv: 2197.. Dec: 878

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite set new record highsSemiconductor stocks soar following positive earnings results from Texas Instruments (TXN)Caterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA) disappoint on earnings, guidanceDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities, Consumer Staples

16:25 ET

Dow -79.22 at 27269.97, Nasdaq +70.10 at 8321.51, S&P +14.09 at 3019.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 (+0.5%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.9%) set new record highs on Wednesday, boosted by out-sized gains in the semiconductor stocks and by shares of companies that beat earnings estimates. The Russell 2000 rose 1.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, however, lost 0.3% amid noticeable losses in Boeing (BA 361.43, -11.54, -3.1%) and Caterpillar (CAT 131.91, -6.19, -4.5%) following disappointing earnings reports.

Today's advance was forged in the afternoon, as the market began to shake off several early concerns and instead rally around the host of companies that did provide good earnings news. Some of those concerns included the Department of Justice announcing a probe into the "market-leading online platforms," the weaker-than-expected eurozone flash manufacturing PMI for July, and Caterpillar lowering its full-year EPS guidance.

Notable earnings-related gainers included Visa (V 183.33, +2.43, +1.3%), UPS (UPS 114.39, +9.12, +8.7%), Texas Instruments (TXN 129.00, +8.93, +7.4%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 342.97, +18.98, +5.9%), ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 777.96, +38.36, +5.2%), and Snap (SNAP 17.61, +2.78, +18.8%). The market's ability to find support in these companies was encouraging for investors worried about market leadership being too concentrated among a handful of tech giants.

The S&P 500 communication services (+0.9%) and financials (+0.9%) sectors were the day's best-performing sectors. Semiconductor stocks had a field day, rallying on Texas Instruments' solid results. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index advanced 3.1%, boosting its year-to-date gain to a staggering 40%.

Conversely, the consumer staples (-0.6%), real estate (-0.1%), and materials (-0.02%) sectors finished lower.

Separately, for most of the day, the DoJ regulatory threat weighed on shares of Facebook (FB 204.66, +2.30, +1.1%), Amazon (AMZN 2000.81, +6.32, +0.3%), Alphabet (GOOG 1137.81, -8.40, -0.7%), and Apple (AAPL 208.67, -0.17, -0.1%). The FTC also confirmed that Facebook will pay a $5 billion fine for its privacy mishaps, but the stock still rallied heading into its earnings report after the close.

Although the probe added to the uncertainty facing these companies, the positive mood in the market helped shares recoup a bulk of their early losses. In addition, the fact that interest rates remain low should remain a positive consideration for risk assets.

U.S. Treasury yields finished lower on Wednesday. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 1.82%, and the 10-yr yield declined two basis points to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index was unchanged at 97.72. WTI crude lost 1.4% to $55.93/bbl.

Reviewing Wednesday's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June, the weekly Initial and Continuing claims report, and the Advance reports for International Trade in Goods, Retail Inventories, and Wholesale Inventories for June on Thursday.

Nasdaq Composite +25.4% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.9% YTDRussell 2000 +17.2% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2119/784. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2197/878.

15:30 ET

Dow -100.36 at 27248.83, Nasdaq +65.54 at 8316.95, S&P +11.61 at 3017.08

[BRIEFING.COM] Metals Settlement Prices:Aug gold settled today's session $1.90 higher (+0.1%) at $1423.60/ozSept silver settled today's session $0.15 higher (+0.1%) at $16.63/ozSept copper settled $0.01 higher (+0.3%) at $2.71/lbAgriculture Settlement Prices:Sept corn settled $0.03 lower at $4.22/bushelSept wheat settled $0.10 higher at $4.97/bushelAug soybeans settled $0.03 higher at $8.89/bushelEnergy Settlement Prices:Aug Crude Oil futures fell $0.79 (-1.4%) to $55.93/barrelAug Natural Gas settled $0.07 lower (-3.0%) at $2.21/MMBtuAug RBOB Gasoline settled $0.01 lower (-0.4%) at $1.81/gallonAug Heating oil futures settled unch at $1.92/gallon ..NYSE Adv/Dec 799/1.5 bln. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2163/860.

14:55 ET

Dow -108.23 at 27240.96, Nasdaq +45.13 at 8296.54, S&P +8.58 at 3014.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.3%, nearing its all-time high, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.2%. The Nasdaq Composite (+0.5%) is currently trading at its all-time intraday high.

Today's advance has been concentrated among the cyclical sectors -- financials (+0.7%), industrials (+0.5%), information technology (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer discretionary (+0.3%). The communication services sector (+0.7%) has been another leader as investors buy the dip in Netflix (NFLX 319.42, +12.12, +4.0%).

Looking ahead, notable companies that will report earnings after today's close include Facebook (FB 203.19, +0.83, +0.4%), Ford Motor (F 10.32, +0.15, +1.4%), PayPal (PYPL 120.77, +0.55, +0.5%), and Tesla (TSLA 262.65, +2.48, +1.0%).

14:30 ET

Dow -118.60 at 27230.59, Nasdaq +37.92 at 8289.33, S&P +6.95 at 3012.42

[BRIEFING.COM] Both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite notched session highs in the last half hour, up 0.23% and 0.46%, respectively.

Positive action in the S&P 500 is led by earnings movers like Discover Financial Services (DFS 92.13, +7.65, +9.06%), Edwards Lifesciences (EW 211.97, +16.51, +8.45%), and Grainger (GWW 301.54, +22.76, +8.16%).

Conversely, Rollins (ROL 34.35, -3.80, -9.96%) sits at the bottom of the index in light of this morning's in-line Q2 results.

14:00 ET

Dow -124.98 at 27224.21, Nasdaq +31.96 at 8283.37, S&P +4.50 at 3009.97

[BRIEFING.COM] Again, the major averages have held their lines in the last half hour with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite still within shouting distance of session highs.

Gold futures gave up most of their morning advance though still settled 0.1% higher to $1,423.60/oz on Wednesday in view of this morning's less than stellar Manufacturing PMI reading.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index has traded mostly sideways today, down less than 0.1% at the moment to 97.66.

13:30 ET

Dow -116.45 at 27232.74, Nasdaq +32.39 at 8283.8, S&P +4.58 at 3010.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages sit little changed in the last half hour with the Dow Jones Industrial Average still in a hole, down about 116 points now.

Aside from the widely-covered losses from Dow Jones Industrial Average components Boeing (BA 362.35, -10.72, -2.87%) & Caterpillar (CAT 131.93, -6.127, -4.47%) shares of UnitedHealth (UNH 252.51, -2.50, -0.98%), Procter & Gamble (PG 112.73, -1.12, -0.98%), and Pfizer (PFE 42.68, -0.41, -0.95%) sit modestly lower.

Conversely, semiconductor giant Intel (INTC 52.72, +0.97, +1.87%) sits atop the index due in part to broader strength in tech and chips.

The DJIA gives back almost all of yesterday's decently higher session, now 0.29% higher on the week.

Elsewhere, at the top of the hour, the Treasury's $41 bln 5-year note auction drew a high yield of 1.824% on a bid-to-cover of 2.26.

12:55 ET

Dow -116.01 at 27233.18, Nasdaq +31.88 at 8283.29, S&P +3.92 at 3009.39

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market trades mixed today. Strong gains in the semiconductor stocks have contributed to the positive disposition in the S&P 500 (+0.1%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.4%), but noticeable losses in shares of Boeing (BA 363.44, -9.60, -2.6%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.34, -5.77, -4.2%) have pressured the Dow Jones Industrial Average (-0.4%).

Outside of Caterpillar, which missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance, earnings results have continued to come in mostly better than expected. Boeing beat estimates, but its struggles remain company-specific.

UPS (UPS 113.27, +8.00, +7.6%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 338.16, +14.17, +4.4%), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 785.79, +46.19, +6.3%), and Texas Instruments (TXN 129.13, +9.06, +7.4%) are some of today's biggest earnings gainers. Visa (V 180.68, -0.22, -0.1%) beat estimates and raised guidance, but reaction has been muted.

Texas Instruments' report has spurred big gains in the semiconductor stocks, many of which are contributing to the leadership of the S&P 500 information technology sector (+0.5%) and Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.9%). Still, losses in five of the 11 S&P 500 sectors, including consumer staples (-0.7%), have kept the broader market in check.

The market is also missing the influential leadership from some of its largest tech companies, which are currently holding modest losses after the Department of Justice announced an antitrust review into the "market-leading online platforms."

Big-tech scrutiny is nothing new, but it does show legitimate efforts to oversee the influence of market leaders like Facebook (FB 201.40, -0.94, -0.5%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.50, -2.99, -0.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1133.77, -12.44, -1.1%), and Apple (AAPL 208.13, -0.70, -0.3%). On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1949/905. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1963/986.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HMD1-JC8H-K18V-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 16:25 ET

Dow: -79.22...

Nasdaq: +70.10... S&P: +14.09...

NYSE Vol: 777.5 mln.. Adv: 2119.. Dec: 784

Nasdaq Vol: 1.9 bln.. Adv: 2197.. Dec: 878

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite push to all-time highs; cyclical sectors outperformRelative strength in UPS (UPS) and the semiconductor stocks following upbeat earnings resultsCaterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA) disappoint on earnings, guidanceDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities, Consumer Staples

16:25 ET

Dow -79.22 at 27269.97, Nasdaq +70.10 at 8321.51, S&P +14.09 at 3019.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 (+0.5%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.9%) set new records highs on Wednesday, boosted by out-sized gains in the semiconductor stocks and by shares of companies that beat earnings estimates. The Russell 2000 rose 1.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, however, lost 0.3% amid noticeable losses in Boeing (BA 361.43, -11.54, -3.1%) and Caterpillar (CAT 131.91, -6.19, -4.5%) following disappointing earnings reports.

Today's advance was forged in the afternoon, as the market began to shake off several early concerns and instead rally around the host of companies that did provide good earnings news. Some of those concerns included the Department of Justice announcing a probe into the "market-leading online platforms," the weaker-than-expected eurozone flash manufacturing PMI for July, and Caterpillar lowering its full-year EPS guidance.

Notable earnings-related gainers included Visa (V 183.33, +2.43, +1.3%), UPS (UPS 114.39, +9.12, +8.7%), Texas Instruments (TXN 129.00, +8.93, +7.4%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 342.97, +18.98, +5.9%), ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 777.96, +38.36, +5.2%), and Snap (SNAP 17.61, +2.78, +18.8%). The market's ability to find support in these companies was encouraging for investors worried about market leadership being too concentrated among a handful of tech giants.

The S&P 500 communication services (+0.9%) and financials (+0.9%) sectors were the day's best-performing sectors. Semiconductor stocks had a field day, rallying on Texas Instruments' solid results. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index advanced 3.1%, boosting its year-to-date gain to a staggering 40%.

Conversely, the consumer staples (-0.6%), real estate (-0.1%), and materials (-0.02%) sectors finished lower.

Separately, for most of the day, the DoJ regulatory threat weighed on shares of Facebook (FB 204.66, +2.30, +1.1%), Amazon (AMZN 2000.81, +6.32, +0.3%), Alphabet (GOOG 1137.81, -8.40, -0.7%), and Apple (AAPL 208.67, -0.17, -0.1%). The FTC also confirmed that Facebook will pay a $5 billion fine for its privacy mishaps, but the stock still rallied heading into its earnings report after the close.

Although the probe added to the uncertainty facing these companies, the positive mood in the market helped shares recoup a bulk of their early losses. In addition, the fact that interest rates remain low should remain a positive consideration for risk assets.

U.S. Treasury yields finished lower on Wednesday. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 1.82%, and the 10-yr yield declined two basis points to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index was unchanged at 97.72. WTI crude lost 1.4% to $55.93/bbl.

Reviewing Wednesday's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June, the weekly Initial and Continuing claims report, and the Advance reports for International Trade in Goods, Retail Inventories, and Wholesale Inventories for June on Thursday.

Nasdaq Composite +25.4% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.9% YTDRussell 2000 +17.2% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2119/784. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2197/878.

15:30 ET

Dow -100.36 at 27248.83, Nasdaq +65.54 at 8316.95, S&P +11.61 at 3017.08

[BRIEFING.COM] Metals Settlement Prices:Aug gold settled today's session $1.90 higher (+0.1%) at $1423.60/ozSept silver settled today's session $0.15 higher (+0.1%) at $16.63/ozSept copper settled $0.01 higher (+0.3%) at $2.71/lbAgriculture Settlement Prices:Sept corn settled $0.03 lower at $4.22/bushelSept wheat settled $0.10 higher at $4.97/bushelAug soybeans settled $0.03 higher at $8.89/bushelEnergy Settlement Prices:Aug Crude Oil futures fell $0.79 (-1.4%) to $55.93/barrelAug Natural Gas settled $0.07 lower (-3.0%) at $2.21/MMBtuAug RBOB Gasoline settled $0.01 lower (-0.4%) at $1.81/gallonAug Heating oil futures settled unch at $1.92/gallon ..NYSE Adv/Dec 799/1.5 bln. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2163/860.

14:55 ET

Dow -108.23 at 27240.96, Nasdaq +45.13 at 8296.54, S&P +8.58 at 3014.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.3%, nearing its all-time high, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.2%. The Nasdaq Composite (+0.5%) is currently trading at its all-time intraday high.

Today's advance has been concentrated among the cyclical sectors -- financials (+0.7%), industrials (+0.5%), information technology (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer discretionary (+0.3%). The communication services sector (+0.7%) has been another leader as investors buy the dip in Netflix (NFLX 319.42, +12.12, +4.0%).

Looking ahead, notable companies that will report earnings after today's close include Facebook (FB 203.19, +0.83, +0.4%), Ford Motor (F 10.32, +0.15, +1.4%), PayPal (PYPL 120.77, +0.55, +0.5%), and Tesla (TSLA 262.65, +2.48, +1.0%).

14:30 ET

Dow -118.60 at 27230.59, Nasdaq +37.92 at 8289.33, S&P +6.95 at 3012.42

[BRIEFING.COM] Both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite notched session highs in the last half hour, up 0.23% and 0.46%, respectively.

Positive action in the S&P 500 is led by earnings movers like Discover Financial Services (DFS 92.13, +7.65, +9.06%), Edwards Lifesciences (EW 211.97, +16.51, +8.45%), and Grainger (GWW 301.54, +22.76, +8.16%).

Conversely, Rollins (ROL 34.35, -3.80, -9.96%) sits at the bottom of the index in light of this morning's in-line Q2 results.

14:00 ET

Dow -124.98 at 27224.21, Nasdaq +31.96 at 8283.37, S&P +4.50 at 3009.97

[BRIEFING.COM] Again, the major averages have held their lines in the last half hour with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite still within shouting distance of session highs.

Gold futures gave up most of their morning advance though still settled 0.1% higher to $1,423.60/oz on Wednesday in view of this morning's less than stellar Manufacturing PMI reading.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index has traded mostly sideways today, down less than 0.1% at the moment to 97.66.

13:30 ET

Dow -116.45 at 27232.74, Nasdaq +32.39 at 8283.8, S&P +4.58 at 3010.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages sit little changed in the last half hour with the Dow Jones Industrial Average still in a hole, down about 116 points now.

Aside from the widely-covered losses from Dow Jones Industrial Average components Boeing (BA 362.35, -10.72, -2.87%) & Caterpillar (CAT 131.93, -6.127, -4.47%) shares of UnitedHealth (UNH 252.51, -2.50, -0.98%), Procter & Gamble (PG 112.73, -1.12, -0.98%), and Pfizer (PFE 42.68, -0.41, -0.95%) sit modestly lower.

Conversely, semiconductor giant Intel (INTC 52.72, +0.97, +1.87%) sits atop the index due in part to broader strength in tech and chips.

The DJIA gives back almost all of yesterday's decently higher session, now 0.29% higher on the week.

Elsewhere, at the top of the hour, the Treasury's $41 bln 5-year note auction drew a high yield of 1.824% on a bid-to-cover of 2.26.

12:55 ET

Dow -116.01 at 27233.18, Nasdaq +31.88 at 8283.29, S&P +3.92 at 3009.39

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market trades mixed today. Strong gains in the semiconductor stocks have contributed to the positive disposition in the S&P 500 (+0.1%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.4%), but noticeable losses in shares of Boeing (BA 363.44, -9.60, -2.6%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.34, -5.77, -4.2%) have pressured the Dow Jones Industrial Average (-0.4%).

Outside of Caterpillar, which missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance, earnings results have continued to come in mostly better than expected. Boeing beat estimates, but its struggles remain company-specific.

UPS (UPS 113.27, +8.00, +7.6%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 338.16, +14.17, +4.4%), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 785.79, +46.19, +6.3%), and Texas Instruments (TXN 129.13, +9.06, +7.4%) are some of today's biggest earnings gainers. Visa (V 180.68, -0.22, -0.1%) beat estimates and raised guidance, but reaction has been muted.

Texas Instruments' report has spurred big gains in the semiconductor stocks, many of which are contributing to the leadership of the S&P 500 information technology sector (+0.5%) and Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.9%). Still, losses in five of the 11 S&P 500 sectors, including consumer staples (-0.7%), have kept the broader market in check.

The market is also missing the influential leadership from some of its largest tech companies, which are currently holding modest losses after the Department of Justice announced an antitrust review into the "market-leading online platforms."

Big-tech scrutiny is nothing new, but it does show legitimate efforts to oversee the influence of market leaders like Facebook (FB 201.40, -0.94, -0.5%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.50, -2.99, -0.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1133.77, -12.44, -1.1%), and Apple (AAPL 208.13, -0.70, -0.3%). On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1949/905. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1963/986.

12:25 ET

Dow -124.36 at 27224.83, Nasdaq +22.75 at 8274.16, S&P +1.41 at 3006.88

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades just above its flat line, holding steady above the 3000 level. The Nasdaq outperforms with a gain of 0.3%, while the Dow trades lower by 0.4%.

Looking at the FAANG stocks shows Netflix (NFLX 314.65, +7.39, +2.4%) finally receiving some reprieve after disappointing investors last week. Conversely, Facebook (FB 201.71, -0.65, -0.4%), Apple (AAPL 207.95, -0.89, -0.4%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.43, -3.06, -0.2%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1135.29, -10.92, -1.0%) remain in the red amid the regulatory overhang from the DoJ.

Overseas, the major European indices closed mixed. Germany's DAX increased 0.3%, UK's FTSE lost 0.7%, and France's CAC lost 0.2%. The Europe Stoxx 600 increased 0.1%.

12:00 ET

Dow -139.91 at 27209.28, Nasdaq +14.27 at 8265.68, S&P +0.26 at 3005.73

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market remains mixed, but strikingly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.8%) has advanced to its best levels of the session. That move has been instrumental in lending support to the broader market.

One can sense, however, that selling activity in the broader market might pick up some steam if the semiconductor shares start to roll over, so this will be a closely-watched area as the day progresses.

Overall, there aren't any standout moves from a sector standpoint. Six sectors are up, and five sectors are down, with the performance range spanning -0.5% (health care) to +0.3% (energy).

Separately, Treasuries continue to hold modest gains, with yields down one to three basis points in maturities ranging from the 2-yr note to the 30-yr bond.

11:25 ET

Dow -129.99 at 27219.2, Nasdaq +7.03 at 8258.44, S&P -1.62 at 3003.85

[BRIEFING.COM] It's currently a mixed market with six S&P 500 sectors trading lower and five sectors trading higher. The benchmark index currently trades just below its flat line.

The flattish disposition isn't too bad considering the negative tone in the market prior to the open. Some of that negativity stemmed from weakening manufacturing flash PMI readings out of Europe, the DoJ antitrust probe into the largest online companies, and disappointing guidance from Caterpillar (CAT 132.69, -5.37, -3.9%).

These are legitimate points for investors to be concerned about, but the fact that earnings have come in mostly better than expected has been a positive consideration. The outperformance of the S&P 500 energy sector (+0.8%) amid higher oil prices ($57.08, -$0.30, -0.5%) has also been an area of support for the broader market.

10:55 ET

Dow -135.83 at 27213.36, Nasdaq -11.98 at 8239.43, S&P +1.62 at 3007.09

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher 0.1% after beginning the day on a lower note. The outperformance in several industrial companies and the semiconductor stocks has contributed to the positive disposition.

Like the broader market, the industrials sector (+0.3%) began the day lower amid weakness in shares of Boeing (BA 367.34, -5.69, -1.5%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.38, -5.67, -4.1%) after disappointing investors with results and/or guidance. UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.73, +8.3%) and Northrop Grumman (NOC 337.20, +13.22, +4.1%), however, have provided strong support for the sector after pleasing investors with their results.

Similarly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.5%, rising on the back of solid results from Texas Instruments (TXN 127.99, +7.92, +6.6%). The PHLX is now up a staggering 40% this year.

10:40 ET

Dow -64.20 at 27284.99, Nasdaq +23.24 at 8274.65, S&P +5.19 at 3010.66

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are higher (+0.5% at 79.92 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is lower (-0.1% at 97.6160)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.75 (+1.3%) at $57.52/barrelEIA petroleum data for the week ended July 19- huge draw in oilCrude oil inventories had a draw of 10.8 mln from the prior weekPrior week showed a draw of 3.1 mlnGasoline Inventories had a draw of 0.2 mln barrelPrior week had a build of 3.6 mln barrelDistillate Inventories had a build of 0.6 mlnPrior week had a build of 5.7 mlnEIA reported U.S. oil production fell 700K barrels per day (bpd) to 11.3 mln bpd, a massive reduction. Recent storm Barry plays some part in the reported data, but this really does seem to be a huge reduction..In other energy, Aug natural gas is -$0.06 (-2.5%) at $2.24/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$2.85 (+0.2%) at $1424.55/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.13 (+0.8%) at $16.61/ozSept copper is now +$0.02 (+0.6%) at $2.72/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1800/911. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1719/1095.

10:00 ET

Dow -80.60 at 27268.59, Nasdaq +3.12 at 8254.53, S&P +0.18 at 3005.65

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has marched back to its flat line, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.1%.

Just in, New Home Sales in June hit an annualized rate of 646,000, coming in below the Briefing.com consensus of 660,000. The May reading was revised to 604,000 (from 626,000).

09:45 ET

Dow -139.01 at 27210.18, Nasdaq -6.58 at 8244.83, S&P -2.97 at 3002.5

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market begins the day modestly lower amid weakness in Caterpillar (CAT 129.24, -8.89, -6.4%), Boeing (BA 367.44, -5.80, -1.6%), and mega-cap tech stocks. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%, and the Nasdaq composite is down 0.1%.

An early look at the S&P 500 sectors shows industrials (-0.1%) recovering some its opening losses as UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.71, +8.0%) helps offset losses from Caterpillar and Boeing following their earnings reports. Health care (-0.9%) is an early laggard, while energy (+0.4%) outperforms.

Separately, Facebook (FB 199.30, -3.09, -1.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1131.90, -14.31, -1.3%), and Amazon (AMZN 1974.59, -19.90, -1.0%) are each down at least 1.0% after the DoJ launched an antitrust probe into the leading online platforms.

U.S. Treasuries are slightly higher, pushing yields lower. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.63. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $56.91/bbl.

09:15 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -24.50.

Wall Street is headed for a lower start in a busy morning in news that has reined in some of yesterday's enthusiasm. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

Alphabet (GOOG 1134.35, -11.86, -1.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1970.00, -24.49, -1.2%), and Facebook (FB 198.50, -3.86, -1.9%) are under pressure this morning after the DoJ announced that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms. On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

Elsewhere, shares of Caterpillar (CAT 131.20, -6.60, -4.8%) are getting hit in pre-market after the Dow component missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance. Fellow Dow components Visa (V 180.21, -0.69, -0.4%) and Boeing (BA 370.89, -2.18, -0.6%) are also down following their results.

Overseas, the slowdown in the eurozone region has persisted, evidenced by the weaker-than-expected flash Manufacturing PMI readings for July. The eurozone reading declined to 46.4 from 47.6. A level below 50.0 denotes a contraction.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -20.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade seven points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own. Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

In economic data: Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3). Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6). New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.2% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.8% India's Sensex: -0.4% South Korea's Kospi: -0.9% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.7%

Major European indices are mixed. The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

In economic data: Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%). Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8). France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102). Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.1%Germany's DAX: +0.3% U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.8% France's CAC 40: -0.4% Italy's FTSE MIB: +0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: +0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.

The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices.

In other earnings news, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights.

08:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.

U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action.

In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.

Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance. Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance. Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei +0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng +0.2%, China's Shanghai Composite +0.8%, India's Sensex -0.4%, South Korea's Kospi -0.9%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries +0.7%.In economic data:Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3).Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6).New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).In news: People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own.Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.Major European indices are mixed. STOXX Europe 600 UNCH, Germany's DAX +0.4%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -1.0%, France's CAC 40 -0.3%, Italy's FTSE MIB +0.4%, Spain's IBEX 35 +0.3%.In economic data:Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%).Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8).France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102).Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)In news:The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HMD1-JC8H-K18W-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 16:25 ET

Dow: -79.22...

Nasdaq: +70.10... S&P: +14.09...

NYSE Vol: 777.5 mln.. Adv: 2119.. Dec: 784

Nasdaq Vol: 1.9 bln.. Adv: 2197.. Dec: 878

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite set new record highsSemiconductor stocks soar following positive earnings results from Texas Instruments (TXN)Caterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA) disappoint on earnings, guidanceDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities, Consumer Staples

16:25 ET

Dow -79.22 at 27269.97, Nasdaq +70.10 at 8321.51, S&P +14.09 at 3019.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 (+0.5%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.9%) set new record highs on Wednesday, boosted by out-sized gains in the semiconductor stocks and by shares of companies that beat earnings estimates. The Russell 2000 rose 1.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, however, lost 0.3% amid noticeable losses in Boeing (BA 361.43, -11.54, -3.1%) and Caterpillar (CAT 131.91, -6.19, -4.5%) following disappointing earnings reports.

Today's advance was forged in the afternoon, as the market began to shake off several early concerns and instead rally around the host of companies that did provide good earnings news. Some of those concerns included the Department of Justice announcing a probe into the "market-leading online platforms," the weaker-than-expected eurozone flash manufacturing PMI for July, and Caterpillar lowering its full-year EPS guidance.

Notable earnings-related gainers included Visa (V 183.33, +2.43, +1.3%), UPS (UPS 114.39, +9.12, +8.7%), Texas Instruments (TXN 129.00, +8.93, +7.4%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 342.97, +18.98, +5.9%), ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 777.96, +38.36, +5.2%), and Snap (SNAP 17.61, +2.78, +18.8%). The market's ability to find support in these companies was encouraging for investors worried about market leadership being too concentrated among a handful of tech giants.

The S&P 500 communication services (+0.9%) and financials (+0.9%) sectors were the day's best-performing sectors. Semiconductor stocks had a field day, rallying on Texas Instruments' solid results. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index advanced 3.1%, boosting its year-to-date gain to a staggering 40%.

Conversely, the consumer staples (-0.6%), real estate (-0.1%), and materials (-0.02%) sectors finished lower.

Separately, for most of the day, the DoJ regulatory threat weighed on shares of Facebook (FB 204.66, +2.30, +1.1%), Amazon (AMZN 2000.81, +6.32, +0.3%), Alphabet (GOOG 1137.81, -8.40, -0.7%), and Apple (AAPL 208.67, -0.17, -0.1%). The FTC also confirmed that Facebook will pay a $5 billion fine for its privacy mishaps, but the stock still rallied heading into its earnings report after the close.

Although the probe added to the uncertainty facing these companies, the positive mood in the market helped shares recoup a bulk of their early losses. In addition, the fact that interest rates remain low should remain a positive consideration for risk assets.

U.S. Treasury yields finished lower on Wednesday. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 1.82%, and the 10-yr yield declined two basis points to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index was unchanged at 97.72. WTI crude lost 1.4% to $55.93/bbl.

Reviewing Wednesday's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June, the weekly Initial and Continuing claims report, and the Advance reports for International Trade in Goods, Retail Inventories, and Wholesale Inventories for June on Thursday.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HKS1-DYRK-9496-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 16:25 ET

Dow: -79.22...

Nasdaq: +70.10... S&P: +14.09...

NYSE Vol: 777.5 mln.. Adv: 2119.. Dec: 784

Nasdaq Vol: 1.9 bln.. Adv: 2197.. Dec: 878

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite push to all-time highs; cyclical sectors outperformRelative strength in UPS (UPS) and the semiconductor stocks following upbeat earnings resultsCaterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA) disappoint on earnings, guidanceDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities, Consumer Staples

16:25 ET

Dow -79.22 at 27269.97, Nasdaq +70.10 at 8321.51, S&P +14.09 at 3019.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 (+0.5%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.9%) set new records highs on Wednesday, boosted by out-sized gains in the semiconductor stocks and by shares of companies that beat earnings estimates. The Russell 2000 rose 1.6%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, however, lost 0.3% amid noticeable losses in Boeing (BA 361.43, -11.54, -3.1%) and Caterpillar (CAT 131.91, -6.19, -4.5%) following disappointing earnings reports.

Today's advance was forged in the afternoon, as the market began to shake off several early concerns and instead rally around the host of companies that did provide good earnings news. Some of those concerns included the Department of Justice announcing a probe into the "market-leading online platforms," the weaker-than-expected eurozone flash manufacturing PMI for July, and Caterpillar lowering its full-year EPS guidance.

Notable earnings-related gainers included Visa (V 183.33, +2.43, +1.3%), UPS (UPS 114.39, +9.12, +8.7%), Texas Instruments (TXN 129.00, +8.93, +7.4%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 342.97, +18.98, +5.9%), ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 777.96, +38.36, +5.2%), and Snap (SNAP 17.61, +2.78, +18.8%). The market's ability to find support in these companies was encouraging for investors worried about market leadership being too concentrated among a handful of tech giants.

The S&P 500 communication services (+0.9%) and financials (+0.9%) sectors were the day's best-performing sectors. Semiconductor stocks had a field day, rallying on Texas Instruments' solid results. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index advanced 3.1%, boosting its year-to-date gain to a staggering 40%.

Conversely, the consumer staples (-0.6%), real estate (-0.1%), and materials (-0.02%) sectors finished lower.

Separately, for most of the day, the DoJ regulatory threat weighed on shares of Facebook (FB 204.66, +2.30, +1.1%), Amazon (AMZN 2000.81, +6.32, +0.3%), Alphabet (GOOG 1137.81, -8.40, -0.7%), and Apple (AAPL 208.67, -0.17, -0.1%). The FTC also confirmed that Facebook will pay a $5 billion fine for its privacy mishaps, but the stock still rallied heading into its earnings report after the close.

Although the probe added to the uncertainty facing these companies, the positive mood in the market helped shares recoup a bulk of their early losses. In addition, the fact that interest rates remain low should remain a positive consideration for risk assets.

U.S. Treasury yields finished lower on Wednesday. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 1.82%, and the 10-yr yield declined two basis points to 2.05%. The U.S. Dollar Index was unchanged at 97.72. WTI crude lost 1.4% to $55.93/bbl.

Reviewing Wednesday's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June, the weekly Initial and Continuing claims report, and the Advance reports for International Trade in Goods, Retail Inventories, and Wholesale Inventories for June on Thursday.

Nasdaq Composite +25.4% YTDS&P 500 +20.5% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +16.9% YTDRussell 2000 +17.2% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2119/784. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2197/878.

15:30 ET

Dow -100.36 at 27248.83, Nasdaq +65.54 at 8316.95, S&P +11.61 at 3017.08

[BRIEFING.COM] Metals Settlement Prices:Aug gold settled today's session $1.90 higher (+0.1%) at $1423.60/ozSept silver settled today's session $0.15 higher (+0.1%) at $16.63/ozSept copper settled $0.01 higher (+0.3%) at $2.71/lbAgriculture Settlement Prices:Sept corn settled $0.03 lower at $4.22/bushelSept wheat settled $0.10 higher at $4.97/bushelAug soybeans settled $0.03 higher at $8.89/bushelEnergy Settlement Prices:Aug Crude Oil futures fell $0.79 (-1.4%) to $55.93/barrelAug Natural Gas settled $0.07 lower (-3.0%) at $2.21/MMBtuAug RBOB Gasoline settled $0.01 lower (-0.4%) at $1.81/gallonAug Heating oil futures settled unch at $1.92/gallon ..NYSE Adv/Dec 799/1.5 bln. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2163/860.

14:55 ET

Dow -108.23 at 27240.96, Nasdaq +45.13 at 8296.54, S&P +8.58 at 3014.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 0.3%, nearing its all-time high, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.2%. The Nasdaq Composite (+0.5%) is currently trading at its all-time intraday high.

Today's advance has been concentrated among the cyclical sectors -- financials (+0.7%), industrials (+0.5%), information technology (+0.5%), energy (+0.5%), and consumer discretionary (+0.3%). The communication services sector (+0.7%) has been another leader as investors buy the dip in Netflix (NFLX 319.42, +12.12, +4.0%).

Looking ahead, notable companies that will report earnings after today's close include Facebook (FB 203.19, +0.83, +0.4%), Ford Motor (F 10.32, +0.15, +1.4%), PayPal (PYPL 120.77, +0.55, +0.5%), and Tesla (TSLA 262.65, +2.48, +1.0%).

14:30 ET

Dow -118.60 at 27230.59, Nasdaq +37.92 at 8289.33, S&P +6.95 at 3012.42

[BRIEFING.COM] Both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite notched session highs in the last half hour, up 0.23% and 0.46%, respectively.

Positive action in the S&P 500 is led by earnings movers like Discover Financial Services (DFS 92.13, +7.65, +9.06%), Edwards Lifesciences (EW 211.97, +16.51, +8.45%), and Grainger (GWW 301.54, +22.76, +8.16%).

Conversely, Rollins (ROL 34.35, -3.80, -9.96%) sits at the bottom of the index in light of this morning's in-line Q2 results.

14:00 ET

Dow -124.98 at 27224.21, Nasdaq +31.96 at 8283.37, S&P +4.50 at 3009.97

[BRIEFING.COM] Again, the major averages have held their lines in the last half hour with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite still within shouting distance of session highs.

Gold futures gave up most of their morning advance though still settled 0.1% higher to $1,423.60/oz on Wednesday in view of this morning's less than stellar Manufacturing PMI reading.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Dollar Index has traded mostly sideways today, down less than 0.1% at the moment to 97.66.

13:30 ET

Dow -116.45 at 27232.74, Nasdaq +32.39 at 8283.8, S&P +4.58 at 3010.05

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages sit little changed in the last half hour with the Dow Jones Industrial Average still in a hole, down about 116 points now.

Aside from the widely-covered losses from Dow Jones Industrial Average components Boeing (BA 362.35, -10.72, -2.87%) & Caterpillar (CAT 131.93, -6.127, -4.47%) shares of UnitedHealth (UNH 252.51, -2.50, -0.98%), Procter & Gamble (PG 112.73, -1.12, -0.98%), and Pfizer (PFE 42.68, -0.41, -0.95%) sit modestly lower.

Conversely, semiconductor giant Intel (INTC 52.72, +0.97, +1.87%) sits atop the index due in part to broader strength in tech and chips.

The DJIA gives back almost all of yesterday's decently higher session, now 0.29% higher on the week.

Elsewhere, at the top of the hour, the Treasury's $41 bln 5-year note auction drew a high yield of 1.824% on a bid-to-cover of 2.26.

12:55 ET

Dow -116.01 at 27233.18, Nasdaq +31.88 at 8283.29, S&P +3.92 at 3009.39

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market trades mixed today. Strong gains in the semiconductor stocks have contributed to the positive disposition in the S&P 500 (+0.1%) and Nasdaq Composite (+0.4%), but noticeable losses in shares of Boeing (BA 363.44, -9.60, -2.6%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.34, -5.77, -4.2%) have pressured the Dow Jones Industrial Average (-0.4%).

Outside of Caterpillar, which missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance, earnings results have continued to come in mostly better than expected. Boeing beat estimates, but its struggles remain company-specific.

UPS (UPS 113.27, +8.00, +7.6%), Northrop Grumman (NOC 338.16, +14.17, +4.4%), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 785.79, +46.19, +6.3%), and Texas Instruments (TXN 129.13, +9.06, +7.4%) are some of today's biggest earnings gainers. Visa (V 180.68, -0.22, -0.1%) beat estimates and raised guidance, but reaction has been muted.

Texas Instruments' report has spurred big gains in the semiconductor stocks, many of which are contributing to the leadership of the S&P 500 information technology sector (+0.5%) and Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.9%). Still, losses in five of the 11 S&P 500 sectors, including consumer staples (-0.7%), have kept the broader market in check.

The market is also missing the influential leadership from some of its largest tech companies, which are currently holding modest losses after the Department of Justice announced an antitrust review into the "market-leading online platforms."

Big-tech scrutiny is nothing new, but it does show legitimate efforts to oversee the influence of market leaders like Facebook (FB 201.40, -0.94, -0.5%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.50, -2.99, -0.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1133.77, -12.44, -1.1%), and Apple (AAPL 208.13, -0.70, -0.3%). On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

U.S. Treasuries have edged higher, pushing yields lower across the curve. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.64.

Reviewing today's economic data, which included New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index:

New home sales increased 7.0% m/m to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 646,000 (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) from a downwardly revised 604,000 (from 626,000) in May. Sales for April and March were also revised lower.The key takeaway from the report is that overall sales activity remains tepid despite the fundamental supports of low mortgage rates, low unemployment, and a tight supply of existing homes for sale.The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week. ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1949/905. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1963/986.

12:25 ET

Dow -124.36 at 27224.83, Nasdaq +22.75 at 8274.16, S&P +1.41 at 3006.88

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades just above its flat line, holding steady above the 3000 level. The Nasdaq outperforms with a gain of 0.3%, while the Dow trades lower by 0.4%.

Looking at the FAANG stocks shows Netflix (NFLX 314.65, +7.39, +2.4%) finally receiving some reprieve after disappointing investors last week. Conversely, Facebook (FB 201.71, -0.65, -0.4%), Apple (AAPL 207.95, -0.89, -0.4%), Amazon (AMZN 1991.43, -3.06, -0.2%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1135.29, -10.92, -1.0%) remain in the red amid the regulatory overhang from the DoJ.

Overseas, the major European indices closed mixed. Germany's DAX increased 0.3%, UK's FTSE lost 0.7%, and France's CAC lost 0.2%. The Europe Stoxx 600 increased 0.1%.

12:00 ET

Dow -139.91 at 27209.28, Nasdaq +14.27 at 8265.68, S&P +0.26 at 3005.73

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market remains mixed, but strikingly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.8%) has advanced to its best levels of the session. That move has been instrumental in lending support to the broader market.

One can sense, however, that selling activity in the broader market might pick up some steam if the semiconductor shares start to roll over, so this will be a closely-watched area as the day progresses.

Overall, there aren't any standout moves from a sector standpoint. Six sectors are up, and five sectors are down, with the performance range spanning -0.5% (health care) to +0.3% (energy).

Separately, Treasuries continue to hold modest gains, with yields down one to three basis points in maturities ranging from the 2-yr note to the 30-yr bond.

11:25 ET

Dow -129.99 at 27219.2, Nasdaq +7.03 at 8258.44, S&P -1.62 at 3003.85

[BRIEFING.COM] It's currently a mixed market with six S&P 500 sectors trading lower and five sectors trading higher. The benchmark index currently trades just below its flat line.

The flattish disposition isn't too bad considering the negative tone in the market prior to the open. Some of that negativity stemmed from weakening manufacturing flash PMI readings out of Europe, the DoJ antitrust probe into the largest online companies, and disappointing guidance from Caterpillar (CAT 132.69, -5.37, -3.9%).

These are legitimate points for investors to be concerned about, but the fact that earnings have come in mostly better than expected has been a positive consideration. The outperformance of the S&P 500 energy sector (+0.8%) amid higher oil prices ($57.08, -$0.30, -0.5%) has also been an area of support for the broader market.

10:55 ET

Dow -135.83 at 27213.36, Nasdaq -11.98 at 8239.43, S&P +1.62 at 3007.09

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher 0.1% after beginning the day on a lower note. The outperformance in several industrial companies and the semiconductor stocks has contributed to the positive disposition.

Like the broader market, the industrials sector (+0.3%) began the day lower amid weakness in shares of Boeing (BA 367.34, -5.69, -1.5%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.38, -5.67, -4.1%) after disappointing investors with results and/or guidance. UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.73, +8.3%) and Northrop Grumman (NOC 337.20, +13.22, +4.1%), however, have provided strong support for the sector after pleasing investors with their results.

Similarly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.5%, rising on the back of solid results from Texas Instruments (TXN 127.99, +7.92, +6.6%). The PHLX is now up a staggering 40% this year.

10:40 ET

Dow -64.20 at 27284.99, Nasdaq +23.24 at 8274.65, S&P +5.19 at 3010.66

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are higher (+0.5% at 79.92 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is lower (-0.1% at 97.6160)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.75 (+1.3%) at $57.52/barrelEIA petroleum data for the week ended July 19- huge draw in oilCrude oil inventories had a draw of 10.8 mln from the prior weekPrior week showed a draw of 3.1 mlnGasoline Inventories had a draw of 0.2 mln barrelPrior week had a build of 3.6 mln barrelDistillate Inventories had a build of 0.6 mlnPrior week had a build of 5.7 mlnEIA reported U.S. oil production fell 700K barrels per day (bpd) to 11.3 mln bpd, a massive reduction. Recent storm Barry plays some part in the reported data, but this really does seem to be a huge reduction..In other energy, Aug natural gas is -$0.06 (-2.5%) at $2.24/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$2.85 (+0.2%) at $1424.55/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.13 (+0.8%) at $16.61/ozSept copper is now +$0.02 (+0.6%) at $2.72/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1800/911. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1719/1095.

10:00 ET

Dow -80.60 at 27268.59, Nasdaq +3.12 at 8254.53, S&P +0.18 at 3005.65

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has marched back to its flat line, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.1%.

Just in, New Home Sales in June hit an annualized rate of 646,000, coming in below the Briefing.com consensus of 660,000. The May reading was revised to 604,000 (from 626,000).

09:45 ET

Dow -139.01 at 27210.18, Nasdaq -6.58 at 8244.83, S&P -2.97 at 3002.5

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market begins the day modestly lower amid weakness in Caterpillar (CAT 129.24, -8.89, -6.4%), Boeing (BA 367.44, -5.80, -1.6%), and mega-cap tech stocks. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%, and the Nasdaq composite is down 0.1%.

An early look at the S&P 500 sectors shows industrials (-0.1%) recovering some its opening losses as UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.71, +8.0%) helps offset losses from Caterpillar and Boeing following their earnings reports. Health care (-0.9%) is an early laggard, while energy (+0.4%) outperforms.

Separately, Facebook (FB 199.30, -3.09, -1.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1131.90, -14.31, -1.3%), and Amazon (AMZN 1974.59, -19.90, -1.0%) are each down at least 1.0% after the DoJ launched an antitrust probe into the leading online platforms.

U.S. Treasuries are slightly higher, pushing yields lower. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.63. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $56.91/bbl.

09:15 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -24.50.

Wall Street is headed for a lower start in a busy morning in news that has reined in some of yesterday's enthusiasm. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

Alphabet (GOOG 1134.35, -11.86, -1.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1970.00, -24.49, -1.2%), and Facebook (FB 198.50, -3.86, -1.9%) are under pressure this morning after the DoJ announced that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms. On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

Elsewhere, shares of Caterpillar (CAT 131.20, -6.60, -4.8%) are getting hit in pre-market after the Dow component missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance. Fellow Dow components Visa (V 180.21, -0.69, -0.4%) and Boeing (BA 370.89, -2.18, -0.6%) are also down following their results.

Overseas, the slowdown in the eurozone region has persisted, evidenced by the weaker-than-expected flash Manufacturing PMI readings for July. The eurozone reading declined to 46.4 from 47.6. A level below 50.0 denotes a contraction.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -20.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade seven points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own. Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

In economic data: Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3). Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6). New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.2% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.8% India's Sensex: -0.4% South Korea's Kospi: -0.9% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.7%

Major European indices are mixed. The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

In economic data: Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%). Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8). France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102). Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.1%Germany's DAX: +0.3% U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.8% France's CAC 40: -0.4% Italy's FTSE MIB: +0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: +0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.

The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices.

In other earnings news, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights.

08:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.

U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action.

In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.

Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance. Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance. Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. 16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.
