Stock Market Update

Updated: 04-Jun-19

The market at 16:25 ET

Dow: +512.40...

Nasdaq: +194.10... S&P: +58.82...

NYSE Vol: 889.3 mln.. Adv: 2365.. Dec: 538

Nasdaq Vol: 2.3 bln.. Adv: 2312.. Dec: 782

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Stock market rallies from short-term oversold conditions and yesterday's rout in big-techFed Chair Powell said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansionDemand for U.S. Treasuries cools off, sending yields higher, in a counter-trade from short-term overbought conditions The S&P 500 breaks above its 200-day moving average (2775)

Strong: Financials, Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Industrials

Weak: Utilities, Real Estate

16:25 ET

Dow +512.40 at 25332.18, Nasdaq +194.10 at 7527.09, S&P +58.82 at 2803.27

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market had its best day since early January, boosted by gains across most sectors and by the prevailing view that the market was due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. Each of the major averages rose at least 2.0%, led by the 2.7% gain in the Nasdaq Composite, and the S&P 500 (+2.1%) climbed back above its 200-day moving average (2775).

Tuesday's advance was rooted in yesterday's ability in the broader market to withstand heavy losses from Apple (AAPL 179.64, +6.34, +3.7%), Amazon (AMZN 1729.56, +36.87, +2.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1053.05, +16.82, +1.6%), and Facebook (FB 167.50, +3.35, +2.0%), which all fell on antitrust concerns.

The turnaround in these mega-cap stocks ensured there was little to impede the rebound effort, especially when given the seemingly supportive comments from the Fed.

Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, acknowledged the trade uncertainty and the persistently low inflation levels. Although no rate cut was promised, Mr. Powell said that the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, assuring the market that the Fed is still on its side.

Cyclical sectors led the rally with the S&P 500 information technology (+3.3%), materials (+2.8%), financials (+2.7%), consumer discretionary (+2.6%), and industrials (+2.4%) sectors all finishing with gains over 2.0%. The defensive-oriented utilities (unch) and real estate (-0.6%) sectors were left out of the rally.

Favorable trade headlines were pointed as having an early effect on the market. China said it wants dialogue and mutual respect in talks with the U.S. while speculation arose that President Trump's Mexico tariffs could be blocked by Congress. However, China's comments were largely in-line with prior rhetoric, and The Hill reported that President Trump is weighing a national emergency to implement new tariffs on Mexico.

Counter to the view that the stock market was oversold on a short-term basis, the Treasury market exhibited weakness on the view that it had gotten overbought on a short-term basis. The 2-yr yield increased five basis points to 1.88%, and the 10-yr yield increased four basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index declined 0.1% to 97.10. WTI crude increased 0.5% to $53.53/bbl.

Separately, Uber (UBER 42.75, +1.50, +3.6%) was rated positively by a host of firms on Tuesday. According to data from Briefing.com, 16 firms initiated the stock with the equivalent of a Buy rating.

Reviewing Friday's lone economic report, Factory Orders for April:

Factory orders declined 0.8% m/m in April (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%) following a downwardly revised 1.3% increase (from 1.9%) in March. Excluding transportation, orders increased 0.3%.The key takeaway from the report is the understanding that business investment was weak in April, evidenced by the 1.0% m/m decline in nondefense capital goods orders excluding aircraft.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the ADP Employment Change report for May, the ISM Non-Manufacturing Index for May, the Fed's Beige Book for June, and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index for May on Wednesday.

Dow +454.12 at 25273.9, Nasdaq +156.06 at 7489.05, S&P +47.84 at 2792.29

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has made a nice run so far today, bolstered by broad-based buying interest and an opportunistic trade rooted in the idea that it was primed to rebound from a short-term oversold condition. The major indices, led by a 2.3% gain in the Russell 2000, are all up at least 1.8% and trading at session highs.

Today's move began in earnest at the sound of the opening bell, as market participants reacted favorably to headlines that seemingly cooled down the temperature surrounding the trade dispute with China, and provided some cover to think the tariff on imported goods from Mexico could be averted, either due to a deal with the U.S. ahead of the June 10 deadline or a possible vote in Congress to forestall the action, according to the Washington Post.

In reality, the mood of the market had been lifted on Monday when the S&P 500 exhibited some relative strength in the face of large losses suffered by Alphabet (GOOG 1051.22, +14.99, +1.5%), Facebook (FB 166.54, +2.39, +1.5%), Amazon.com (AMZN 1723.80, +31.11, +1.8%), and Apple (AAPL 178.68, +5.37, +3.1%), which fell prone to some regulatory angst on the part of investors.

Those mega-cap stocks have managed to bounce back some today on the belief that any investigation into their business practices is likely to be a drawn out one; moreover, there is some underlying hope that none of the companies would eventually be broken up by the government.

Their gains today have helped bolster the broader market, yet the buying interest has been widespread. The information technology (+2.6%), financials (+2.3%), industrials (+2.1%), and consumer discretionary (+2.1%) sectors are all up at least 2.0%. The only sectors not participating today are the defensive-oriented real estate (-1.1%) and utilities (-1.0%) sectors.

Some of the fallout for the latter two sectors hearkens back to the Treasury market, where yields have risen noticeably across the curve on a counter-trade rooted in the idea that Treasuries were primed for a pullback from a short-term overbought condition.

The 2-yr note yield has spiked seven basis points to 1.90% while the 10-yr note yield has jumped five basis points to 2.14%.

The losses in the Treasury market have unfolded despite some softening CPI data out of the eurozone and a 0.8% decline in U.S. factory orders for April.

The non-response in the Treasury market to otherwise disappointing economic data and some seemingly supportive remarks from Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, underscores how the Treasury market is succumbing to the overbought perspective.

Neither Mr. Powell nor Mr. Evans promised a rate cut soon while speaking at a conference in Chicago, yet both paid heed to the risks of undershooting the 2.0% inflation target and the risks of the trade uncertainty, which has been construed by some today as a dovish policy leaning.

Separately, there was no mistaking the leaning in the analyst community with respect to Uber (UBER 42.17, +0.92, +2.2%). No fewer than 20 firms initiated coverage of the stock after its IPO, 16 of which had the equivalent of a Buy recommendation.

Dow +4.74 at 24819.78, Nasdaq -120.13 at 7332.99, S&P -7.61 at 2744.45

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows.

The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.

Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.

These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.

Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.

On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation.

Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.

In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).

Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

urn:contentItem:5W8C-0J11-JC8H-K1P2-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 16:25 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 04-Jun-19

The market at 16:25 ET

Dow: +512.40...

Nasdaq: +194.10... S&P: +58.82...

NYSE Vol: 889.3 mln.. Adv: 2365.. Dec: 538

Nasdaq Vol: 2.3 bln.. Adv: 2312.. Dec: 782

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Stock market rallies from short-term oversold conditions, has its best day since early JanuaryFed Chair Powell said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, assuring the market the Fed is still on its sideDemand for U.S. Treasuries cools off, sending yields higher, amid the view that Treasuries were overbought on a short-term basisThe S&P 500 closed back above its 200-day moving average (2775)

Strong: Financials, Information Technology, Materials, Consumer Discretionary, Industrials

Weak: Utilities, Real Estate

16:25 ET

Dow +512.40 at 25332.18, Nasdaq +194.10 at 7527.09, S&P +58.82 at 2803.27

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market had its best day since early January, boosted by gains across most sectors and by the prevailing view that the market was due for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions. Each of the major averages rose at least 2.0%, led by the 2.7% gain in the Nasdaq Composite, and the S&P 500 (+2.1%) climbed back above its 200-day moving average (2775).

Tuesday's advance was rooted in yesterday's ability in the broader market to withstand heavy losses from Apple (AAPL 179.64, +6.34, +3.7%), Amazon (AMZN 1729.56, +36.87, +2.2%), Alphabet (GOOG 1053.05, +16.82, +1.6%), and Facebook (FB 167.50, +3.35, +2.0%), which all fell on antitrust concerns.

The turnaround in these mega-cap stocks ensured there was little to impede the rebound effort, especially when given the seemingly supportive comments from the Fed.

Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, acknowledged the trade uncertainty and the persistently low inflation levels. Although no rate cut was promised, Mr. Powell said that the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, assuring the market that the Fed is still on its side.

Cyclical sectors led the rally with the S&P 500 information technology (+3.3%), materials (+2.8%), financials (+2.7%), consumer discretionary (+2.6%), and industrials (+2.4%) sectors all finishing with gains over 2.0%. The defensive-oriented utilities (unch) and real estate (-0.6%) sectors were left out of the rally.

Favorable trade headlines were pointed as having an early effect on the market. China said it wants dialogue and mutual respect in talks with the U.S. while speculation arose that President Trump's Mexico tariffs could be blocked by Congress. However, China's comments were largely in-line with prior rhetoric, and The Hill reported that President Trump is weighing a national emergency to implement new tariffs on Mexico.

Counter to the view that the stock market was oversold on a short-term basis, the Treasury market exhibited weakness on the view that it had gotten overbought on a short-term basis. The 2-yr yield increased five basis points to 1.88%, and the 10-yr yield increased four basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index declined 0.1% to 97.10. WTI crude increased 0.5% to $53.53/bbl.

Separately, Uber (UBER 42.75, +1.50, +3.6%) was rated positively by a host of firms on Tuesday. According to data from Briefing.com, 16 firms initiated the stock with the equivalent of a Buy rating.

Reviewing Friday's lone economic report, Factory Orders for April:

Factory orders declined 0.8% m/m in April (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%) following a downwardly revised 1.3% increase (from 1.9%) in March. Excluding transportation, orders increased 0.3%.The key takeaway from the report is the understanding that business investment was weak in April, evidenced by the 1.0% m/m decline in nondefense capital goods orders excluding aircraft.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the ADP Employment Change report for May, the ISM Non-Manufacturing Index for May, the Fed's Beige Book for June, and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index for May on Wednesday.

Nasdaq Composite +13.4% YTDS&P 500 +11.8% YTDRussell 2000 +11.9% YTDDow Jones Industrial Average +8.6% YTD ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2365/538. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2312/782.

15:30 ET

Dow +452.14 at 25271.92, Nasdaq +170.50 at 7503.49, S&P +50.85 at 2795.3

[BRIEFING.COM] Metals closing prices:Jun gold settled today's session $6.55 higher (+0.5%) at $1329.25/ozJul silver settled $0.02 higher at $14.76/ozJul copper settled $0.02 higher (+0.8%) at $2.67/lbAgriculture Settlement Prices:July corn settled $0.02 higher (+0.5%) at $4.23/bushelJuly wheat settled $0.15 lower (-2.9%) at $5.06/bushelJuly soybeans settled $0.03 higher (+0.3%) at $8.80/bushel Energy settlement prices:July Crude Oil futures settled $0.28 higher (+0.5) to $53.53/barrelJuly Natural Gas settled $0.02 higher (+0.8%) at $2.42/MMBtuJuly RBOB Gasoline settled $0.01 lower (-0.6%) at $1.73/gallonJuly Heating oil futures settled $0.01 higher (+0.6%) at $1.82/gallon ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2245/580. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2243/805.

14:55 ET

Dow +436.07 at 25255.85, Nasdaq +163.33 at 7496.32, S&P +48.30 at 2792.75

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher by 1.7%, and the Russell 2000 trades higher by 1.8%.

The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX 17.52, -1.34, -7.2%) has declined noticeably today as buying conviction for equities holds firm. Strikingly, despite the recent losses in the stock market, the VIX never made a convincing move to its recent May 5 high of 23.38.

Looking ahead, Salesforce (CRM 148.90, +3.80, +2.6%) will report its earnings report after today's close.

14:25 ET

Dow +430.82 at 25250.6, Nasdaq +159.91 at 7492.9, S&P +47.95 at 2792.4

[BRIEFING.COM] There has been little to sway the market's decision to rally today. The S&P 500 continues to trade near session highs with a gain of 1.7%.

A look inside the S&P 500 shows Mattel Inc (MAT 10.71, +1.06, +10.9%), Wynn Resorts (WYNN 111.38, +7.81, +7.5%), and MGM Resorts International (MGM 25.35, +1.48, +6.2%) among today's biggest gainers. Mattel announced an international licensing agreement with Sanrio, Inc. WYNN and MGM are benefiting from the prevailing view that stocks were primed for a bounce from short-term oversold conditions.

On the other hand, Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR 32.72, -1.34, -3.9%) has been left out of today's rally, as investors take some profits from yesterday's 8.8% surge.

14:00 ET

Dow +451.73 at 25271.51, Nasdaq +163.67 at 7496.66, S&P +48.88 at 2793.33

[BRIEFING.COM] In the last half hour the Nasdaq Composite and the S&P 500 both made session highs with the Nasdaq's lead growing, now up 2.23% on the day.

Gold futures settled higher for a fifth straight session on Tuesday, but only just so, up less than 0.1% to $1,328.70/oz.

The U.S. Dollar Index sits little changed at 97.13, but spent a good portion of the morning in negative territory.

13:30 ET

Dow +438.51 at 25258.29, Nasdaq +157.30 at 7490.29, S&P +47.80 at 2792.25

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages have held their ground in the last half hour, little changed with the Nasdaq Composite still in the lead, up 2.15%.

Inside the Dow Jones Industrial Average action has held its broadly higher bias with NIKE (NKE 80.66, +2.70, +3.46%), Dow (DOW 49.56, +1.60, +3.34%) & Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 51.52, +1.61, +3.23%) leading the move.

Conversely, Coca-Cola (KO 49.88, -0.10, -0.20%) is the lone decliner in the Dow 30.

The DJIA sits near a six-day high at this moment, now up 1.79% on the month.

13:00 ET

Dow +454.12 at 25273.9, Nasdaq +156.06 at 7489.05, S&P +47.84 at 2792.29

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market has made a nice run so far today, bolstered by broad-based buying interest and an opportunistic trade rooted in the idea that it was primed to rebound from a short-term oversold condition. The major indices, led by a 2.3% gain in the Russell 2000, are all up at least 1.8% and trading at session highs.

Today's move began in earnest at the sound of the opening bell, as market participants reacted favorably to headlines that seemingly cooled down the temperature surrounding the trade dispute with China, and provided some cover to think the tariff on imported goods from Mexico could be averted, either due to a deal with the U.S. ahead of the June 10 deadline or a possible vote in Congress to forestall the action, according to the Washington Post.

In reality, the mood of the market had been lifted on Monday when the S&P 500 exhibited some relative strength in the face of large losses suffered by Alphabet (GOOG 1051.22, +14.99, +1.5%), Facebook (FB 166.54, +2.39, +1.5%), Amazon.com (AMZN 1723.80, +31.11, +1.8%), and Apple (AAPL 178.68, +5.37, +3.1%), which fell prone to some regulatory angst on the part of investors.

Those mega-cap stocks have managed to bounce back some today on the belief that any investigation into their business practices is likely to be a drawn out one; moreover, there is some underlying hope that none of the companies would eventually be broken up by the government.

Their gains today have helped bolster the broader market, yet the buying interest has been widespread. The information technology (+2.6%), financials (+2.3%), industrials (+2.1%), and consumer discretionary (+2.1%) sectors are all up at least 2.0%. The only sectors not participating today are the defensive-oriented real estate (-1.1%) and utilities (-1.0%) sectors.

Some of the fallout for the latter two sectors hearkens back to the Treasury market, where yields have risen noticeably across the curve on a counter-trade rooted in the idea that Treasuries were primed for a pullback from a short-term overbought condition.

The 2-yr note yield has spiked seven basis points to 1.90% while the 10-yr note yield has jumped five basis points to 2.14%.

The losses in the Treasury market have unfolded despite some softening CPI data out of the eurozone and a 0.8% decline in U.S. factory orders for April.

The non-response in the Treasury market to otherwise disappointing economic data and some seemingly supportive remarks from Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters, underscores how the Treasury market is succumbing to the overbought perspective.

Neither Mr. Powell nor Mr. Evans promised a rate cut soon while speaking at a conference in Chicago, yet both paid heed to the risks of undershooting the 2.0% inflation target and the risks of the trade uncertainty, which has been construed by some today as a dovish policy leaning.

Separately, there was no mistaking the leaning in the analyst community with respect to Uber (UBER 42.17, +0.92, +2.2%). No fewer than 20 firms initiated coverage of the stock after its IPO, 16 of which had the equivalent of a Buy recommendation.

12:25 ET

Dow +403.11 at 25222.89, Nasdaq +141.44 at 7474.43, S&P +42.97 at 2787.42

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages hover near their recently established session highs. The Nasdaq (+1.9%) remains in the lead while the S&P 500 (+1.6%) follows a bit behind. The Nasdaq's outperformance comes after the tech-heavy index displayed relative weakness on Monday.

Accordingly, the Nasdaq's outperformance has been supported by a 2.3% gain in the technology sector. The top-weighted group is today's best performer with chipmakers doing their part. The PHLX Semiconductor Index is up 3.0% with all 30 components trading in the green. NVIDIA (NVDA 140.84, +7.06, +5.3%) is up 5.3%, pacing the group's advance after recording eight consecutive losses.

Treasuries sit a bit above their morning lows with the 10-yr yield up five basis points at 2.14%.

11:55 ET

Dow +422.01 at 25241.79, Nasdaq +150.99 at 7483.98, S&P +44.89 at 2789.34

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages continue to push higher with the S&P 500 up 1.7%, the Nasdaq up 2.1%, and the Dow up 1.7%. Contributing to today's bullish bias are supportive comments from Fed Chair Powell and Chicago Fed President Evans, both of whom are FOMC voters.

Mr. Powell said that the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion. Mr. Evans said the "fundamentals" of the economy remain in good footing and is open to a change in policy if necessary. There was no promise of a rate cut, but both did acknowledge concerns about low inflation.

Separately, shares of Box (BOX 16.61, -1.33) have dropped 7.4% after the company guided Q2 revenue below consensus and lowered its FY20 revenue below consensus. On a related note, the stock was downgraded to Hold from Buy at Canaccord Genuity with a price target of $16.

11:25 ET

Dow +419.65 at 25239.43, Nasdaq +137.40 at 7470.39, S&P +41.50 at 2785.95

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades near session highs with a gain of 1.5%. Most of the FAANG stocks that were indicated in potential antitrust probes yesterday have turned it around today.

Shares of Apple (AAPL 1748.91, +5.60) have bounced 3.2% after declining 1.0% yesterday. Amazon (AMZN 1715.83, +23.15, +1.4%) and Alphabet (GOOG 1046.54, +10.31, +1.0%) have recouped some of their losses, while Facebook (FB 163.74, -0.50, -0.3%) has succumbed to follow-through selling interest.

Separately, shares of Uber (UBER 41.84, +0.58) are up 1.6% after the stock was initiated with a Buy rating, or its equivalent thereof, by a host of firms.

10:55 ET

Dow +325.92 at 25145.7, Nasdaq +94.54 at 7427.53, S&P +29.79 at 2774.24

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 1.1% and is flirting with its 200-day moving average (2775).

The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (+2.3%) has been one of today's best-performing groups. Nearly all of its components are up and some have provided solid support for the S&P 500 information technology sector (+1.9%).

Retail stocks, too, have shown some strength, evident by 2.3% gain in the SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT 41.25, +0.95). Shares of Tiffany & Co (TIF 92.93, +2.76, +3.2%) have given the group a boost after the stock initially traded lower by more than 4% in pre-market action. Investors have since cozied up to its earnings beat.

10:30 ET

Dow +345.45 at 25165.23, Nasdaq +104.87 at 7437.86, S&P +34.33 at 2778.78

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities higher (-0.01% at 77.45 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is higher (+0.04% at 97.1800)Looking at energy:Jul WTI crude oil futures are now -$0.33 (-0.6%) at $52.92/barrelIn other energy, Jul natural gas is +$0.01 at $2.41/MMBtuMoving on to metals:June gold is currently +$1.75 at $1329.65/oz, while May silver is +$0.03 at $14.77/ozMay copper is now unch at $2.65/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 2164/609. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 2068/775.

10:00 ET

Dow +242.14 at 25061.92, Nasdaq +69.21 at 7402.2, S&P +23.72 at 2768.17

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is up 0.8%, and the Russell 2000 is up 1.3%. Fed Chair Powell recently said the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the economic expansion, giving the market assurance that the Fed is on its side.

Just in, the Factory Orders report for April showed a decline of 0.8% (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%), and the March reading was revised to +1.3% (from +1.9%).

09:40 ET

Dow +232.30 at 25052.08, Nasdaq +63.13 at 7396.12, S&P +22.40 at 2766.85

[BRIEFING.COM] The major averages begin the day in a rebound led by the cyclical sectors. The S&P 500 is up 0.8%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite is up 0.9%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows financials (+1.4%), information technology (+1.0%), and consumer discretionary (+1.0%) leading the rebound effort. The real estate (-0.3%) and utilities (-0.1%) sectors are the lone sectors in the red amid a rise in U.S. Treasury yields.

Demand for Treasuries has eased amid the positive disposition in equities. The 2-yr yield is up seven basis points to 1.90%, and the 10-yr yield is up four basis points to 2.12%. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.1% to 97.27. WTI crude is down 0.3% to $53.08/bbl.

09:14 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +29.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +80.90.

Wall Street is set for a nice rebound at the open, as the S&P 500 futures trade 27 points, or 1.0%, above fair value.

There has been little-to-no progress in U.S.-China trade talks, but the market appears content for now that there is still a willingness for further talks. There is also a prevailing belief that the market was due for a rebound from short-term oversold conditions, especially considering that the broader market withstood the heavy tech sell-off yesterday.

U.S. Treasury yields have increased noticeably across the curve, as demand for Treasuries cools off. The 2-yr yield is up nine basis points to 1.92%, and the 10-yr yield is up five basis points to 2.13%. The U.S. Dollar Index is up 0.2% to 97.29.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +24.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +72.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 24 points, or 0.9%, above fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended Tuesday on a mostly lower note. Japan's Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi said that working-level trade talks will be held with officials from the U.S. between June 10 and June 11. The Reserve Bank of Australia lowered its cash rate by 25 bps to 1.25%. The move was anticipated by the market and there are expectations that at least one more cut will be made before the end of 2019. Australia's Treasurer Josh Frydenberg called on the country's big four banks to fully pass the rate cut onto consumers to stimulate the economy.

In economic data: Japan's Q1 Capital Spending +6.1% yr/yr (expected 2.6%; last 5.7%) South Korea's Q1 GDP -0.4% qtr/qtr (expected -0.3%; last 1.0%); +1.7% yr/yr (expected 1.8%; last 1.8%). May CPI +0.2% m/m (expected 0.3%; last 0.4%); +0.7% yr/yr (expected 0.8%; last 0.6%) Australia's Q1 Current Account deficit AUD2.90 bln (expected deficit of AUD2.50 bln; last deficit of AUD6.30 bln). April Retail Sales -0.1% m/m (expected 0.2%; last 0.3%) New Zealand's Q1 Export Prices -2.6% qtr/qtr (expected -1.5%; last -1.7%) and Q1 Import Prices -3.5% qtr/qtr (expected -2.5%; last 1.4%)

The S&P 500 futures trade 24 points, or 0.9%, above fair value.

In U.S.-China trade news, China's Ministry of Commerce said on Tuesday it hopes the U.S. can meet half-way and stop the "wrong-doings." No further trade talks have been planned, but China has reiterated its willingness for further talks to resolve the dispute.

In an interview with CNBC, Chicago Fed President Charles Evans (FOMC Voter) said he was "content" with the current Fed policy but is worried about the persistently low inflation levels.

The S&P 500 futures trade 22 points, or 0.8%, above fair value in a rebound from short-term oversold conditions. Likewise, the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 futures trade 0.9% above fair value after antitrust concerns sent big tech stocks reeling yesterday.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell will deliver opening remarks at the Monetary Policy Strategy, Tools, and Communication Practices Conference in Chicago at 9:55 a.m. ET. Several other Fed members are also expected to speak at the two-day conference, which the market hopes will give further insight about the possibility for a rate cut to address slowing growth and muted inflation.

On the data front, investors will receive Factory Orders for April (Briefing.com consensus -0.9%) at 10:00 a.m. ET.

U.S. Treasuries have cooled off amid the positive disposition in the futures trade, pushing yields higher across the curve. [BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 lost 0.3% on Monday, as shares of big tech companies fell on various reports that heightened antitrust concerns. Lingering trade and growth concerns also helped curb risk sentiment and underpin the strength in U.S. Treasuries. A swarm of buyers in the last 30 minutes of action, however, helped the broader market close off its session lows.

The tech-sensitive Nasdaq Composite fell 1.6%. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.02%) finished fractionally higher, and the small-cap Russell 2000 increased 0.3%.

Facebook (FB 164.15, -13.32, -7.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1036.23, -67.40, -6.1%), Amazon (AMZN 1692.69, -82.38, -4.6%), and Apple (AAPL 173.30, -1.77, -1.0%) were all singled out in various reports indicating that the companies could face antitrust scrutiny by the Department of Justice and/or Federal Trade Commission.

These companies represent some of the most widely-held stocks in the U.S., and their out-sized losses weighed heavily on the Nasdaq and on the S&P 500 communication services (-2.8%), information technology (-1.8%), and consumer discretionary (-1.2%) sectors. The other eight S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by materials (+3.4%), to provide offsetting support.

Persisting concerns about trade and growth helped restrain buying conviction throughout the day. China blamed the U.S. for the setback in trade talks, which reinforced fears that a protracted trade war will squeeze global growth, and earnings, prospects. Global manufacturing PMI data, including in the U.S., revealed slower or flat growth in May.

On a related note, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard (FOMC Voter) said that slower economic growth could be sharper-than-expected due to the trade uncertainty. Mr. Bullard added that a rate cut may soon be warranted to boost inflation.

Growing expectations for a rate cut, and general growth concerns, helped send the 2-yr yield down 12 basis points to 1.83%. The 10-yr yield declined six basis points to 2.08%. The U.S. Dollar Index fell 0.5% to 97.22. WTI crude decreased 0.5% to $53.25/bbl, giving up an intraday rebound effort.

In other corporate news, German company Infineon announced plans to acquire Cypress Semiconductor (CY 22.07, +4.25, +23.9%) for approximately $10 billion, or $23.85 per share, in cash. The offer represents a 33.8% premium to CY's Friday closing price. Humana (HUM 250.32, +5.46, +2.2%) said it will not make a competing bid to acquire Centene (CNC 51.82, -5.93, -10.3%).

Reviewing Monday's economic data, which included the ISM Manufacturing Index for May and Construction Spending for April:

The ISM Manufacturing Index for May checked in at 52.1% (Briefing.com consensus 52.6%), down from 52.8% in April. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016. The May reading is the lowest since October 2016.The key takeaway from the report is that it reflects a deceleration in national manufacturing activity that will contribute to the burgeoning growth concerns for the U.S. economy. According to the ISM, the past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates the PMI for May corresponds to a 2.7% increase in real GDP on an annualized basis.Total construction spending was unchanged in April (Briefing.com consensus +0.4%) following an upwardly revised 0.1% increase (from -0.9%) in March.The key takeaway from the report is that it was better than the headline suggests, after accounting for the March revision, yet that still didn't change the fact that total construction spending is soft, evidenced by the 1.2% yr/yr decline that was driven by an 11.2% yr/yr decline in residential spending.

Looking ahead, investors will receive the Factory Orders report for April on Tuesday.

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 12-Aug-20

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 14:43 | 14:05 | 11:51 | 11:15 | 10:20 | 09:51

14:43 ET

Cisco: Earnings Preview; first tech earnings report to include July:

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is set to report Q4 (Jul) results today after the close with a call to follow at 4:30pm ET. CSCO typically reports 5 minutes after the close. The current S&P CapitalIQ consensus is for adjusted EPS of $0.74 (down 11% yr/yr) and revenue of $12.09 bln (down 10% yr/yr). Cisco typically guides for EPS and revenue (on a percentage basis) for the next quarter. Last quarter, Cisco guided to Q4 adjusted EPS of $0.72-0.74 and a revenue decline of -11.5% to -8.5%, which computes as $11.884-12.287 bln. Cisco tends to be conservative with guidance so we're not surprised to see analysts on the higher end of EPS guidance. Current guidance for non-GAAP operating margin in Q4 is 31.5-32.5%. Cisco is a particularly important tech name to watch with earnings. Because it's so large and touches so many areas, it's a great barometer to get a general sense for enterprise sending levels on IT. It's also the first big tech name to report that includes the month of July, so we should get a better sense of how briskly enterprises are spending this summer. Last quarter, Cisco reported nice upside, but was still pretty harshly impacted by the pandemic. Infrastructure Platform sales were down 15% due to supply chain challenges. Switching and routing revenue also declined. Applications segment sales were down 5%, however, this segment saw strong double-digit growth in AppDynamics and IoT software. The main bright spot was booming demand for its Webex video conferencing platform which in April was running at 3x February's capacity. Something that stood out to us on the last call was Cisco saying that the pandemic had caused a lot of customers to realize they have a lot of aged equipment. Many of those customers have said this is a wakeup call and the crisis has provided cover to talk to senior leadership about upgrading to more modernized infrastructure. We'll see if that panned out in Q4. In terms of how Cisco performs relative to consensus, it typically beats modestly on EPS in the $0.01-0.03 range with modest revenue upside. As such, the $0.08 beat in Q3 was unusually strong but that may have been caused by analysts being overly pessimistic due to the pandemic. CSCO has not missed on EPS or revs in the past five years, so if it did so, that would be notable. (PVIEW)

14:05 ET

Kornit Digital is benefiting from an inflection point in the textile industry:

Kornit Digital (KRNT +4%) is printing a nice gain today on a strong Q2 report and a bullish outlook for 2H20. The company, which makes digital printing systems for the apparel and textile industries, has been hit hard by the pandemic but it's clearly showing signs of emerging from the downturn. KRNT reported a loss in Q2 and revenue fell 17.4% yr/yr, but both headline numbers were better than expected. What stood out to us most was KRNT saying it believes it's in the midst of a sharp V-shaped recovery. KRNT remains very confident in its business outlook not only for 2H20 but into 2021 as well. While KRNT did not provide specific 2H20 guidance, the company did raise its 2H20 revenue growth outlook to the low teens from prior guidance of high-single-digits. In addition to earnings, KRNT also announced the acquisition of Custom Gateway, a provider of cloud-based software workflow systems for on-demand production business models.

There have been a lot of cloud computing names that have surged during the pandemic as businesses adapt to the pandemic. We would add KRNT to that list. The vast majority of printed textile industry output is still made using analog print methods. Digital printing accounts for just 3% of output but this number is growing quickly and KRNT is a pure play on that trend.

What stands out to us is that KRNT says the broader market disruption of the last few months has created an inflection point in the textile industry, further accelerating the shift to e-commerce. The pandemic is driving an increased need for on-demand digital production and decoration of textiles.

In sum, KRNT is not the first name you might think of as a pandemic beneficiary, but it seems the pandemic-fueled rapid move to ecommerce is reaching all the way to the old school textile/apparel industry. With KRNT's bullish comment on 2H20 and 2021, it seems like business is picking up nicely.

11:51 ET

Lyft earnings preview - Uber's report sets low bar to hurdle; focus turns to 2H20 rebound:

After the close today, Lyft (LYFT) is scheduled to report 2Q20 results. Following Uber's (UBER) dreary report on August 6, which included a 66% nose-dive in mobility revenue, expectations are low for LYFT's earnings report. The muted sentiment is reflected in LYFT's stock price, which is down nearly 30% on the year.

Analysts are expecting LYFT to report a loss per share of ($0.97) on revenue of $349.4 mln, equating to a yr/yr decline of nearly 60%.UBER's high-growth food delivery business has helped insulate the company from the virus-induced plunge in ride-sharing. As a ride-sharing pure-play, LYFT doesn't enjoy that benefit.On the other hand, LYFT's cost structure is more simplified and the company has managed expenses well. Last quarter, LYFT slashed R&D expenses by 60%, enabling the company to generate EBITDA of ($85) mln, representing a 61% yr/yr improvement.

On June 2, LYFT provided a business update, disclosing that rides for the month of May increased 26% compared to April, when rides plummeted by 70%. The improvement in rides coincided with the reopening of businesses within local economies. The positive momentum likely stalled in mid-to-late June as virus cases increased, causing many local governments to reinstate strict social distancing rules.

In the same press release, LYFT stated that Adjusted EBITDA loss for Q2 is not expected to exceed $325 mln if average daily ride-share volume in June is unchanged versus May levels. That forecast equated to a ~10% improvement compared to LYFT's prior guidance for adjusted EBITDA loss to not exceed $360 mln.

Ever since LYFT went public in March of 2019, investors have been focused on the company's path to profitability. Before the pandemic hit, the company believed it would reach profitability on an EBITDA basis by the end of 2021.

The virus has likely pushed that timeline out, but the company has levers to pull that can keep it moving in the right direction. Through lower payroll and insurance costs, LYFT believes it can shed an additional $300 mln beyond its original 2020 expectations.

The wild card is whether the recent ruling in California, which requires LYFT and UBER to stop classifying their drivers as independent contractors, will create a major headwind. Both companies will appeal the decision and the matter will also be included on voting ballots in November.

If the appeal is unsuccessful and if voters agree with the state that drivers should be classified as employees, LYFT and UBER's expenses will sharply rise because the companies will need to provide costly benefits.

Lastly, a meaningful recovery for the ride-sharing business largely rests on the widespread availability of a vaccine. There has been plenty of positive news on the vaccine front recently, offering hope for a rebound in ride volume later this year.

11:15 ET

Tesla joins the stock split party, will others follow? Maybe AMZN?: Tesla (TSLA +8%) is zooming higher as the electric car maker declared a 5-for-1 stock split last night. We know it should not matter what the actual price of the stock is as the valuation metrics and earnings are computed on a per share basis. But it does matter to a lot of investors, especially retail investors who buy in smaller increments or just psychologically would rather own a $300 stock instead of a $1,500 stock. Tesla is actually the second huge name to announce a split in as many weeks as Apple (AAPL) declared a 4-for-1 split on July 30 along with its JunQ earnings report. With Apple and now Tesla, maybe there is a trend starting where companies are becoming more open to stock splits.Of course, the big name most people would like to see split is Amazon (AMZN), which trades above $3000. BKNG ($1,818), GOOG ($1,511), AZO ($1,192), CMG ($1,163) and NFLX ($476) are other names we think are ripe for a split.

10:20 ET

Brinker is satisfying investors' appetite with a solid JunQ result and SepQ guidance:

Brinker Intl (EAT +4%) is serving up some delicious Q4 (Jun) results for investors. We had concerns regarding how the pandemic would impact EAT since it is an operator of casual restaurant chains, including its flagship Chili's brand. While the company certainly took a hit from restaurants closing due to the pandemic, the loss was much narrower than expected. Overall, it was a mixed quarter as the adjusted loss of $(0.88) per share was much better than the $(1.37) consensus although revenue was a bit light of expectations. The best news was the guidance for Q1 (Sep) as the loss of $(0.40)-$(0.25) was a good bit narrower than consensus of $(0.56). Q1 comps are expected to be down in the low to mid-teens, a nice improvement from -38.6% comps in Q4. It's Just Wings, a virtual offering through EAT's partnership with Doordash, launched nationally in 1,050 company-owned restaurants on June 23. It's Just Wings sales are included in comps for restaurants operating the virtual brand.

Of all the casual restaurant chains, we think EAT is among the best positioned to ride out the pandemic since EAT focuses on value offerings. For example, its value-priced 2-for-$25 menu has been a hit with consumers. Also, Chili's has really stepped up its digital and delivery offerings in recent quarters, just in time for the pandemic.

We also think this It's Just Wings virtual delivery-only offering is pretty genius and should be a nice tailwind for comps in coming quarters. What's smart about the offering is that it has a simple, quick to prepare menu and the wings are prepared using existing capacity at Chili's kitchens, so there are no upfront costs. Also, Wingstop (WING) has seen a surge of sales during the pandemic and we see this offering as tapping into that wing potential.

Overall, this was a solid quarter. It did not blow us away but the EPS upside and especially the SepQ guidance provides reassurance that EAT is handling the pandemic pretty well.

09:51 ET

Moderna lands major vaccine supply agreement with U.S government, lifting shares higher: Positive vaccine-related headlines have allowed investors to look past gloomy economic data in anticipation of an eventual return to normalcy. Today, the stock market received more good news: the U.S government has secured a supply agreement with Moderna (MRNA) for the company's COVID-19 vaccine, mRNA-1273.

The order calls for an initial delivery of 100 mln doses with the option to purchase up to 400 mln more doses. In total, the contract is worth up to $1.525 bln.

After rocketing higher by as much as 385% this year, shares of MRNA have cooled off over the past few weeks. Encouraging clinical trial data from other COVID-19 vaccine producers like Pfizer (PFE)/BioNTech(BNTX) and AstraZeneca (AZN)/Oxford University, combined with profit-taking and valuation concerns, tentatively stymied MRNA's rally.

However, today's news has the stock back in rally mode.

The near-term outlook does indeed look bright for MRNA. While the company will likely ultimately share the stage with other pharmaceutical companies, MRNA is in good position to launch a vaccine first.

When the company reported Q2 results on August 5, CEO Stphane Bancel stated that enrollment for MRNA's Phase 3 study was on track to be completed in September. Assuming that the company reaches that goal, Bancel believes that trial data will be available in October and November.

MRNA appears to be neck-in-neck with the PFE/BNTX and AZN/Oxford teams, both of which are also conducting late-stage trials. During PFE's earnings conference call on July 28, CEO Albert Bourla commented that he expects the vaccine (BNT162b2) to be ready to seek emergency use authorization, or some form of regulatory approval, as early as this October.

Whether MRNA wins this race remains to be seen. What's more certain, though, is that the company is in solid financial condition, thanks to the flood of capital it has obtained.

MRNA ended Q2 with $3.1 bln in cash, and the company received ~$400 mln of customer deposits for the potential supply of mRNA-1273. That amount is prior to today's agreement with the U.S. government.

Based on a presumed regulatory approval, analysts are predicting that MRNA will generate revenue of $4.5 bln in FY21, lifting the company into profitability. The top-line estimate translates into a 1-year forward P/S of about 6x, which is reasonable in our view. The primary risk, though, is that the stock has already priced in FDA approval for the vaccine.

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 12-Aug-20

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 14:43 | 14:05 | 11:51 | 11:15 | 10:20 | 09:51

14:43 ET

Cisco: Earnings Preview; first tech earnings report to include July:

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is set to report Q4 (Jul) results today after the close with a call to follow at 4:30pm ET. CSCO typically reports 5 minutes after the close. The current S&P CapitalIQ consensus is for adjusted EPS of $0.74 (down 11% yr/yr) and revenue of $12.09 bln (down 10% yr/yr). Cisco typically guides for EPS and revenue (on a percentage basis) for the next quarter. Last quarter, Cisco guided to Q4 adjusted EPS of $0.72-0.74 and a revenue decline of -11.5% to -8.5%, which computes as $11.884-12.287 bln. Cisco tends to be conservative with guidance so we're not surprised to see analysts on the higher end of EPS guidance. Current guidance for non-GAAP operating margin in Q4 is 31.5-32.5%. Cisco is a particularly important tech name to watch with earnings. Because it's so large and touches so many areas, it's a great barometer to get a general sense for enterprise sending levels on IT. It's also the first big tech name to report that includes the month of July, so we should get a better sense of how briskly enterprises are spending this summer. Last quarter, Cisco reported nice upside, but was still pretty harshly impacted by the pandemic. Infrastructure Platform sales were down 15% due to supply chain challenges. Switching and routing revenue also declined. Applications segment sales were down 5%, however, this segment saw strong double-digit growth in AppDynamics and IoT software. The main bright spot was booming demand for its Webex video conferencing platform which in April was running at 3x February's capacity. Something that stood out to us on the last call was Cisco saying that the pandemic had caused a lot of customers to realize they have a lot of aged equipment. Many of those customers have said this is a wakeup call and the crisis has provided cover to talk to senior leadership about upgrading to more modernized infrastructure. We'll see if that panned out in Q4. In terms of how Cisco performs relative to consensus, it typically beats modestly on EPS in the $0.01-0.03 range with modest revenue upside. As such, the $0.08 beat in Q3 was unusually strong but that may have been caused by analysts being overly pessimistic due to the pandemic. CSCO has not missed on EPS or revs in the past five years, so if it did so, that would be notable. (PVIEW)

14:05 ET

Kornit Digital is benefiting from an inflection point in the textile industry:

Kornit Digital (KRNT +4%) is printing a nice gain today on a strong Q2 report and a bullish outlook for 2H20. The company, which makes digital printing systems for the apparel and textile industries, has been hit hard by the pandemic but it's clearly showing signs of emerging from the downturn. KRNT reported a loss in Q2 and revenue fell 17.4% yr/yr, but both headline numbers were better than expected. What stood out to us most was KRNT saying it believes it's in the midst of a sharp V-shaped recovery. KRNT remains very confident in its business outlook not only for 2H20 but into 2021 as well. While KRNT did not provide specific 2H20 guidance, the company did raise its 2H20 revenue growth outlook to the low teens from prior guidance of high-single-digits. In addition to earnings, KRNT also announced the acquisition of Custom Gateway, a provider of cloud-based software workflow systems for on-demand production business models.

There have been a lot of cloud computing names that have surged during the pandemic as businesses adapt to the pandemic. We would add KRNT to that list. The vast majority of printed textile industry output is still made using analog print methods. Digital printing accounts for just 3% of output but this number is growing quickly and KRNT is a pure play on that trend.

What stands out to us is that KRNT says the broader market disruption of the last few months has created an inflection point in the textile industry, further accelerating the shift to e-commerce. The pandemic is driving an increased need for on-demand digital production and decoration of textiles.

In sum, KRNT is not the first name you might think of as a pandemic beneficiary, but it seems the pandemic-fueled rapid move to ecommerce is reaching all the way to the old school textile/apparel industry. With KRNT's bullish comment on 2H20 and 2021, it seems like business is picking up nicely.

11:51 ET

Lyft earnings preview - Uber's report sets low bar to hurdle; focus turns to 2H20 rebound:

After the close today, Lyft (LYFT) is scheduled to report 2Q20 results. Following Uber's (UBER) dreary report on August 6, which included a 66% nose-dive in mobility revenue, expectations are low for LYFT's earnings report. The muted sentiment is reflected in LYFT's stock price, which is down nearly 30% on the year.

Analysts are expecting LYFT to report a loss per share of ($0.97) on revenue of $349.4 mln, equating to a yr/yr decline of nearly 60%.UBER's high-growth food delivery business has helped insulate the company from the virus-induced plunge in ride-sharing. As a ride-sharing pure-play, LYFT doesn't enjoy that benefit.On the other hand, LYFT's cost structure is more simplified and the company has managed expenses well. Last quarter, LYFT slashed R&D expenses by 60%, enabling the company to generate EBITDA of ($85) mln, representing a 61% yr/yr improvement.

On June 2, LYFT provided a business update, disclosing that rides for the month of May increased 26% compared to April, when rides plummeted by 70%. The improvement in rides coincided with the reopening of businesses within local economies. The positive momentum likely stalled in mid-to-late June as virus cases increased, causing many local governments to reinstate strict social distancing rules.

In the same press release, LYFT stated that Adjusted EBITDA loss for Q2 is not expected to exceed $325 mln if average daily ride-share volume in June is unchanged versus May levels. That forecast equated to a ~10% improvement compared to LYFT's prior guidance for adjusted EBITDA loss to not exceed $360 mln.

Ever since LYFT went public in March of 2019, investors have been focused on the company's path to profitability. Before the pandemic hit, the company believed it would reach profitability on an EBITDA basis by the end of 2021.

The virus has likely pushed that timeline out, but the company has levers to pull that can keep it moving in the right direction. Through lower payroll and insurance costs, LYFT believes it can shed an additional $300 mln beyond its original 2020 expectations.

The wild card is whether the recent ruling in California, which requires LYFT and UBER to stop classifying their drivers as independent contractors, will create a major headwind. Both companies will appeal the decision and the matter will also be included on voting ballots in November.

If the appeal is unsuccessful and if voters agree with the state that drivers should be classified as employees, LYFT and UBER's expenses will sharply rise because the companies will need to provide costly benefits.

Lastly, a meaningful recovery for the ride-sharing business largely rests on the widespread availability of a vaccine. There has been plenty of positive news on the vaccine front recently, offering hope for a rebound in ride volume later this year.

11:15 ET

Tesla joins the stock split party, will others follow? Maybe AMZN?: Tesla (TSLA +8%) is zooming higher as the electric car maker declared a 5-for-1 stock split last night. We know it should not matter what the actual price of the stock is as the valuation metrics and earnings are computed on a per share basis. But it does matter to a lot of investors, especially retail investors who buy in smaller increments or just psychologically would rather own a $300 stock instead of a $1,500 stock. Tesla is actually the second huge name to announce a split in as many weeks as Apple (AAPL) declared a 4-for-1 split on July 30 along with its JunQ earnings report. With Apple and now Tesla, maybe there is a trend starting where companies are becoming more open to stock splits.Of course, the big name most people would like to see split is Amazon (AMZN), which trades above $3000. BKNG ($1,818), GOOG ($1,511), AZO ($1,192), CMG ($1,163) and NFLX ($476) are other names we think are ripe for a split.

10:20 ET

Brinker is satisfying investors' appetite with a solid JunQ result and SepQ guidance:

Brinker Intl (EAT +4%) is serving up some delicious Q4 (Jun) results for investors. We had concerns regarding how the pandemic would impact EAT since it is an operator of casual restaurant chains, including its flagship Chili's brand. While the company certainly took a hit from restaurants closing due to the pandemic, the loss was much narrower than expected. Overall, it was a mixed quarter as the adjusted loss of $(0.88) per share was much better than the $(1.37) consensus although revenue was a bit light of expectations. The best news was the guidance for Q1 (Sep) as the loss of $(0.40)-$(0.25) was a good bit narrower than consensus of $(0.56). Q1 comps are expected to be down in the low to mid-teens, a nice improvement from -38.6% comps in Q4. It's Just Wings, a virtual offering through EAT's partnership with Doordash, launched nationally in 1,050 company-owned restaurants on June 23. It's Just Wings sales are included in comps for restaurants operating the virtual brand.

Of all the casual restaurant chains, we think EAT is among the best positioned to ride out the pandemic since EAT focuses on value offerings. For example, its value-priced 2-for-$25 menu has been a hit with consumers. Also, Chili's has really stepped up its digital and delivery offerings in recent quarters, just in time for the pandemic.

We also think this It's Just Wings virtual delivery-only offering is pretty genius and should be a nice tailwind for comps in coming quarters. What's smart about the offering is that it has a simple, quick to prepare menu and the wings are prepared using existing capacity at Chili's kitchens, so there are no upfront costs. Also, Wingstop (WING) has seen a surge of sales during the pandemic and we see this offering as tapping into that wing potential.

Overall, this was a solid quarter. It did not blow us away but the EPS upside and especially the SepQ guidance provides reassurance that EAT is handling the pandemic pretty well.

09:51 ET

Moderna lands major vaccine supply agreement with U.S government, lifting shares higher: Positive vaccine-related headlines have allowed investors to look past gloomy economic data in anticipation of an eventual return to normalcy. Today, the stock market received more good news: the U.S government has secured a supply agreement with Moderna (MRNA) for the company's COVID-19 vaccine, mRNA-1273.

Whether MRNA wins this race remains to be seen. What's more certain, though, is that the company is in solid financial condition, thanks to the flood of capital it has obtained.

MRNA ended Q2 with $3.1 bln in cash, and the company received ~$400 mln of customer deposits for the potential supply of mRNA-1273. That amount is prior to today's agreement with the U.S. government.

Based on a presumed regulatory approval, analysts are predicting that MRNA will generate revenue of $4.5 bln in FY21, lifting the company into profitability. Digital printing accounts for just 3% of output but this number is growing quickly and KRNT is a pure play on that trend.

What stands out to us is that KRNT says the broader market disruption of the last few months has created an inflection point in the textile industry, further accelerating the shift to e-commerce. The pandemic is driving an increased need for on-demand digital production and decoration of textiles.

In sum, KRNT is not the first name you might think of as a pandemic beneficiary, but it seems the pandemic-fueled rapid move to ecommerce is reaching all the way to the old school textile/apparel industry. With KRNT's bullish comment on 2H20 and 2021, it seems like business is picking up nicely.

11:51 ET

Lyft earnings preview - Uber's report sets low bar to hurdle; focus turns to 2H20 rebound:

After the close today, Lyft (LYFT) is scheduled to report 2Q20 results. Following Uber's (UBER) dreary report on August 6, which included a 66% nose-dive in mobility revenue, expectations are low for LYFT's earnings report. The muted sentiment is reflected in LYFT's stock price, which is down nearly 30% on the year.

Analysts are expecting LYFT to report a loss per share of ($0.97) on revenue of $349.4 mln, equating to a yr/yr decline of nearly 60%.UBER's high-growth food delivery business has helped insulate the company from the virus-induced plunge in ride-sharing. As a ride-sharing pure-play, LYFT doesn't enjoy that benefit.On the other hand, LYFT's cost structure is more simplified and the company has managed expenses well. Last quarter, LYFT slashed R&D expenses by 60%, enabling the company to generate EBITDA of ($85) mln, representing a 61% yr/yr improvement.

On June 2, LYFT provided a business update, disclosing that rides for the month of May increased 26% compared to April, when rides plummeted by 70%. The improvement in rides coincided with the reopening of businesses within local economies. The positive momentum likely stalled in mid-to-late June as virus cases increased, causing many local governments to reinstate strict social distancing rules.

In the same press release, LYFT stated that Adjusted EBITDA loss for Q2 is not expected to exceed $325 mln if average daily ride-share volume in June is unchanged versus May levels. That forecast equated to a ~10% improvement compared to LYFT's prior guidance for adjusted EBITDA loss to not exceed $360 mln.

Ever since LYFT went public in March of 2019, investors have been focused on the company's path to profitability. Before the pandemic hit, the company believed it would reach profitability on an EBITDA basis by the end of 2021.

The virus has likely pushed that timeline out, but the company has levers to pull that can keep it moving in the right direction. Through lower payroll and insurance costs, LYFT believes it can shed an additional $300 mln beyond its original 2020 expectations.

The wild card is whether the recent ruling in California, which requires LYFT and UBER to stop classifying their drivers as independent contractors, will create a major headwind. Both companies will appeal the decision and the matter will also be included on voting ballots in November.

If the appeal is unsuccessful and if voters agree with the state that drivers should be classified as employees, LYFT and UBER's expenses will sharply rise because the companies will need to provide costly benefits.

Lastly, a meaningful recovery for the ride-sharing business largely rests on the widespread availability of a vaccine. There has been plenty of positive news on the vaccine front recently, offering hope for a rebound in ride volume later this year.

11:15 ET

Tesla joins the stock split party, will others follow? Maybe AMZN?: Tesla (TSLA +8%) is zooming higher as the electric car maker declared a 5-for-1 stock split last night. We know it should not matter what the actual price of the stock is as the valuation metrics and earnings are computed on a per share basis. But it does matter to a lot of investors, especially retail investors who buy in smaller increments or just psychologically would rather own a $300 stock instead of a $1,500 stock. Tesla is actually the second huge name to announce a split in as many weeks as Apple (AAPL) declared a 4-for-1 split on July 30 along with its JunQ earnings report. With Apple and now Tesla, maybe there is a trend starting where companies are becoming more open to stock splits.Of course, the big name most people would like to see split is Amazon (AMZN), which trades above $3000. BKNG ($1,818), GOOG ($1,511), AZO ($1,192), CMG ($1,163) and NFLX ($476) are other names we think are ripe for a split.

10:20 ET

Brinker is satisfying investors' appetite with a solid JunQ result and SepQ guidance:

Brinker Intl (EAT +4%) is serving up some delicious Q4 (Jun) results for investors. We had concerns regarding how the pandemic would impact EAT since it is an operator of casual restaurant chains, including its flagship Chili's brand. While the company certainly took a hit from restaurants closing due to the pandemic, the loss was much narrower than expected. Overall, it was a mixed quarter as the adjusted loss of $(0.88) per share was much better than the $(1.37) consensus although revenue was a bit light of expectations. The best news was the guidance for Q1 (Sep) as the loss of $(0.40)-$(0.25) was a good bit narrower than consensus of $(0.56). Q1 comps are expected to be down in the low to mid-teens, a nice improvement from -38.6% comps in Q4. It's Just Wings, a virtual offering through EAT's partnership with Doordash, launched nationally in 1,050 company-owned restaurants on June 23. It's Just Wings sales are included in comps for restaurants operating the virtual brand.

Of all the casual restaurant chains, we think EAT is among the best positioned to ride out the pandemic since EAT focuses on value offerings. For example, its value-priced 2-for-$25 menu has been a hit with consumers. Also, Chili's has really stepped up its digital and delivery offerings in recent quarters, just in time for the pandemic.

We also think this It's Just Wings virtual delivery-only offering is pretty genius and should be a nice tailwind for comps in coming quarters. What's smart about the offering is that it has a simple, quick to prepare menu and the wings are prepared using existing capacity at Chili's kitchens, so there are no upfront costs. Also, Wingstop (WING) has seen a surge of sales during the pandemic and we see this offering as tapping into that wing potential.

Overall, this was a solid quarter. It did not blow us away but the EPS upside and especially the SepQ guidance provides reassurance that EAT is handling the pandemic pretty well.

09:51 ET

Moderna lands major vaccine supply agreement with U.S government, lifting shares higher: Positive vaccine-related headlines have allowed investors to look past gloomy economic data in anticipation of an eventual return to normalcy. Today, the stock market received more good news: the U.S government has secured a supply agreement with Moderna (MRNA) for the company's COVID-19 vaccine, mRNA-1273.

The order calls for an initial delivery of 100 mln doses with the option to purchase up to 400 mln more doses. In total, the contract is worth up to $1.525 bln.

After rocketing higher by as much as 385% this year, shares of MRNA have cooled off over the past few weeks. Encouraging clinical trial data from other COVID-19 vaccine producers like Pfizer (PFE)/BioNTech(BNTX) and AstraZeneca (AZN)/Oxford University, combined with profit-taking and valuation concerns, tentatively stymied MRNA's rally.

However, today's news has the stock back in rally mode.

The near-term outlook does indeed look bright for MRNA. While the company will likely ultimately share the stage with other pharmaceutical companies, MRNA is in good position to launch a vaccine first.

When the company reported Q2 results on August 5, CEO Stphane Bancel stated that enrollment for MRNA's Phase 3 study was on track to be completed in September. Assuming that the company reaches that goal, Bancel believes that trial data will be available in October and November.

MRNA appears to be neck-in-neck with the PFE/BNTX and AZN/Oxford teams, both of which are also conducting late-stage trials. During PFE's earnings conference call on July 28, CEO Albert Bourla commented that he expects the vaccine (BNT162b2) to be ready to seek emergency use authorization, or some form of regulatory approval, as early as this October.

Whether MRNA wins this race remains to be seen. What's more certain, though, is that the company is in solid financial condition, thanks to the flood of capital it has obtained.

MRNA ended Q2 with $3.1 bln in cash, and the company received ~$400 mln of customer deposits for the potential supply of mRNA-1273. That amount is prior to today's agreement with the U.S. government.

Based on a presumed regulatory approval, analysts are predicting that MRNA will generate revenue of $4.5 bln in FY21, lifting the company into profitability. The top-line estimate translates into a 1-year forward P/S of about 6x, which is reasonable in our view. The primary risk, though, is that the stock has already priced in FDA approval for the vaccine.
