urn:contentItem:60DV-WN31-DYRK-90TM-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 23-Jul-20

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 14:43 | 14:14 | 12:39 | 11:31 | 10:43 | 10:10

14:43 ET

Intel: Earnings Preview -- Expectations for chip companies are running high:

Intel (INTC) is set to report Q2 results today after the close with a call to follow at 5pm ET. Current CapitalIQ consensus for EPS is $1.11 and for revenue it's $18.55 bln. Intel typically guides for EPS and revenue for the next quarter in the press release. In April, Intel guided to Q2 non-GAAP EPS of approx. $1.10 and revenue of approx. $18.50 bln. Expectations for semiconductor companies are running high this earnings season as several companies have reported strong results (like TXN on Tuesday and MU in late June) while several others have increased guidance in the past couple of weeks or so, including ADI, MXIM, IMOS, FORM, MXL, XLNX. In fairness, Intel is not a direct comparison as it does more than make chips. INTC has been transforming from a PC-centric company to a data-centric company, the latter of which accounted for 48% of revenue in 2019. Its data center segment is focused on cloud computing, network infrastructure, and intelligent edge applications as well as artificial intelligence (AI) and 5G. The PC side is not seeing a lot of growth but Intel recently began shipping its 10nm Intel Core processors, which feature a new core architecture. INTC is on track to launch its first 7nm-based product, a discrete GPU, at the end of 2021. Intel's top line growth tends to be pretty modest. However, the company also tends to be consistent relative to consensus estimates as it has not missed on EPS in any quarter over the past five years. And its EPS beats have been getting larger in recent quarters, with four consecutive double digit EPS beats. Overall, some big tech names have reported, but we are still early in the tech reporting cycle.We think Intel should have pretty good results. IBM had a nice quarter and said large enterprise customers are still spending. TXN's quarter is a good sign for Intel as well. Also, Microsoft (MSFT) had a mixed quarter, but its consumer/PC side did well with more people working at home. This is good news for Intel's PC business.

14:14 ET

AutoNation and LAD prove our point that car dealerships will be among first to recover:

AutoNation (AN +8%) is in the driver's seat today as it reported a ridiculously strong Q2 earnings report this morning, which followed a very strong Q1 result in May. As the nation's largest auto retailer with 325 car dealerships from coast to coast, AutoNation has been right in the crosshairs of the pandemic.

We had to do a double take when the earnings hit this morning. Analysts were expecting a 69% yr/yr decline in EPS. However, AN wound up posting 18% EPS growth at $1.41, way ahead of the $0.37 consensus estimate. Revenue fell 15.2% yr/yr to $4.53 bln, but that also was well ahead of the $4.09 bln consensus.

This was not just a one-off situation. Another nationwide car dealership, Lithia Motors (LAD +7%), also reported blowout results last night. LAD reported adjusted EPS of $3.72, also well ahead of the $1.54 consensus. LAD also reported strong upside revenue.

When we published our story stock on AN in May, we hypothesized that car dealerships would see a relatively quicker rebound than industries like air travel, hotels, restaurants, movie theatres, and especially cruise lines. That prediction seems to be coming to fruition with these reports today. Low interest rates and a consumer preference shift toward cars and away from public transit are clearly helping drive demand.

12:39 ET

Union Pacific derailed by soft volumes across multiple business groups:

Heading into this morning's earnings report, shares of Union Pacific (UNP) had rallied nearly 50% off their March lows. The rally, presumably based off hopes of an improving economy, has hit a roadblock as UNP's mixed results and cautious outlook has reset investors' expectations.

Through solid cost containment efforts, the railroad operator managed to outpace analysts' earnings expectations, generating EPS of $1.67 vs. the $1.56 consensus estimate. While the execution is commendable, the main story resides on the top-line where revenue fell by 24% yr/yr to $4.24 bln.

The drop was fueled by a 20% decrease in volumes, coupled with a 6% dip in average revenue per car, as negative COVID-19 effects rippled across business groups.

Main areas of weakness were not surprising, and included automotive (volume -64%), coal (-24%), and energy products (-26%). In order, auto plant shutdowns, weak export demand and low natural gas prices, and depressed oil prices pressured volumes in these segments.

While facing this very difficult business climate, UNP implemented several cost-cutting and productivity initiatives to help mitigate the demand erosion.

For instance, the company reduced its train and engine workforce by 32%, outpacing volume declines. Additionally, UNP increased train sizes and put more product on fewer trains, boosting efficiency.

Lower diesel fuel prices and reduced volumes also pushed fuel expenses lower by 56%.

Despite these positive factors, UNP's operating ratio deteriorated by 140 bps yr/yr to 61%. UNP is not alone in reporting a downturn in its operating ratio. CSX (CSX) and Canadian National Railway (CNI) reported operating ratios of 63.3% and 60.4% compared to 57.4% and 57.5%, respectively, a year ago. As a reminder, a lower operating ratio is better, illustrating the company's efficiency in generating profits.

Looking ahead, UNP expects 2020 volumes to be down by about 10% from 2019 levels. The company still sees considerable economic uncertainty due to the virus, especially as local economies reverse recent re-openings.

On the positive side, UNP has experienced a recent rebound in the automotive segment as vehicle manufacturing plants have reopened and as vehicle demand has strengthened. eCommerce is another area of strength that is likely to continue. Overall, though, UNP remains cautious about business conditions for the remainder of the year.

11:31 ET

Chipotle is rolling lower today as the burrito chain broke its string of huge beats:

Chipotle (CMG -2%) is rolling a bit lower today following its Q2 earnings report last night. There was some consternation heading into this report because CMG did not provide a mid-quarter update as some burger chains had.

Overall, the results were decent but did not blow us away. Not surprisingly, analysts were expecting a big drop in EPS on a yr/yr basis due to the pandemic and limitations on in-premise dining. That's what happened as adjusted EPS fell 90% yr/yr to $0.40. What's a bit odd is that EPS was right on the button with analyst expectations, which is surprising and rare given the lack of guidance and so many variables related to the pandemic. The unfortunate part of this is that CMG broke its string of seven consecutive double-digit EPS beats. The revenue decline was much more muted as it fell 4.8% yr/yr to $1.36 bln, slightly above analyst expectations.

In Q2, comps came in at -9.8%, down from +3.3% in Q1. As we said in our preview, investors were likely expecting a weak comp in Q2, but they would want to see at least gradual improvement as the quarter went on. CMG came through in this regard: March (part of Q1, but including here for context) at -16.0%; April -24.4%, May -7.0%, June +2.0%, and July (Q3) so far is +6.4% and that's despite CMG lapping a robust +10% comp in July 2019.

It's definitely a positive to see CMG back to positive comps the past couple of months. CMG is at a bit of a disadvantage relative to other fast food chains because it does not have a big drive-thru presence that consumers could use to avoid going into a restaurant during the pandemic.

However, CMG does deserve credit for getting customers to use its digital app and delivery service. Digital sales grew 216.3% yr/yr in Q2 and accounted for 60.7% of sales for the quarter. What's very encouraging, and we've said this in past comments, is that digital sales tend to be sticky. Once people get used to the app, they keep using it. Since sales troughed in late March, CMG has retained 70-80% of its digital sales gains while recovering 40-50% of in-store sales.

Despite the monthly comp improvement, the stock is lower today. We think the in-line EPS/revenue is being seen as a bit of a disappointment given CMG's penchant for reporting big beats. Also, the stock made a big move in recent months (from $415 at its mid-March low to $1180 heading into this report). We cautioned in our preview that a lot of good news is already priced in, so any stumble/in-line results could take a bite out of the stock. We are seeing a bit of that today.

10:43 ET

Tesla electrifies investors with blow-out results and potential inclusion in S&P 500: With shares nearly doubling since Tesla (TSLA) last reported earnings on April 29, the company faced an exceptionally high bar to hurdle regarding its 2Q20 performance. To avoid a likely steep sell-off, blow-out results and another profitable quarter was needed.

TSLA delivered just that, generating EPS of $2.34, crushing the ($0.16) consensus estimate. In an environment in which the auto industry suffered a 30% decline in 1H20, TSLA's Q2 revenue only fell by 5% to $6.04 bln, easily beating the $5.31 bln forecast.

The GAAP profit of $104 mln marks the company's fourth straight quarterly profit, paving the way for TSLA to be included in the S&P 500. The meteoric rise in TSLA's stock price suggests that this bullish development was mostly priced into shares. Still, TSLA's evolution to profitability is a significant fundamental achievement that makes the stock more appealing to a wider base of investors.

TSLA reported solid, better-than-expected Q2 vehicle deliveries of 90,650 on July 2. What was unknown was whether lower operating efficiency, resulting from plant shut-downs, would prevent the company from posting a profit.

Adjusted automotive gross margin did slide to 18.7% from 20.0% last quarter. However, this dip was mitigated by record regulatory tax credit sales of $428 mln. TSLA sells these government issued credits to its competitors, which they use to offset the cost of making zero emission vehicles.

If one wants to nit-pick at TSLA's report, one could argue that the quality of the earnings beat is somewhat questionable due to inflated regulatory tax credit sales. Indeed, the degree of TSLA's upside performance wouldn't have been as impressive without this inflation, but this doesn't negate the overall strong performance in our view.

Improvements in product and manufacturing costs, and a 12.5% yr/yr reduction in operating expenses to $951 mln, also positively impacted the company's profitability.

In addition to the quarterly results, TSLA had important news to share regarding its next production facility.

The company has chosen Austin, TX as the location for its fourth plant. The 2,000 acre facility will house production for the Cybertruck and Tesla Semi, which is expected to be available for delivery in 2021. Also, Model 3 and Model Y sedans for the eastern U.S. market will be produced there.

Given the sky-high expectations, TSLA needed to astonish investors with strong Q2 results, while spurring excitement for future growth opportunities. The company achieved both goals, as reflected in the stock's move higher.

10:10 ET

Microsoft reports a solid quarter but a few areas like Azure were not as robust as in MarQ:

Microsoft (MSFT) reported another solid beat, and yet the stock trades modestly lower. That response makes sense if you dig into the quarter a bit. In terms of revenue, MSFT did quite well overall, reporting upside relative to prior guidance in two of its three segments - Intelligent Cloud (IC) and More Personal Computing (MPC) - while Productivity and Business Processes' (PBP) result was in-line. A slight negative is that growth rates declined from MarQ in PBP (15% to 6%) and IC (27% to 17%). Offsetting that was MPC (+3% to +14%), which saw an acceleration as Windows OEM, Surface, and Gaming benefitted from more people at home. In terms of EPS, MSFT broke its string of double digit EPS beats at five in a row. The $0.08 upside this quarter was good, but it was not quite as robust as the beats delivered in recent quarters. Probably more troubling was a modest degradation in growth in several key areas: Most prominently, in MSFT's Azure cloud computing business, its crown jewel, growth slowed a bit to 47% in JunQ from 59% in MarQ. Office Commercial products and cloud services slowed to +5% from +13% in MarQ. IC Server products and cloud services slowed to +19% in JunQ from +30% in MarQ. LinkedIn growth slowed to +10% in JunQ from +21% in MarQ, as it was impacted by a weak job market and reductions in advertising spend. Search was negatively impacted by reductions in advertising spend. Transactional license purchasing continued to slow, particularly in small and medium businesses.

Overall, this was still a very good quarter, with a solid beat on revenue and EPS. The primary culprits for the stock's move lower, we think, is lackluster PBP segment growth coupled with Azure's performance. While Azure had great growth, with so many companies and consumers using the cloud as they work/learn from home, the Azure number was a slight letdown. This may be a slight cause for concern for Amazon (AMZN) and its rival AWS unit, which reports on July 30.

urn:contentItem:60DV-WN31-DYRK-90TG-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 23-Jul-20

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 14:43 | 14:14 | 12:39 | 11:31 | 10:43 | 10:10

14:43 ET

Intel: Earnings Preview -- Expectations for chip companies are running high:

Intel (INTC) is set to report Q2 results today after the close with a call to follow at 5pm ET. Current CapitalIQ consensus for EPS is $1.11 and for revenue it's $18.55 bln. Intel typically guides for EPS and revenue for the next quarter in the press release. In April, Intel guided to Q2 non-GAAP EPS of approx. $1.10 and revenue of approx. $18.50 bln. Expectations for semiconductor companies are running high this earnings season as several companies have reported strong results (like TXN on Tuesday and MU in late June) while several others have increased guidance in the past couple of weeks or so, including ADI, MXIM, IMOS, FORM, MXL, XLNX. In fairness, Intel is not a direct comparison as it does more than make chips. INTC has been transforming from a PC-centric company to a data-centric company, the latter of which accounted for 48% of revenue in 2019. Its data center segment is focused on cloud computing, network infrastructure, and intelligent edge applications as well as artificial intelligence (AI) and 5G. The PC side is not seeing a lot of growth but Intel recently began shipping its 10nm Intel Core processors, which feature a new core architecture. INTC is on track to launch its first 7nm-based product, a discrete GPU, at the end of 2021. Intel's top line growth tends to be pretty modest. However, the company also tends to be consistent relative to consensus estimates as it has not missed on EPS in any quarter over the past five years. And its EPS beats have been getting larger in recent quarters, with four consecutive double digit EPS beats. Overall, some big tech names have reported, but we are still early in the tech reporting cycle.We think Intel should have pretty good results. IBM had a nice quarter and said large enterprise customers are still spending. TXN's quarter is a good sign for Intel as well. Also, Microsoft (MSFT) had a mixed quarter, but its consumer/PC side did well with more people working at home. This is good news for Intel's PC business.

14:14 ET

AutoNation and LAD prove our point that car dealerships will be among first to recover:

AutoNation (AN +8%) is in the driver's seat today as it reported a ridiculously strong Q2 earnings report this morning, which followed a very strong Q1 result in May. As the nation's largest auto retailer with 325 car dealerships from coast to coast, AutoNation has been right in the crosshairs of the pandemic.

We had to do a double take when the earnings hit this morning. Analysts were expecting a 69% yr/yr decline in EPS. However, AN wound up posting 18% EPS growth at $1.41, way ahead of the $0.37 consensus estimate. Revenue fell 15.2% yr/yr to $4.53 bln, but that also was well ahead of the $4.09 bln consensus.

This was not just a one-off situation. Another nationwide car dealership, Lithia Motors (LAD +7%), also reported blowout results last night. LAD reported adjusted EPS of $3.72, also well ahead of the $1.54 consensus. LAD also reported strong upside revenue.

When we published our story stock on AN in May, we hypothesized that car dealerships would see a relatively quicker rebound than industries like air travel, hotels, restaurants, movie theatres, and especially cruise lines. That prediction seems to be coming to fruition with these reports today. Low interest rates and a consumer preference shift toward cars and away from public transit are clearly helping drive demand.

12:39 ET

Union Pacific derailed by soft volumes across multiple business groups:

Heading into this morning's earnings report, shares of Union Pacific (UNP) had rallied nearly 50% off their March lows. The rally, presumably based off hopes of an improving economy, has hit a roadblock as UNP's mixed results and cautious outlook has reset investors' expectations.

Through solid cost containment efforts, the railroad operator managed to outpace analysts' earnings expectations, generating EPS of $1.67 vs. the $1.56 consensus estimate. While the execution is commendable, the main story resides on the top-line where revenue fell by 24% yr/yr to $4.24 bln.

The drop was fueled by a 20% decrease in volumes, coupled with a 6% dip in average revenue per car, as negative COVID-19 effects rippled across business groups.

Main areas of weakness were not surprising, and included automotive (volume -64%), coal (-24%), and energy products (-26%). In order, auto plant shutdowns, weak export demand and low natural gas prices, and depressed oil prices pressured volumes in these segments.

While facing this very difficult business climate, UNP implemented several cost-cutting and productivity initiatives to help mitigate the demand erosion.

For instance, the company reduced its train and engine workforce by 32%, outpacing volume declines. Additionally, UNP increased train sizes and put more product on fewer trains, boosting efficiency.

Lower diesel fuel prices and reduced volumes also pushed fuel expenses lower by 56%.

Despite these positive factors, UNP's operating ratio deteriorated by 140 bps yr/yr to 61%. UNP is not alone in reporting a downturn in its operating ratio. CSX (CSX) and Canadian National Railway (CNI) reported operating ratios of 63.3% and 60.4% compared to 57.4% and 57.5%, respectively, a year ago. As a reminder, a lower operating ratio is better, illustrating the company's efficiency in generating profits.

Looking ahead, UNP expects 2020 volumes to be down by about 10% from 2019 levels. The company still sees considerable economic uncertainty due to the virus, especially as local economies reverse recent re-openings.

On the positive side, UNP has experienced a recent rebound in the automotive segment as vehicle manufacturing plants have reopened and as vehicle demand has strengthened. eCommerce is another area of strength that is likely to continue. Overall, though, UNP remains cautious about business conditions for the remainder of the year.

11:31 ET

Chipotle is rolling lower today as the burrito chain broke its string of huge beats:

Chipotle (CMG -2%) is rolling a bit lower today following its Q2 earnings report last night. There was some consternation heading into this report because CMG did not provide a mid-quarter update as some burger chains had.

Overall, the results were decent but did not blow us away. Not surprisingly, analysts were expecting a big drop in EPS on a yr/yr basis due to the pandemic and limitations on in-premise dining. That's what happened as adjusted EPS fell 90% yr/yr to $0.40. What's a bit odd is that EPS was right on the button with analyst expectations, which is surprising and rare given the lack of guidance and so many variables related to the pandemic. The unfortunate part of this is that CMG broke its string of seven consecutive double-digit EPS beats. The revenue decline was much more muted as it fell 4.8% yr/yr to $1.36 bln, slightly above analyst expectations.

In Q2, comps came in at -9.8%, down from +3.3% in Q1. As we said in our preview, investors were likely expecting a weak comp in Q2, but they would want to see at least gradual improvement as the quarter went on. CMG came through in this regard: March (part of Q1, but including here for context) at -16.0%; April -24.4%, May -7.0%, June +2.0%, and July (Q3) so far is +6.4% and that's despite CMG lapping a robust +10% comp in July 2019.

It's definitely a positive to see CMG back to positive comps the past couple of months. CMG is at a bit of a disadvantage relative to other fast food chains because it does not have a big drive-thru presence that consumers could use to avoid going into a restaurant during the pandemic.

However, CMG does deserve credit for getting customers to use its digital app and delivery service. Digital sales grew 216.3% yr/yr in Q2 and accounted for 60.7% of sales for the quarter. What's very encouraging, and we've said this in past comments, is that digital sales tend to be sticky. Once people get used to the app, they keep using it. Since sales troughed in late March, CMG has retained 70-80% of its digital sales gains while recovering 40-50% of in-store sales.

Despite the monthly comp improvement, the stock is lower today. We think the in-line EPS/revenue is being seen as a bit of a disappointment given CMG's penchant for reporting big beats. Also, the stock made a big move in recent months (from $415 at its mid-March low to $1180 heading into this report). We cautioned in our preview that a lot of good news is already priced in, so any stumble/in-line results could take a bite out of the stock. We are seeing a bit of that today.

10:43 ET

Tesla electrifies investors with blow-out results and potential inclusion in S&P 500: With shares nearly doubling since Tesla (TSLA) last reported earnings on April 29, the company faced an exceptionally high bar to hurdle regarding its 2Q20 performance. To avoid a likely steep sell-off, blow-out results and another profitable quarter was needed.

TSLA delivered just that, generating EPS of $2.34, crushing the ($0.16) consensus estimate. In an environment in which the auto industry suffered a 30% decline in 1H20, TSLA's Q2 revenue only fell by 5% to $6.04 bln, easily beating the $5.31 bln forecast.

The GAAP profit of $104 mln marks the company's fourth straight quarterly profit, paving the way for TSLA to be included in the S&P 500. The meteoric rise in TSLA's stock price suggests that this bullish development was mostly priced into shares. Still, TSLA's evolution to profitability is a significant fundamental achievement that makes the stock more appealing to a wider base of investors.

TSLA reported solid, better-than-expected Q2 vehicle deliveries of 90,650 on July 2. What was unknown was whether lower operating efficiency, resulting from plant shut-downs, would prevent the company from posting a profit.

Adjusted automotive gross margin did slide to 18.7% from 20.0% last quarter. However, this dip was mitigated by record regulatory tax credit sales of $428 mln. TSLA sells these government issued credits to its competitors, which they use to offset the cost of making zero emission vehicles.

If one wants to nit-pick at TSLA's report, one could argue that the quality of the earnings beat is somewhat questionable due to inflated regulatory tax credit sales. Indeed, the degree of TSLA's upside performance wouldn't have been as impressive without this inflation, but this doesn't negate the overall strong performance in our view.

Improvements in product and manufacturing costs, and a 12.5% yr/yr reduction in operating expenses to $951 mln, also positively impacted the company's profitability.

In addition to the quarterly results, TSLA had important news to share regarding its next production facility.

The company has chosen Austin, TX as the location for its fourth plant. The 2,000 acre facility will house production for the Cybertruck and Tesla Semi, which is expected to be available for delivery in 2021. Also, Model 3 and Model Y sedans for the eastern U.S. market will be produced there.

Given the sky-high expectations, TSLA needed to astonish investors with strong Q2 results, while spurring excitement for future growth opportunities. The company achieved both goals, as reflected in the stock's move higher.

10:10 ET

Microsoft reports a solid quarter but a few areas like Azure were not as robust as in MarQ:

Microsoft (MSFT) reported another solid beat, and yet the stock trades modestly lower. That response makes sense if you dig into the quarter a bit. In terms of revenue, MSFT did quite well overall, reporting upside relative to prior guidance in two of its three segments - Intelligent Cloud (IC) and More Personal Computing (MPC) - while Productivity and Business Processes' (PBP) result was in-line. A slight negative is that growth rates declined from MarQ in PBP (15% to 6%) and IC (27% to 17%). Offsetting that was MPC (+3% to +14%), which saw an acceleration as Windows OEM, Surface, and Gaming benefitted from more people at home. In terms of EPS, MSFT broke its string of double digit EPS beats at five in a row. The $0.08 upside this quarter was good, but it was not quite as robust as the beats delivered in recent quarters. Probably more troubling was a modest degradation in growth in several key areas: Most prominently, in MSFT's Azure cloud computing business, its crown jewel, growth slowed a bit to 47% in JunQ from 59% in MarQ. Office Commercial products and cloud services slowed to +5% from +13% in MarQ. IC Server products and cloud services slowed to +19% in JunQ from +30% in MarQ. LinkedIn growth slowed to +10% in JunQ from +21% in MarQ, as it was impacted by a weak job market and reductions in advertising spend. Search was negatively impacted by reductions in advertising spend. Transactional license purchasing continued to slow, particularly in small and medium businesses.

Overall, this was still a very good quarter, with a solid beat on revenue and EPS. The primary culprits for the stock's move lower, we think, is lackluster PBP segment growth coupled with Azure's performance. While Azure had great growth, with so many companies and consumers using the cloud as they work/learn from home, the Azure number was a slight letdown. This may be a slight cause for concern for Amazon (AMZN) and its rival AWS unit, which reports on July 30.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60DV-WN41-JC8H-K013-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 23-Jul-20

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 14:43 | 14:14 | 12:39 | 11:31 | 10:43 | 10:10

14:43 ET

Intel: Earnings Preview -- Expectations for chip companies are running high:

Intel (INTC) is set to report Q2 results today after the close with a call to follow at 5pm ET. Current CapitalIQ consensus for EPS is $1.11 and for revenue it's $18.55 bln. Intel typically guides for EPS and revenue for the next quarter in the press release. In April, Intel guided to Q2 non-GAAP EPS of approx. $1.10 and revenue of approx. $18.50 bln. Expectations for semiconductor companies are running high this earnings season as several companies have reported strong results (like TXN on Tuesday and MU in late June) while several others have increased guidance in the past couple of weeks or so, including ADI, MXIM, IMOS, FORM, MXL, XLNX. In fairness, Intel is not a direct comparison as it does more than make chips. INTC has been transforming from a PC-centric company to a data-centric company, the latter of which accounted for 48% of revenue in 2019. Its data center segment is focused on cloud computing, network infrastructure, and intelligent edge applications as well as artificial intelligence (AI) and 5G. The PC side is not seeing a lot of growth but Intel recently began shipping its 10nm Intel Core processors, which feature a new core architecture. INTC is on track to launch its first 7nm-based product, a discrete GPU, at the end of 2021. Intel's top line growth tends to be pretty modest. However, the company also tends to be consistent relative to consensus estimates as it has not missed on EPS in any quarter over the past five years. And its EPS beats have been getting larger in recent quarters, with four consecutive double digit EPS beats. Overall, some big tech names have reported, but we are still early in the tech reporting cycle.We think Intel should have pretty good results. IBM had a nice quarter and said large enterprise customers are still spending. TXN's quarter is a good sign for Intel as well. Also, Microsoft (MSFT) had a mixed quarter, but its consumer/PC side did well with more people working at home. This is good news for Intel's PC business.

14:14 ET

AutoNation and LAD prove our point that car dealerships will be among first to recover:

AutoNation (AN +8%) is in the driver's seat today as it reported a ridiculously strong Q2 earnings report this morning, which followed a very strong Q1 result in May. As the nation's largest auto retailer with 325 car dealerships from coast to coast, AutoNation has been right in the crosshairs of the pandemic.

We had to do a double take when the earnings hit this morning. Analysts were expecting a 69% yr/yr decline in EPS. However, AN wound up posting 18% EPS growth at $1.41, way ahead of the $0.37 consensus estimate. Revenue fell 15.2% yr/yr to $4.53 bln, but that also was well ahead of the $4.09 bln consensus.

This was not just a one-off situation. Another nationwide car dealership, Lithia Motors (LAD +7%), also reported blowout results last night. LAD reported adjusted EPS of $3.72, also well ahead of the $1.54 consensus. LAD also reported strong upside revenue.

When we published our story stock on AN in May, we hypothesized that car dealerships would see a relatively quicker rebound than industries like air travel, hotels, restaurants, movie theatres, and especially cruise lines. That prediction seems to be coming to fruition with these reports today. Low interest rates and a consumer preference shift toward cars and away from public transit are clearly helping drive demand.

12:39 ET

Union Pacific derailed by soft volumes across multiple business groups:

Heading into this morning's earnings report, shares of Union Pacific (UNP) had rallied nearly 50% off their March lows. The rally, presumably based off hopes of an improving economy, has hit a roadblock as UNP's mixed results and cautious outlook has reset investors' expectations.

Through solid cost containment efforts, the railroad operator managed to outpace analysts' earnings expectations, generating EPS of $1.67 vs. the $1.56 consensus estimate. While the execution is commendable, the main story resides on the top-line where revenue fell by 24% yr/yr to $4.24 bln.

The drop was fueled by a 20% decrease in volumes, coupled with a 6% dip in average revenue per car, as negative COVID-19 effects rippled across business groups.

Main areas of weakness were not surprising, and included automotive (volume -64%), coal (-24%), and energy products (-26%). In order, auto plant shutdowns, weak export demand and low natural gas prices, and depressed oil prices pressured volumes in these segments.

While facing this very difficult business climate, UNP implemented several cost-cutting and productivity initiatives to help mitigate the demand erosion.

For instance, the company reduced its train and engine workforce by 32%, outpacing volume declines. Additionally, UNP increased train sizes and put more product on fewer trains, boosting efficiency.

Lower diesel fuel prices and reduced volumes also pushed fuel expenses lower by 56%.

Despite these positive factors, UNP's operating ratio deteriorated by 140 bps yr/yr to 61%. UNP is not alone in reporting a downturn in its operating ratio. CSX (CSX) and Canadian National Railway (CNI) reported operating ratios of 63.3% and 60.4% compared to 57.4% and 57.5%, respectively, a year ago. As a reminder, a lower operating ratio is better, illustrating the company's efficiency in generating profits.

Looking ahead, UNP expects 2020 volumes to be down by about 10% from 2019 levels. The company still sees considerable economic uncertainty due to the virus, especially as local economies reverse recent re-openings.

On the positive side, UNP has experienced a recent rebound in the automotive segment as vehicle manufacturing plants have reopened and as vehicle demand has strengthened. eCommerce is another area of strength that is likely to continue. Overall, though, UNP remains cautious about business conditions for the remainder of the year.

11:31 ET

Chipotle is rolling lower today as the burrito chain broke its string of huge beats:

Chipotle (CMG -2%) is rolling a bit lower today following its Q2 earnings report last night. There was some consternation heading into this report because CMG did not provide a mid-quarter update as some burger chains had.

Overall, the results were decent but did not blow us away. Not surprisingly, analysts were expecting a big drop in EPS on a yr/yr basis due to the pandemic and limitations on in-premise dining. That's what happened as adjusted EPS fell 90% yr/yr to $0.40. What's a bit odd is that EPS was right on the button with analyst expectations, which is surprising and rare given the lack of guidance and so many variables related to the pandemic. The unfortunate part of this is that CMG broke its string of seven consecutive double-digit EPS beats. The revenue decline was much more muted as it fell 4.8% yr/yr to $1.36 bln, slightly above analyst expectations.

In Q2, comps came in at -9.8%, down from +3.3% in Q1. As we said in our preview, investors were likely expecting a weak comp in Q2, but they would want to see at least gradual improvement as the quarter went on. CMG came through in this regard: March (part of Q1, but including here for context) at -16.0%; April -24.4%, May -7.0%, June +2.0%, and July (Q3) so far is +6.4% and that's despite CMG lapping a robust +10% comp in July 2019.

It's definitely a positive to see CMG back to positive comps the past couple of months. CMG is at a bit of a disadvantage relative to other fast food chains because it does not have a big drive-thru presence that consumers could use to avoid going into a restaurant during the pandemic.

However, CMG does deserve credit for getting customers to use its digital app and delivery service. Digital sales grew 216.3% yr/yr in Q2 and accounted for 60.7% of sales for the quarter. What's very encouraging, and we've said this in past comments, is that digital sales tend to be sticky. Once people get used to the app, they keep using it. Since sales troughed in late March, CMG has retained 70-80% of its digital sales gains while recovering 40-50% of in-store sales.

Despite the monthly comp improvement, the stock is lower today. We think the in-line EPS/revenue is being seen as a bit of a disappointment given CMG's penchant for reporting big beats. Also, the stock made a big move in recent months (from $415 at its mid-March low to $1180 heading into this report). We cautioned in our preview that a lot of good news is already priced in, so any stumble/in-line results could take a bite out of the stock. We are seeing a bit of that today.

10:43 ET

Tesla electrifies investors with blow-out results and potential inclusion in S&P 500: With shares nearly doubling since Tesla (TSLA) last reported earnings on April 29, the company faced an exceptionally high bar to hurdle regarding its 2Q20 performance. To avoid a likely steep sell-off, blow-out results and another profitable quarter was needed.

TSLA delivered just that, generating EPS of $2.34, crushing the ($0.16) consensus estimate. In an environment in which the auto industry suffered a 30% decline in 1H20, TSLA's Q2 revenue only fell by 5% to $6.04 bln, easily beating the $5.31 bln forecast.

The GAAP profit of $104 mln marks the company's fourth straight quarterly profit, paving the way for TSLA to be included in the S&P 500. The meteoric rise in TSLA's stock price suggests that this bullish development was mostly priced into shares. Still, TSLA's evolution to profitability is a significant fundamental achievement that makes the stock more appealing to a wider base of investors.

TSLA reported solid, better-than-expected Q2 vehicle deliveries of 90,650 on July 2. What was unknown was whether lower operating efficiency, resulting from plant shut-downs, would prevent the company from posting a profit.

Adjusted automotive gross margin did slide to 18.7% from 20.0% last quarter. However, this dip was mitigated by record regulatory tax credit sales of $428 mln. TSLA sells these government issued credits to its competitors, which they use to offset the cost of making zero emission vehicles.

If one wants to nit-pick at TSLA's report, one could argue that the quality of the earnings beat is somewhat questionable due to inflated regulatory tax credit sales. Indeed, the degree of TSLA's upside performance wouldn't have been as impressive without this inflation, but this doesn't negate the overall strong performance in our view.

Improvements in product and manufacturing costs, and a 12.5% yr/yr reduction in operating expenses to $951 mln, also positively impacted the company's profitability.

In addition to the quarterly results, TSLA had important news to share regarding its next production facility.

The company has chosen Austin, TX as the location for its fourth plant. The 2,000 acre facility will house production for the Cybertruck and Tesla Semi, which is expected to be available for delivery in 2021. Also, Model 3 and Model Y sedans for the eastern U.S. market will be produced there.

Given the sky-high expectations, TSLA needed to astonish investors with strong Q2 results, while spurring excitement for future growth opportunities. The company achieved both goals, as reflected in the stock's move higher.

10:10 ET

Microsoft reports a solid quarter but a few areas like Azure were not as robust as in MarQ:

Microsoft (MSFT) reported another solid beat, and yet the stock trades modestly lower. That response makes sense if you dig into the quarter a bit. In terms of revenue, MSFT did quite well overall, reporting upside relative to prior guidance in two of its three segments - Intelligent Cloud (IC) and More Personal Computing (MPC) - while Productivity and Business Processes' (PBP) result was in-line. A slight negative is that growth rates declined from MarQ in PBP (15% to 6%) and IC (27% to 17%). Offsetting that was MPC (+3% to +14%), which saw an acceleration as Windows OEM, Surface, and Gaming benefitted from more people at home. In terms of EPS, MSFT broke its string of double digit EPS beats at five in a row. The $0.08 upside this quarter was good, but it was not quite as robust as the beats delivered in recent quarters. Probably more troubling was a modest degradation in growth in several key areas: Most prominently, in MSFT's Azure cloud computing business, its crown jewel, growth slowed a bit to 47% in JunQ from 59% in MarQ. Office Commercial products and cloud services slowed to +5% from +13% in MarQ. IC Server products and cloud services slowed to +19% in JunQ from +30% in MarQ. LinkedIn growth slowed to +10% in JunQ from +21% in MarQ, as it was impacted by a weak job market and reductions in advertising spend. Search was negatively impacted by reductions in advertising spend. Transactional license purchasing continued to slow, particularly in small and medium businesses.

Overall, this was still a very good quarter, with a solid beat on revenue and EPS. The primary culprits for the stock's move lower, we think, is lackluster PBP segment growth coupled with Azure's performance. While Azure had great growth, with so many companies and consumers using the cloud as they work/learn from home, the Azure number was a slight letdown. This may be a slight cause for concern for Amazon (AMZN) and its rival AWS unit, which reports on July 30.

10:43 ET

Tesla electrifies investors with blow-out results and potential inclusion in S&P 500: With shares nearly doubling since Tesla (TSLA) last reported earnings on April 29, the company faced an exceptionally high bar to hurdle regarding its 2Q20 performance. To avoid a likely steep sell-off, blow-out results and another profitable quarter was needed.

TSLA delivered just that, generating EPS of $2.34, crushing the ($0.16) consensus estimate. In an environment in which the auto industry suffered a 30% decline in 1H20, TSLA's Q2 revenue only fell by 5% to $6.04 bln, easily beating the $5.31 bln forecast.

The GAAP profit of $104 mln marks the company's fourth straight quarterly profit, paving the way for TSLA to be included in the S&P 500. The meteoric rise in TSLA's stock price suggests that this bullish development was mostly priced into shares. Still, TSLA's evolution to profitability is a significant fundamental achievement that makes the stock more appealing to a wider base of investors.

TSLA reported solid, better-than-expected Q2 vehicle deliveries of 90,650 on July 2. What was unknown was whether lower operating efficiency, resulting from plant shut-downs, would prevent the company from posting a profit.

Adjusted automotive gross margin did slide to 18.7% from 20.0% last quarter. However, this dip was mitigated by record regulatory tax credit sales of $428 mln. TSLA sells these government issued credits to its competitors, which they use to offset the cost of making zero emission vehicles.

If one wants to nit-pick at TSLA's report, one could argue that the quality of the earnings beat is somewhat questionable due to inflated regulatory tax credit sales. Indeed, the degree of TSLA's upside performance wouldn't have been as impressive without this inflation, but this doesn't negate the overall strong performance in our view.

Improvements in product and manufacturing costs, and a 12.5% yr/yr reduction in operating expenses to $951 mln, also positively impacted the company's profitability.

In addition to the quarterly results, TSLA had important news to share regarding its next production facility.

The company has chosen Austin, TX as the location for its fourth plant. The 2,000 acre facility will house production for the Cybertruck and Tesla Semi, which is expected to be available for delivery in 2021. Also, Model 3 and Model Y sedans for the eastern U.S. market will be produced there.

Given the sky-high expectations, TSLA needed to astonish investors with strong Q2 results, while spurring excitement for future growth opportunities. The company achieved both goals, as reflected in the stock's move higher.

10:10 ET

Microsoft reports a solid quarter but a few areas like Azure were not as robust as in MarQ:

Microsoft (MSFT) reported another solid beat, and yet the stock trades modestly lower. That response makes sense if you dig into the quarter a bit. In terms of revenue, MSFT did quite well overall, reporting upside relative to prior guidance in two of its three segments - Intelligent Cloud (IC) and More Personal Computing (MPC) - while Productivity and Business Processes' (PBP) result was in-line. A slight negative is that growth rates declined from MarQ in PBP (15% to 6%) and IC (27% to 17%). Offsetting that was MPC (+3% to +14%), which saw an acceleration as Windows OEM, Surface, and Gaming benefitted from more people at home. In terms of EPS, MSFT broke its string of double digit EPS beats at five in a row. The $0.08 upside this quarter was good, but it was not quite as robust as the beats delivered in recent quarters. Probably more troubling was a modest degradation in growth in several key areas: Most prominently, in MSFT's Azure cloud computing business, its crown jewel, growth slowed a bit to 47% in JunQ from 59% in MarQ. Office Commercial products and cloud services slowed to +5% from +13% in MarQ. IC Server products and cloud services slowed to +19% in JunQ from +30% in MarQ. LinkedIn growth slowed to +10% in JunQ from +21% in MarQ, as it was impacted by a weak job market and reductions in advertising spend. Search was negatively impacted by reductions in advertising spend. Transactional license purchasing continued to slow, particularly in small and medium businesses.

Overall, this was still a very good quarter, with a solid beat on revenue and EPS. The primary culprits for the stock's move lower, we think, is lackluster PBP segment growth coupled with Azure's performance. While Azure had great growth, with so many companies and consumers using the cloud as they work/learn from home, the Azure number was a slight letdown. This may be a slight cause for concern for Amazon (AMZN) and its rival AWS unit, which reports on July 30.

urn:contentItem:60DV-WN41-JC8H-K01C-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2020-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 23-Jul-20

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 14:43 | 14:14 | 12:39 | 11:31 | 10:43 | 10:10

14:43 ET

Intel: Earnings Preview -- Expectations for chip companies are running high:

Intel (INTC) is set to report Q2 results today after the close with a call to follow at 5pm ET. Current CapitalIQ consensus for EPS is $1.11 and for revenue it's $18.55 bln. Intel typically guides for EPS and revenue for the next quarter in the press release. In April, Intel guided to Q2 non-GAAP EPS of approx. $1.10 and revenue of approx. $18.50 bln. Expectations for semiconductor companies are running high this earnings season as several companies have reported strong results (like TXN on Tuesday and MU in late June) while several others have increased guidance in the past couple of weeks or so, including ADI, MXIM, IMOS, FORM, MXL, XLNX. In fairness, Intel is not a direct comparison as it does more than make chips. INTC has been transforming from a PC-centric company to a data-centric company, the latter of which accounted for 48% of revenue in 2019. Its data center segment is focused on cloud computing, network infrastructure, and intelligent edge applications as well as artificial intelligence (AI) and 5G. The PC side is not seeing a lot of growth but Intel recently began shipping its 10nm Intel Core processors, which feature a new core architecture. INTC is on track to launch its first 7nm-based product, a discrete GPU, at the end of 2021. Intel's top line growth tends to be pretty modest. However, the company also tends to be consistent relative to consensus estimates as it has not missed on EPS in any quarter over the past five years. And its EPS beats have been getting larger in recent quarters, with four consecutive double digit EPS beats. Overall, some big tech names have reported, but we are still early in the tech reporting cycle.We think Intel should have pretty good results. IBM had a nice quarter and said large enterprise customers are still spending. TXN's quarter is a good sign for Intel as well. Also, Microsoft (MSFT) had a mixed quarter, but its consumer/PC side did well with more people working at home. This is good news for Intel's PC business.

14:14 ET

AutoNation and LAD prove our point that car dealerships will be among first to recover:

AutoNation (AN +8%) is in the driver's seat today as it reported a ridiculously strong Q2 earnings report this morning, which followed a very strong Q1 result in May. As the nation's largest auto retailer with 325 car dealerships from coast to coast, AutoNation has been right in the crosshairs of the pandemic.

We had to do a double take when the earnings hit this morning. Analysts were expecting a 69% yr/yr decline in EPS. However, AN wound up posting 18% EPS growth at $1.41, way ahead of the $0.37 consensus estimate. Revenue fell 15.2% yr/yr to $4.53 bln, but that also was well ahead of the $4.09 bln consensus.

This was not just a one-off situation. Another nationwide car dealership, Lithia Motors (LAD +7%), also reported blowout results last night. LAD reported adjusted EPS of $3.72, also well ahead of the $1.54 consensus. LAD also reported strong upside revenue.

When we published our story stock on AN in May, we hypothesized that car dealerships would see a relatively quicker rebound than industries like air travel, hotels, restaurants, movie theatres, and especially cruise lines. That prediction seems to be coming to fruition with these reports today. Low interest rates and a consumer preference shift toward cars and away from public transit are clearly helping drive demand.

12:39 ET

Union Pacific derailed by soft volumes across multiple business groups:

Heading into this morning's earnings report, shares of Union Pacific (UNP) had rallied nearly 50% off their March lows. The rally, presumably based off hopes of an improving economy, has hit a roadblock as UNP's mixed results and cautious outlook has reset investors' expectations.

Through solid cost containment efforts, the railroad operator managed to outpace analysts' earnings expectations, generating EPS of $1.67 vs. the $1.56 consensus estimate. While the execution is commendable, the main story resides on the top-line where revenue fell by 24% yr/yr to $4.24 bln.

The drop was fueled by a 20% decrease in volumes, coupled with a 6% dip in average revenue per car, as negative COVID-19 effects rippled across business groups.

Main areas of weakness were not surprising, and included automotive (volume -64%), coal (-24%), and energy products (-26%). In order, auto plant shutdowns, weak export demand and low natural gas prices, and depressed oil prices pressured volumes in these segments.

While facing this very difficult business climate, UNP implemented several cost-cutting and productivity initiatives to help mitigate the demand erosion.

For instance, the company reduced its train and engine workforce by 32%, outpacing volume declines. Additionally, UNP increased train sizes and put more product on fewer trains, boosting efficiency.

Lower diesel fuel prices and reduced volumes also pushed fuel expenses lower by 56%.

Despite these positive factors, UNP's operating ratio deteriorated by 140 bps yr/yr to 61%. UNP is not alone in reporting a downturn in its operating ratio. CSX (CSX) and Canadian National Railway (CNI) reported operating ratios of 63.3% and 60.4% compared to 57.4% and 57.5%, respectively, a year ago. As a reminder, a lower operating ratio is better, illustrating the company's efficiency in generating profits.

Looking ahead, UNP expects 2020 volumes to be down by about 10% from 2019 levels. The company still sees considerable economic uncertainty due to the virus, especially as local economies reverse recent re-openings.

On the positive side, UNP has experienced a recent rebound in the automotive segment as vehicle manufacturing plants have reopened and as vehicle demand has strengthened. eCommerce is another area of strength that is likely to continue. Overall, though, UNP remains cautious about business conditions for the remainder of the year.

11:31 ET

Chipotle is rolling lower today as the burrito chain broke its string of huge beats:

Chipotle (CMG -2%) is rolling a bit lower today following its Q2 earnings report last night. There was some consternation heading into this report because CMG did not provide a mid-quarter update as some burger chains had.

Overall, the results were decent but did not blow us away. Not surprisingly, analysts were expecting a big drop in EPS on a yr/yr basis due to the pandemic and limitations on in-premise dining. That's what happened as adjusted EPS fell 90% yr/yr to $0.40. What's a bit odd is that EPS was right on the button with analyst expectations, which is surprising and rare given the lack of guidance and so many variables related to the pandemic. The unfortunate part of this is that CMG broke its string of seven consecutive double-digit EPS beats. The revenue decline was much more muted as it fell 4.8% yr/yr to $1.36 bln, slightly above analyst expectations.

In Q2, comps came in at -9.8%, down from +3.3% in Q1. As we said in our preview, investors were likely expecting a weak comp in Q2, but they would want to see at least gradual improvement as the quarter went on. CMG came through in this regard: March (part of Q1, but including here for context) at -16.0%; April -24.4%, May -7.0%, June +2.0%, and July (Q3) so far is +6.4% and that's despite CMG lapping a robust +10% comp in July 2019.

It's definitely a positive to see CMG back to positive comps the past couple of months. CMG is at a bit of a disadvantage relative to other fast food chains because it does not have a big drive-thru presence that consumers could use to avoid going into a restaurant during the pandemic.

However, CMG does deserve credit for getting customers to use its digital app and delivery service. Digital sales grew 216.3% yr/yr in Q2 and accounted for 60.7% of sales for the quarter. What's very encouraging, and we've said this in past comments, is that digital sales tend to be sticky. Once people get used to the app, they keep using it. Since sales troughed in late March, CMG has retained 70-80% of its digital sales gains while recovering 40-50% of in-store sales.

Despite the monthly comp improvement, the stock is lower today. We think the in-line EPS/revenue is being seen as a bit of a disappointment given CMG's penchant for reporting big beats. Also, the stock made a big move in recent months (from $415 at its mid-March low to $1180 heading into this report). We cautioned in our preview that a lot of good news is already priced in, so any stumble/in-line results could take a bite out of the stock. We are seeing a bit of that today.

10:43 ET

10:10 ET

Microsoft reports a solid quarter but a few areas like Azure were not as robust as in MarQ:

Microsoft (MSFT) reported another solid beat, and yet the stock trades modestly lower. That response makes sense if you dig into the quarter a bit. In terms of revenue, MSFT did quite well overall, reporting upside relative to prior guidance in two of its three segments - Intelligent Cloud (IC) and More Personal Computing (MPC) - while Productivity and Business Processes' (PBP) result was in-line. urn:contentItem:5WN1-HKS1-DYRK-949K-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 15:11 | 13:34 | 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

15:11 ET

Boeing hits a bit of turbulence today as 777X first flight gets delayed:

Boeing (BA -3.2%) is under some modest pressure after reporting Q2 results this morning. It reported a large miss and announced a delay with its 777X program.

The top-line numbers were actually pretty good relative to consensus as BA reported a core (non-GAAP) loss of $(5.82) per share while revenue fell 35.1% yr/yr to $15.75 bln. Both metrics saw big declines yr/yr but came in well ahead of consensus estimates. Boeing's well known 737 MAX issues and delays caused the large loss and revenue decline this quarter.

Investors who have followed Boeing over the long term know that its annual guidance is very important to monitor. However, BA suspended its full year guidance last quarter due to the MAX issues and that is still the case now. It sounds like it may be a while before we get annual guidance again.

So why is the stock down? We do not think it's the headline numbers as most investors expected big losses from the MAX. The culprit seems to a delay in its 777X program. Boeing is delaying first flight until early 2020 vs earlier guidance of late 2019. It's still progressing well through pre-flight testing and BA is still targeting late 2020 for first delivery of the 777X. However, BA now says there is significant risk to this schedule given engine challenges at its GE supplier.

The 737 MAX gets most of the attention, but investors have also been eagerly awaiting the 777X, which will be the world's largest and most efficient twin-engine jet. Other planes are larger, but they require four engines. The 777X needs just two engines despite its larger size and its spacious, widebody cabin.

In sum, the stock is down on the Q2 report. While some investors are likely focusing on the large loss, which is very unusual for Boeing, we think the 777X delay is the main reason the stock is lower today. With the 737 MAX issues and now 777X, it sort of seems like BA is playing whack-a-mole as it works through these issues.

The weakness was further exacerbated on the call this morning as the company said it expected the MAX issues will hurt cash flow for several years with it being more front-end loaded in the first few years.

We continue to like the long-term potential for Boeing. Specifically, BA thinks the worldwide fleet will double over the longer term as more countries with emerging economies boost air travel. Also, there is a large replacement cycle expected in the next few years. However, we think there will be a cloud over this stock until we get more clarity on when the 737 MAX will return to the air.

13:34 ET

Chipotle rolls higher on strong EPS upside; new CEO seems to be making progress:

ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG) is trading higher today following a strong Q2 report last night. Non-GAAP EPS Jumped 39% yr/yr to $3.99 while revenue rose 13.2% yr/yr to $1.43 bln. Both results were better than expected with EPS coming in well ahead of expectations.

The metric that really stands out to us is the same-store comps coming in a robust +10%, with +7% coming from a higher number of transactions and +3.5% from higher average check (mostly menu price increases). What's notable is that the Q2 comps have accelerated in recent quarters. In Q1, comps were +9.9%, and were at +6.1% in Q4 and +1.0% in Q3.

Chipotle has made a remarkable turnaround and these results are the product of a number of new initiatives being implemented by the company. CMG hired a new CEO in March 2018. Brian Niccol was tasked with turning around the struggling burrito chain.

Prior to joining Chipotle, Brian Niccol was at Taco Bell from 2011 and served as CEO from January 2015. He successfully repositioned Taco Bell as a lifestyle brand and successfully launched numerous product initiatives, including the new breakfast daypart which is the fastest growing daypart in the industry. He also transformed Taco Bell into a social media leader and revolutionized its digital approach. According to Eater,com, he was "largely credited with helping turning the brand into a #brand, using social platforms like Snapchat and Twitter to lure a more youthful demographic into late-night drive-thru runs for Doritos Locos tacos and fried chicken shell tacos."

The company has been busy revamping its marketing message (focusing more on real ingredients), building out its digital capabilities, launching its delivery service (now available at 95% of locations), and launching a new loyalty program, which is exceeding internal expectations, according to the company on the call last night.

There also are some menu additions on the way. On the call, CEO Niccol said that carne asada is the new addition that is furthest along. It "is nearing validation through our stage-gate process, after which we will decide on the timing of a potential national launch." Niccol also said CMG has a quesadilla pilot going on as well and it's getting high marks from customers. Desserts and nachos are also in the works. Also, catering is a tiny part of its business, but CMG sees tremendous opportunity for that sales channel.

In sum, CMG is ramping higher today. The strong EPS upside accounts for part of it, but it seems the excitement about changes ahead are just as responsible for the big move today. Upcoming menu changes, catering, delivery etc. are whetting investors' appetites. We have to tip our cap to the new CEO as he seems to be doing a good job in turning Chipotle around.

12:26 ET

Visa's growth accelerates on stronger consumer spending, ongoing shift towards digital payments: Visa (V) posted solid Q3 results after the close last night. The company reported EPS of $1.37 vs. the $1.32 consensus, extending its winning streak vs. analysts' expectations to fifteen straight quarters.

Growth accelerated during the quarter with revenue increasing by 13% on a constant currency basis to $5.84 bln, edging the $5.7 bln expectation. That represents an up-tick from last quarter's 9.5% top-line growth.

The better-than-expected Q3 results, combined with the integration of a few acquisitions and the continuing trend towards electronic payments, provided the confidence for Visa to slightly raise its outlook for FY19.

Visa now expects to generate EPS growth in the "mid-to-high teens" compared to its prior guidance of "high end of mid-teens".

Click here to access Visa's earnings press release.

All of Visa's key demand-related operating metrics showed improvement. Payment volume was up 9% on a constant currency basis vs. 8% in Q2. Cross-border volume was higher by 7% compared to 4% last quarter. Processed transactions grew by 12%, up from 11% in Q2, driven primarily by stronger growth in the U.S. and a full quarter of processing gains in Argentina.

There were a few main catalysts underlying Visa's performance.

First, consumer credit is expanding. Specifically, April U.S. consumer credit increased by $17.5 bln, followed by a $17.1 bln increase in May. This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

urn:contentItem:5WN0-J2W1-JC8H-K40G-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

12:26 ET

Visa's growth accelerates on stronger consumer spending, ongoing shift towards digital payments: Visa (V) posted solid Q3 results after the close last night. The company reported EPS of $1.37 vs. the $1.32 consensus, extending its winning streak vs. analysts' expectations to fifteen straight quarters.

Growth accelerated during the quarter with revenue increasing by 13% on a constant currency basis to $5.84 bln, edging the $5.7 bln expectation. That represents an up-tick from last quarter's 9.5% top-line growth.

The better-than-expected Q3 results, combined with the integration of a few acquisitions and the continuing trend towards electronic payments, provided the confidence for Visa to slightly raise its outlook for FY19.

Visa now expects to generate EPS growth in the "mid-to-high teens" compared to its prior guidance of "high end of mid-teens".

Click here to access Visa's earnings press release.

All of Visa's key demand-related operating metrics showed improvement. Payment volume was up 9% on a constant currency basis vs. 8% in Q2. Cross-border volume was higher by 7% compared to 4% last quarter. Processed transactions grew by 12%, up from 11% in Q2, driven primarily by stronger growth in the U.S. and a full quarter of processing gains in Argentina.

There were a few main catalysts underlying Visa's performance.

First, consumer credit is expanding. Specifically, April U.S. consumer credit increased by $17.5 bln, followed by a $17.1 bln increase in May. This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.
