urn:contentItem:5WN1-HMD1-JC8H-K198-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 15:11 | 13:34 | 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

15:11 ET

Boeing hits a bit of turbulence today as 777X first flight gets delayed:

Boeing (BA -3.2%) is under some modest pressure after reporting Q2 results this morning. It reported a large miss and announced a delay with its 777X program.

The top-line numbers were actually pretty good relative to consensus as BA reported a core (non-GAAP) loss of $(5.82) per share while revenue fell 35.1% yr/yr to $15.75 bln. Both metrics saw big declines yr/yr but came in well ahead of consensus estimates. Boeing's well known 737 MAX issues and delays caused the large loss and revenue decline this quarter.

Investors who have followed Boeing over the long term know that its annual guidance is very important to monitor. However, BA suspended its full year guidance last quarter due to the MAX issues and that is still the case now. It sounds like it may be a while before we get annual guidance again.

So why is the stock down? We do not think it's the headline numbers as most investors expected big losses from the MAX. The culprit seems to a delay in its 777X program. Boeing is delaying first flight until early 2020 vs earlier guidance of late 2019. It's still progressing well through pre-flight testing and BA is still targeting late 2020 for first delivery of the 777X. However, BA now says there is significant risk to this schedule given engine challenges at its GE supplier.

The 737 MAX gets most of the attention, but investors have also been eagerly awaiting the 777X, which will be the world's largest and most efficient twin-engine jet. Other planes are larger, but they require four engines. The 777X needs just two engines despite its larger size and its spacious, widebody cabin.

In sum, the stock is down on the Q2 report. While some investors are likely focusing on the large loss, which is very unusual for Boeing, we think the 777X delay is the main reason the stock is lower today. With the 737 MAX issues and now 777X, it sort of seems like BA is playing whack-a-mole as it works through these issues.

The weakness was further exacerbated on the call this morning as the company said it expected the MAX issues will hurt cash flow for several years with it being more front-end loaded in the first few years.

We continue to like the long-term potential for Boeing. Specifically, BA thinks the worldwide fleet will double over the longer term as more countries with emerging economies boost air travel. Also, there is a large replacement cycle expected in the next few years. However, we think there will be a cloud over this stock until we get more clarity on when the 737 MAX will return to the air.

13:34 ET

Chipotle rolls higher on strong EPS upside; new CEO seems to be making progress:

ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG) is trading higher today following a strong Q2 report last night. Non-GAAP EPS Jumped 39% yr/yr to $3.99 while revenue rose 13.2% yr/yr to $1.43 bln. Both results were better than expected with EPS coming in well ahead of expectations.

The metric that really stands out to us is the same-store comps coming in a robust +10%, with +7% coming from a higher number of transactions and +3.5% from higher average check (mostly menu price increases). What's notable is that the Q2 comps have accelerated in recent quarters. In Q1, comps were +9.9%, and were at +6.1% in Q4 and +1.0% in Q3.

Chipotle has made a remarkable turnaround and these results are the product of a number of new initiatives being implemented by the company. CMG hired a new CEO in March 2018. Brian Niccol was tasked with turning around the struggling burrito chain.

Prior to joining Chipotle, Brian Niccol was at Taco Bell from 2011 and served as CEO from January 2015. He successfully repositioned Taco Bell as a lifestyle brand and successfully launched numerous product initiatives, including the new breakfast daypart which is the fastest growing daypart in the industry. He also transformed Taco Bell into a social media leader and revolutionized its digital approach. According to Eater,com, he was "largely credited with helping turning the brand into a #brand, using social platforms like Snapchat and Twitter to lure a more youthful demographic into late-night drive-thru runs for Doritos Locos tacos and fried chicken shell tacos."

The company has been busy revamping its marketing message (focusing more on real ingredients), building out its digital capabilities, launching its delivery service (now available at 95% of locations), and launching a new loyalty program, which is exceeding internal expectations, according to the company on the call last night.

There also are some menu additions on the way. On the call, CEO Niccol said that carne asada is the new addition that is furthest along. It "is nearing validation through our stage-gate process, after which we will decide on the timing of a potential national launch." Niccol also said CMG has a quesadilla pilot going on as well and it's getting high marks from customers. Desserts and nachos are also in the works. Also, catering is a tiny part of its business, but CMG sees tremendous opportunity for that sales channel.

In sum, CMG is ramping higher today. The strong EPS upside accounts for part of it, but it seems the excitement about changes ahead are just as responsible for the big move today. Upcoming menu changes, catering, delivery etc. are whetting investors' appetites. We have to tip our cap to the new CEO as he seems to be doing a good job in turning Chipotle around.

12:26 ET

Visa's growth accelerates on stronger consumer spending, ongoing shift towards digital payments: Visa (V) posted solid Q3 results after the close last night. The company reported EPS of $1.37 vs. the $1.32 consensus, extending its winning streak vs. analysts' expectations to fifteen straight quarters.

Growth accelerated during the quarter with revenue increasing by 13% on a constant currency basis to $5.84 bln, edging the $5.7 bln expectation. That represents an up-tick from last quarter's 9.5% top-line growth.

The better-than-expected Q3 results, combined with the integration of a few acquisitions and the continuing trend towards electronic payments, provided the confidence for Visa to slightly raise its outlook for FY19.

Visa now expects to generate EPS growth in the "mid-to-high teens" compared to its prior guidance of "high end of mid-teens".

Click here to access Visa's earnings press release.

All of Visa's key demand-related operating metrics showed improvement. Payment volume was up 9% on a constant currency basis vs. 8% in Q2. Cross-border volume was higher by 7% compared to 4% last quarter. Processed transactions grew by 12%, up from 11% in Q2, driven primarily by stronger growth in the U.S. and a full quarter of processing gains in Argentina.

There were a few main catalysts underlying Visa's performance.

First, consumer credit is expanding. Specifically, April U.S. consumer credit increased by $17.5 bln, followed by a $17.1 bln increase in May. This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

12:26 ET

Visa's growth accelerates on stronger consumer spending, ongoing shift towards digital payments: Visa (V) posted solid Q3 results after the close last night. The company reported EPS of $1.37 vs. the $1.32 consensus, extending its winning streak vs. analysts' expectations to fifteen straight quarters.

Growth accelerated during the quarter with revenue increasing by 13% on a constant currency basis to $5.84 bln, edging the $5.7 bln expectation. That represents an up-tick from last quarter's 9.5% top-line growth.

The better-than-expected Q3 results, combined with the integration of a few acquisitions and the continuing trend towards electronic payments, provided the confidence for Visa to slightly raise its outlook for FY19.

Visa now expects to generate EPS growth in the "mid-to-high teens" compared to its prior guidance of "high end of mid-teens".

Click here to access Visa's earnings press release.

All of Visa's key demand-related operating metrics showed improvement. Payment volume was up 9% on a constant currency basis vs. 8% in Q2. Cross-border volume was higher by 7% compared to 4% last quarter. Processed transactions grew by 12%, up from 11% in Q2, driven primarily by stronger growth in the U.S. and a full quarter of processing gains in Argentina.

There were a few main catalysts underlying Visa's performance.

First, consumer credit is expanding. Specifically, April U.S. consumer credit increased by $17.5 bln, followed by a $17.1 bln increase in May. This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

urn:contentItem:5WN0-J2W1-JC8H-K409-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HMD1-JC8H-K191-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 13:34 | 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

13:34 ET

Chipotle rolls higher on strong EPS upside; new CEO seems to be making progress:

ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG) is trading higher today following a strong Q2 report last night. Non-GAAP EPS Jumped 39% yr/yr to $3.99 while revenue rose 13.2% yr/yr to $1.43 bln. Both results were better than expected with EPS coming in well ahead of expectations.

The metric that really stands out to us is the same-store comps coming in a robust +10%, with +7% coming from a higher number of transactions and +3.5% from higher average check (mostly menu price increases). What's notable is that the Q2 comps have accelerated in recent quarters. In Q1, comps were +9.9%, and were at +6.1% in Q4 and +1.0% in Q3.

Chipotle has made a remarkable turnaround and these results are the product of a number of new initiatives being implemented by the company. CMG hired a new CEO in March 2018. Brian Niccol was tasked with turning around the struggling burrito chain.

Prior to joining Chipotle, Brian Niccol was at Taco Bell from 2011 and served as CEO from January 2015. He successfully repositioned Taco Bell as a lifestyle brand and successfully launched numerous product initiatives, including the new breakfast daypart which is the fastest growing daypart in the industry. He also transformed Taco Bell into a social media leader and revolutionized its digital approach. According to Eater,com, he was "largely credited with helping turning the brand into a #brand, using social platforms like Snapchat and Twitter to lure a more youthful demographic into late-night drive-thru runs for Doritos Locos tacos and fried chicken shell tacos."

The company has been busy revamping its marketing message (focusing more on real ingredients), building out its digital capabilities, launching its delivery service (now available at 95% of locations), and launching a new loyalty program, which is exceeding internal expectations, according to the company on the call last night.

There also are some menu additions on the way. On the call, CEO Niccol said that carne asada is the new addition that is furthest along. It "is nearing validation through our stage-gate process, after which we will decide on the timing of a potential national launch." Niccol also said CMG has a quesadilla pilot going on as well and it's getting high marks from customers. Desserts and nachos are also in the works. Also, catering is a tiny part of its business, but CMG sees tremendous opportunity for that sales channel.

In sum, CMG is ramping higher today. The strong EPS upside accounts for part of it, but it seems the excitement about changes ahead are just as responsible for the big move today. Upcoming menu changes, catering, delivery etc. are whetting investors' appetites. We have to tip our cap to the new CEO as he seems to be doing a good job in turning Chipotle around.

12:26 ET

Visa's growth accelerates on stronger consumer spending, ongoing shift towards digital payments: Visa (V) posted solid Q3 results after the close last night. The company reported EPS of $1.37 vs. the $1.32 consensus, extending its winning streak vs. analysts' expectations to fifteen straight quarters.

Growth accelerated during the quarter with revenue increasing by 13% on a constant currency basis to $5.84 bln, edging the $5.7 bln expectation. That represents an up-tick from last quarter's 9.5% top-line growth.

The better-than-expected Q3 results, combined with the integration of a few acquisitions and the continuing trend towards electronic payments, provided the confidence for Visa to slightly raise its outlook for FY19.

Visa now expects to generate EPS growth in the "mid-to-high teens" compared to its prior guidance of "high end of mid-teens".

Click here to access Visa's earnings press release.

All of Visa's key demand-related operating metrics showed improvement. Payment volume was up 9% on a constant currency basis vs. 8% in Q2. Cross-border volume was higher by 7% compared to 4% last quarter. Processed transactions grew by 12%, up from 11% in Q2, driven primarily by stronger growth in the U.S. and a full quarter of processing gains in Argentina.

There were a few main catalysts underlying Visa's performance.

First, consumer credit is expanding. Specifically, April U.S. consumer credit increased by $17.5 bln, followed by a $17.1 bln increase in May. This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.

11:11 ET

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HKS1-DYRK-949B-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 13:34 | 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

13:34 ET

Chipotle rolls higher on strong EPS upside; new CEO seems to be making progress:

ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG) is trading higher today following a strong Q2 report last night. Non-GAAP EPS Jumped 39% yr/yr to $3.99 while revenue rose 13.2% yr/yr to $1.43 bln. Both results were better than expected with EPS coming in well ahead of expectations.

The metric that really stands out to us is the same-store comps coming in a robust +10%, with +7% coming from a higher number of transactions and +3.5% from higher average check (mostly menu price increases). What's notable is that the Q2 comps have accelerated in recent quarters. In Q1, comps were +9.9%, and were at +6.1% in Q4 and +1.0% in Q3.

Chipotle has made a remarkable turnaround and these results are the product of a number of new initiatives being implemented by the company. CMG hired a new CEO in March 2018. Brian Niccol was tasked with turning around the struggling burrito chain.

Prior to joining Chipotle, Brian Niccol was at Taco Bell from 2011 and served as CEO from January 2015. He successfully repositioned Taco Bell as a lifestyle brand and successfully launched numerous product initiatives, including the new breakfast daypart which is the fastest growing daypart in the industry. He also transformed Taco Bell into a social media leader and revolutionized its digital approach. According to Eater,com, he was "largely credited with helping turning the brand into a #brand, using social platforms like Snapchat and Twitter to lure a more youthful demographic into late-night drive-thru runs for Doritos Locos tacos and fried chicken shell tacos."

The company has been busy revamping its marketing message (focusing more on real ingredients), building out its digital capabilities, launching its delivery service (now available at 95% of locations), and launching a new loyalty program, which is exceeding internal expectations, according to the company on the call last night.

There also are some menu additions on the way. On the call, CEO Niccol said that carne asada is the new addition that is furthest along. It "is nearing validation through our stage-gate process, after which we will decide on the timing of a potential national launch." Niccol also said CMG has a quesadilla pilot going on as well and it's getting high marks from customers. Desserts and nachos are also in the works. Also, catering is a tiny part of its business, but CMG sees tremendous opportunity for that sales channel.

In sum, CMG is ramping higher today. The strong EPS upside accounts for part of it, but it seems the excitement about changes ahead are just as responsible for the big move today. Upcoming menu changes, catering, delivery etc. are whetting investors' appetites. We have to tip our cap to the new CEO as he seems to be doing a good job in turning Chipotle around.

12:26 ET

Visa's growth accelerates on stronger consumer spending, ongoing shift towards digital payments: Visa (V) posted solid Q3 results after the close last night. The company reported EPS of $1.37 vs. the $1.32 consensus, extending its winning streak vs. analysts' expectations to fifteen straight quarters.

Growth accelerated during the quarter with revenue increasing by 13% on a constant currency basis to $5.84 bln, edging the $5.7 bln expectation. That represents an up-tick from last quarter's 9.5% top-line growth.

The better-than-expected Q3 results, combined with the integration of a few acquisitions and the continuing trend towards electronic payments, provided the confidence for Visa to slightly raise its outlook for FY19.

Visa now expects to generate EPS growth in the "mid-to-high teens" compared to its prior guidance of "high end of mid-teens".

Click here to access Visa's earnings press release.

All of Visa's key demand-related operating metrics showed improvement. Payment volume was up 9% on a constant currency basis vs. 8% in Q2. Cross-border volume was higher by 7% compared to 4% last quarter. Processed transactions grew by 12%, up from 11% in Q2, driven primarily by stronger growth in the U.S. and a full quarter of processing gains in Argentina.

There were a few main catalysts underlying Visa's performance.

First, consumer credit is expanding. Specifically, April U.S. consumer credit increased by $17.5 bln, followed by a $17.1 bln increase in May. This indicates that consumers are willing to spend and borrow money and they are confident in their ability to repay debt. Therefore, the growth in consumer credit is both a positive factor for Visa and the economy.

Second, Visa also benefited from lower-than-expected client incentives as well as a more favorable timing of Easter, relative to last year, which does temper some enthusiasm regarding its results.

Last, Visa has been very aggressive on the acquisition front.

On June 25, Visa acquired the token services and ticketing business from Rambus. This ties in with Visa's strategy to become a leader in blockchain technologies which would support cryptocurrencies like Facebook's (FB) Libra. In fact, Visa is one of the founding members of the Libra Foundation that is working to launch that currency.

A few days following that acquisition, Visa purchased Verify, the owner of a dispute resolution platform that will bolster Visa's risk and fraud management solutions.

Key Takeaways: Visa's strong results are driven by a potent secular trend towards digitization of commerce and a healthy consumer. The pick-up in growth -- albeit modest -- provides confidence that the global economy hasn't significantly deteriorated.

From a company-specific standpoint, Visa's strategy revolves around acquisitions that enhance and diversify its payment processing capabilities.

11:11 ET

UPS moves higher as next-day delivery demand aligns with strategic investments:

Shares of UPS (UPS +9%) are taking off after the company reported better than expected second quarter results this morning.

Earnings grew 1% on a 3% increase in revenue. The company says that it turned rising demand for next-day service into strong financial results in the US while leveraging asset-light and proven cost management strategies in its International and Supply Chain and Freight segments. Total operating profit grew 6.3% on an adjusted basis, with growth in all segments; adjusted operating margin expanded by 30 basis points.

The US Domestic segment generated significant volume growth in all products, led by a more than 30% surge in UPS Next Day Air volume, which was driven by accelerated delivery requirements from e-commerce shippers. Demand for next day service in the US is surging, and UPS made timely strategic investments in that capacity.

The nation's largest courier also saw an inflection point in operating leverage in the US as its strategic investments started to pay off. UPS expects US operating margin improvement to continue.

UPS also announced an extensive roll-out of new customer services and capabilities, including the introduction of new Sunday service starting in 2020. The new solutions are designed to capture growth opportunities in certain strategic markets: small- and medium-sized businesses, e-commerce, high-growth international countries, and healthcare and life sciences.

Analysts were skeptical of UPS's fiscal 2019 earnings guidance, but today's encouraging results may appear to ease those concerns.

These results compare favorably to FedEx's (FDX) more cautious outlook from last month. FedEx continues to struggle with European exposure brought about by the TNT Express acquisition.

UPS stock is attempting to break out from its slight downtrend as it approaches resistance from its April highs.

07:01 ET

Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review:

Big technology stocks are trading lower premarket after the Department of Justice (DOJ) announced that it is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

We already knew that regulators were swarming big technology companies, but this news confirms that the Federal government is serious about potentially reigning in the power of the technology behemoths.

This is separate from the House Judiciary Committee bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets that was announced in early June. Last month, we learned that the DOJ has taken authority regarding potential antitrust issues at Alphabet (GOOG/L) and Apple (AAPL) while the FTC will oversee Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).

Yesterday's news confirms that the DOJ will take a holistic review of potential antitrust matters.

The DOJ has yet to confirm that is already investigating anti-competitive practices at Alphabet specifically. The US government closed an investigation into the company without taking action in 2013, but the company's market position has continued to strengthen since then.

Google dominates search, Facebookdominates social media and Amazon dominates eCommerce. They are the three bigest advertisers on the internet. Apple seems to be the least at risk, although iOS and the app store give it tremendous power over the technology sector. Ironically, the largest U.S. tech company, Microsoft (MSFT), does not seem to be at risk.

The four primary targets of regulators account for just over 33% of the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) and nearly 12% of the S&P 500 (SPY). Clearly, these four stocks have considerable influence over the US stock market.

Politicians have been calling for regulations on Silicon Valley for some time, but we are now finally seeing the wheels set into motion to potentially curb the influence of the most powerful companies in the Western world.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for a while as investigations will take time to play out.

Facebook will report second quarter results this afternoon; Alphabet and Amazon will report Thursday afternoon and Apple reports on the afternoon of July 30.

Tech giants premarket: FB -1.2% GOOG/L -1.1% AMZN -0.8% AAPL -0.5%.

Nasdaq 100 futures are down 0.3%.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-HKS1-DYRK-949R-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 24-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 15:11 | 13:34 | 12:26 | 11:11 | Big tech stocks fall after DOJ announces broad antitrust review 07:01

15:11 ET

Boeing hits a bit of turbulence today as 777X first flight gets delayed:

Boeing (BA -3.2%) is under some modest pressure after reporting Q2 results this morning. It reported a large miss and announced a delay with its 777X program.

The top-line numbers were actually pretty good relative to consensus as BA reported a core (non-GAAP) loss of $(5.82) per share while revenue fell 35.1% yr/yr to $15.75 bln. Both metrics saw big declines yr/yr but came in well ahead of consensus estimates. Boeing's well known 737 MAX issues and delays caused the large loss and revenue decline this quarter.

Investors who have followed Boeing over the long term know that its annual guidance is very important to monitor. However, BA suspended its full year guidance last quarter due to the MAX issues and that is still the case now. It sounds like it may be a while before we get annual guidance again.

So why is the stock down? We do not think it's the headline numbers as most investors expected big losses from the MAX. The culprit seems to a delay in its 777X program. Boeing is delaying first flight until early 2020 vs earlier guidance of late 2019. It's still progressing well through pre-flight testing and BA is still targeting late 2020 for first delivery of the 777X. However, BA now says there is significant risk to this schedule given engine challenges at its GE supplier.

The 737 MAX gets most of the attention, but investors have also been eagerly awaiting the 777X, which will be the world's largest and most efficient twin-engine jet. Other planes are larger, but they require four engines. The 777X needs just two engines despite its larger size and its spacious, widebody cabin.

In sum, the stock is down on the Q2 report. While some investors are likely focusing on the large loss, which is very unusual for Boeing, we think the 777X delay is the main reason the stock is lower today. With the 737 MAX issues and now 777X, it sort of seems like BA is playing whack-a-mole as it works through these issues.

The weakness was further exacerbated on the call this morning as the company said it expected the MAX issues will hurt cash flow for several years with it being more front-end loaded in the first few years.

We continue to like the long-term potential for Boeing. Specifically, BA thinks the worldwide fleet will double over the longer term as more countries with emerging economies boost air travel. Also, there is a large replacement cycle expected in the next few years. However, we think there will be a cloud over this stock until we get more clarity on when the 737 MAX will return to the air.

urn:contentItem:5WKH-RB01-DYRK-93FY-00000-00Briefing.com: Story Stocks (R)2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:58ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Story Stocks (R)

Story Stocks (R)

Updated: 17-Jul-19

Quotes at time of story, top stories today: 15:07 | 14:07 | 11:42 | 09:04

15:07 ET

Amazon: Strong Prime Day, increased regulatory scrutiny in Europe ahead of Q2 results:

Amazon (AMZN -0.5%) shares are in focus after another successful Prime Day wrapped up yesterday.

For the first time, Prime Day actually spanned two days this year. Impressively, Amazon said that sales surpassed the previous Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined.

Amazon has single-handedly created its own shopping holiday. Other retailers even put on their owns sales in order to join in on the midsummer sales event.

Amazon accounts for nearly half of all ecommerce sales in the U.S. Meanwhile, ecommerce represented only 14% of retail sales last year, according to the Department of Commerce.

Perhaps even more importantly, Amazon said it welcomed more new Prime members on July 15 than on any previous day, and almost as many on July 16 -- making these the two biggest days ever for member signups. Obviously, that bodes well for the company going forward.

On a more somber note, the European Commission this morning "opened a formal antitrust investigation to assess whether Amazon's use of sensitive data from independent retailers who sell on its marketplace is in breach of EU competition rules."

Antitrust concerns continue to circle the biggest technology companies. Recall that last month, the House Judiciary Committee announced a bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets here in the US. The FTC will oversee potential antitrust issues for Amazon.

Democrats running for president are also targeting big tech companies as their market power continues to grow unabated.

A regulatory overhang will likely be in place for some time as potential investigations will take years to play out.

Investors have more pressing issues to consider, as Amazon will report second quarter results next Thursday, July 25.

Amazon has blown away profit estimates for seven consecutive quarters, offsetting concerns that revenue growth dropped to its slowest level (17%) in four years. High-margin businesses like AWS and advertising are boosting the bottom line while the ecommerce business begins to mature.

Amazon is expected to grow operating profit by 42% to $17.65 bln with revenue up 18% to more than $275 bln this year.

14:07 ET

Cintas jumps higher on strong MayQ report and FY20 guidance:

Cintas Corp. (CTAS, +8.5%) is trading nicely higher today after following the company's Q4 (May) earnings report last night. The report provided a first look at the company's FY20 guidance, which turned out to be strong as well. The stock has been a huge mover, so Cintas really needed to come in with strong results, and it seems to have done just that.

Cintas is the largest supplier of work uniforms in the US, operating primarily on a rental basis and supplying clients ranging from food service industry workers, with customers including McDonald's and Starbucks, to mechanics and workers on oil and gas rigs, who require more durable uniforms. The company offers more than just uniforms, though, as it has smartly branched into adjacent areas, including floor care, restroom supplies, first aid, and fire extinguishers.

Non-GAAP EPS rose 17% yr/yr to $2.07 while revenue rose 7.4% yr/yr to $1.79 bln. EPS was well above market expectations (its largest EPS beat in seven quarters) while revenue had some modest upside to market expectations. In terms of guidance for FY20, Cintas expects EPS of $8.30-8.45 and revenue of $7.24-7.31 bln. The mid-point of the EPS guidance was nicely above expectations while revenue guidance was basically in-line.

We were a bit nervous heading into this earnings report because the stock had made such a huge run recently, which told us that investor expectations were running pretty high, so anything short of a large beat-and-raise might have led the stock sell-off. Also, we sensed that there was some nervousness among investors, as the stock traded lower yesterday heading into this report.

These results were good overall, and FY19 did well on a full year basis all things considered. Something to be aware of is that Cintas is still digesting its largest acquisition ever -- it bought its rival G&K Services in 2017 for $2.1 bln. On top of that, Cintas has been transitioning from a decades-old platform to a new ERP platform (SAP) for the entire company, which has required changing processes and retraining employees. It's still a work-in-progress, as about 65% of operations are now on SAP, with remaining locations expected to be onboarded in FY20. Essentially, Cintas is currently undergoing a lot of change.

As we said in our preview, Cintas' outlook is helpful to know even beyond its implications for the company's stock. The company's business is very closely tied to the health of the economy generally. Cintas CFO Michael Hansen said on the call that that management "feel[s] pretty good about the macro still." He added, "Job growth has continued to be pretty good... we like the momentum in the business."

In sum, we would rather have seen revenue come in with a stronger beat, but the result is pretty typical for Cintas, as the company is not known for large top line upside. Cintas is known for steady, but not spectacular, EPS and revenue growth, but that's ok with most investors. We were holding our breath as we got out first look at FY20 guidance, and it came in better than expected. Cintas is clearly benefiting from a strong overall economy and the fact that the unemployment rate has been falling. More workers means more uniform rentals.

11:42 ET

United Airlines next carrier to post solid results, demonstrating resiliency in tough climate: On the heels of Delta's (DAL) strong Q2 results and American Airlines' (AAL) raised guidance last week, United Airlines (UAL) posted solid quarterly results last night. For the quarter, it generated EPS of $4.21, surpassing the $4.09 consensus, with revenue up 5.8% yr/yr to $11.4 bln.

Passenger revenue per available seat mile (PRASM), also known as unit revenue, is a key metric that measures sales efficiency across its total flight capacity. It came in at +2.5%, the high end of its +0.5-2.5% guidance range.

UAL's upside EPS result also provided enough confidence for management to raise its FY19 EPS guidance to $10.50-$12.00 from $10-$12.

Click here to access UAL's earnings press release.

The set of positive reports from UAL and its peers exhibit an impressive resiliency as they come in the face of potent headwinds. Most notably, these include the grounding of Boeing's (BA) 737 MAX aircraft and the trade disputes/tariffs that have created uncertainty for businesses.

The encouraging quarterly results from UAL's peers, along with lower crude oil prices, propelled UAL's stock higher into its report last night. The 20% surge higher since early June is one reason why shares have struggled to gain altitude today.

Another cause for the muted reaction is that UAL guided for Q3 unit revenue (PRASM) growth of +0.5-2.5%. At the mid-point, this represents a decline from Q2's +2.5%. Additionally, the company raised its FY19 unit cost to 0.5-1.0% from flat and lowered its capacity growth to +3-4% from +4-5%.

Still, UAL is performing quite well in a challenging environment.

CEO Oscar Munoz credits this to the company's strategic plan to add more flights between its mid-continent hubs (Chicago, Denver, Houston) and smaller cities where it can charge higher fares. The premise is that it would bolster margins and profitability. With UAL posting $1.4 bln in pre-tax earnings - a quarterly record - it appears the strategy is working.

Last, while the grounding of the 737 MAX aircraft has caused disruptions across the industry, UAL's exposure is very light.

For instance, UAL has 14 of these aircraft (1% of fleet) while Southwest Airlines (LUV) has 34 (6% of fleet). The higher exposure at LUV and other airlines has been a positive for UAL as passengers are forced to change flights and carriers.

Key Takeaway: The word that comes to mind when describing UAL and other airlines' financial performance is "resilient." Despite global economic uncertainty stemming from trade disputes and tariffs, and the ongoing issues surrounding the 737 MAX aircraft, UAL delivered solid Q2 results.

UAL believes that its strategy to expand flight coverage into smaller destinations has provided a competitive advantage and a boost to profits. Its lighter exposure to the 737 MAX is another positive factor.

09:04 ET

IPO market reopens on soft note as DouYu prices at low end of expectations: After a two week pause, the IPO market is back in business this morning. However, it didn't return in overly emphatic fashion as China-based DouYu (DOYU) priced its 67.39 mln ADS deal at $11.50, the low end of the $11.50-$14.00 range. Given the concerns swirling around trade disputes and tariffs, and the softening economy in China, sentiment for Chinese IPOs hasn't been very bullish.

For instance, three of the most recent Chinese IPOs -- Jiayin Group (JFIN), So-Young International (SY), and Ruhnn Holding (RUHN) -- are trading 16%, 18%, and 69% below their IPO opening prices.

Therefore, we wouldn't equate DOYU's weak pricing to any material change in the underlying IPO market.

Tomorrow morning, we will have a better sense whether conditions shifted during the break with several deals expected to price. Considering that the indices are hovering around all-time high levels, we would expect most of the IPOs to draw healthy demand.

As for DOYU, it offered 44.9 mln ADS in this deal, raising $516.4 mln in total gross proceeds. The company plans to use the capital to expand its eSports content and content genres, to strengthen technologies and big data analytic capabilities, and to invest in marketing activities.

The lead underwriters on the deal are Morgan Stanley, JP Morgan, BofA Merrill Lynch, and CMBI.

Shares are set to open for trading later this morning on the Nasdaq.

Overview

DOYU is the largest game-centric live streaming platform in China operating its platform both on PC and mobile apps. As of December 31, 2018 and March 31, 2019, it had 253.6 mln and 280.9 mln registered users, respectively. With 110.1 mln average MAUs on its PC platform and 49.1 mln average MAUs on its mobile platform, DOYU had 159.2 mln average total MAUs during 1Q19.

Its platform brings together a pool of top streamers and provides a sustainable streamer development system. As of March 31, 2018 and 2019, DOYU's platform had 4.6 mln and 6.5 mlnn registered streamers, including more than 2,000 and 6,500 top streamers, each of whom entered into an exclusive contract with DOYU directly.

As one of the first game-centric live streaming platforms to make the jump into eSports, DOYU believes it is strategically positioned to benefit from the proliferation of the eSports industry in China. Through its investments in and collaborations with a variety of participants across the value chain, DOYU has gained access to premium eSports content.

DOYU also organizes its own tournaments and produces exclusive eSports content only available on its platform which further attracts viewers and improves their stickiness.

Leveraging a large number of viewers and a deep pool of streamers, DOYU's monetization channels mainly consists of live streaming and advertisements. Live streaming is its main monetization channel and generated 81.5% and 90.9% of its total net revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2018 and 2019 respectively.

Financials

For the three months ended March 31, 2019, revenue jumped by 123% yr/yr to RMB1.49 bln. The growth was mainly attributable to an increase in live streaming revenue, which surged by 149% to RMB1.35 bln.

DOYU's gross margin grew from 3.7% for the three months ended March 31, 2018 to 13.6% for the three months ended March 31, 2019, driven by growth in live streaming revenue. Its bandwidth costs increased by a manageable 27% to RMB162 mln.

Sales and Marketing is its largest expense at 49% of total revenue. For the period, it increased by 61% to RMB123.6 mln.

DOYU generated income before income taxes of RMB17.5 mln compared to a loss of RMB(154.3) mln in the year ago period.

With 110.1 mln average MAUs on its PC platform and 49.1 mln average MAUs on its mobile platform, DOYU had 159.2 mln average total MAUs during 1Q19.

Its platform brings together a pool of top streamers and provides a sustainable streamer development system. As of March 31, 2018 and 2019, DOYU's platform had 4.6 mln and 6.5 mlnn registered streamers, including more than 2,000 and 6,500 top streamers, each of whom entered into an exclusive contract with DOYU directly.

As one of the first game-centric live streaming platforms to make the jump into eSports, DOYU believes it is strategically positioned to benefit from the proliferation of the eSports industry in China. Through its investments in and collaborations with a variety of participants across the value chain, DOYU has gained access to premium eSports content.

DOYU also organizes its own tournaments and produces exclusive eSports content only available on its platform which further attracts viewers and improves their stickiness.

Leveraging a large number of viewers and a deep pool of streamers, DOYU's monetization channels mainly consists of live streaming and advertisements. Live streaming is its main monetization channel and generated 81.5% and 90.9% of its total net revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2018 and 2019 respectively.

Financials

For the three months ended March 31, 2019, revenue jumped by 123% yr/yr to RMB1.49 bln. The growth was mainly attributable to an increase in live streaming revenue, which surged by 149% to RMB1.35 bln.

DOYU's gross margin grew from 3.7% for the three months ended March 31, 2018 to 13.6% for the three months ended March 31, 2019, driven by growth in live streaming revenue. Its bandwidth costs increased by a manageable 27% to RMB162 mln.

Sales and Marketing is its largest expense at 49% of total revenue. For the period, it increased by 61% to RMB123.6 mln.

DOYU generated income before income taxes of RMB17.5 mln compared to a loss of RMB(154.3) mln in the year ago period.
